HEADLINE: Preventing the Next North Korea 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's radically different responses to weapons threats from Iraq and North Korea have confused the American people. Worse, they risk sending other rogue states the perverse message that the way to receive lenient treatment from Washington is to develop nuclear weapons. One reason Pyongyang's defiant provocations are met with diplomatic overtures while Baghdad's mix of cooperation and evasion elicits threats of force is the strong suspicion that Kim Jong Il already has nuclear weapons while Saddam Hussein does not. 
 That may be a good argument for not backing North Korea into a corner. But it is not a very promising formula for avoiding future nuclear threats -- threats almost certain to materialize in the years immediately ahead. What is needed is not just crisis management but a more comprehensive approach to the spread of nuclear weapons. Failure to address this problem more intelligently could mean waking up 10 years from now to discover a half-dozen or more new states with nuclear weapons, including some in the world's most volatile and economically sensitive regions. 
 Thus far the Bush administration has seemed more interested in weakening than reinforcing the two main international agreements intended to rein in nuclear weapons building: the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Neither is perfect. But they are useful tools that could be made more effective through strong American support.
Under the nonproliferation treaty, only five countries are officially recognized nuclear weapons powers: America, Russia, Britain, France and China. But three countries that have never signed the treaty, India, Pakistan and Israel, have developed nuclear weapons outside its structures, and a fourth, North Korea, has secretly violated its obligations and is now moving to withdraw from the treaty to free its nuclear installations from international surveillance. Three other signatories, Iran, Iraq and Libya, are also believed to have secret nuclear weapons programs, and several others, including Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, have the technical ability to build nuclear bombs if they feel threatened by a growing number of nuclear rivals.
The challenge for the United States is to strengthen the incentives not to build nuclear weapons. America is the planet's strongest military power. But it would be much less secure in a world where treaties were allowed to become meaningless and countries believed their only reliable defense was to build nuclear arms. 
Strengthening the nonproliferation treaty requires existing nuclear powers to show good faith by radically reducing their cold war nuclear arsenals, as the Americans and the Russians have recently agreed to do. The Bush administration should also drop its provocative policy of threatening nuclear retaliation against non-nuclear threats. And far more serious pressure must be put on India, Pakistan and Israel to sign the nonproliferation treaty. Washington's credibility in insisting that North Korea not withdraw from the treaty is not helped by its reluctance to press these countries to sign.
The Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, rejected by the Republican-led Senate in 1999, is another neglected restraint. Its ban on all testing could act as a limited freeze on nuclear weapons development. Few countries would rely on nuclear weapons that they had never been able to test. This treaty is now in legal limbo and cannot come into force without American ratification. The Bush administration should reconsider its ill-advised opposition and press for early Senate approval. 
These treaties are not foolproof. They must be backed by stringent verification and a unified international response any time a country is caught circumventing the rules. As different as the administration's responses have been to Iraq and North Korea, one unifying thread has been the effort to mobilize international pressure for both countries' nuclear disarmament. Mr. Bush could make a far more powerful case in this and future crises if he made America once again a strong and consistent supporter of international arms control treaties.

HEADLINE: Oceans in Trouble 

 BODY:
Last week, a commission of scientists, economists, fishermen and other experts assembled by the Pew Oceans Commission published the last of seven studies based on an exhaustive two-year inquiry into the state of America's ocean waters -- its fisheries, estuaries, wetlands and beaches. It is the first top-to-bottom study of its kind since the Stratton Commission reported to Congress in 1969. While the Pew commission's final recommendations are not due for several months, it has already confirmed what most of us thought: America's coastal waters and fishing grounds are in trouble, and they are greatly in need of far more attention at the federal level than they are getting. 
 The crisis has many dimensions. Runaway residential development destroys coastal wetlands and estuaries. Increased runoff from farms and cities pollutes streams, rivers and eventually the sea. Commercially valuable fish species -- cod, haddock, flounder and salmon off the Atlantic coast, salmon in the Pacific -- continue to decline. Invasive species pose a growing threat. 
 That it took a private foundation to organize such a study says much about the government's inattentiveness to marine issues over the past 30 years. But the Pew group argues convincingly that if government helped create the problem, government can also turn things around. Most of the problems can be solved, given enough political will and sufficient resources.
Indeed, a vehicle for addressing at least one big problem, overfishing, is close at hand. It is the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, the basic law governing federal fisheries policy, which is up for reauthorization in the new Congress. The act's basic purpose is to regulate fish catches so depleted fish populations can recover and healthy fish populations can continue to grow.
Unfortunately, the law divides responsibility between the Commerce Department, which is supposed to take the long view, and eight regional councils, which tend to be dominated by fishermen who are more interested in catching fish now, not later. The result has been paralysis.
In fairness to the fishermen, however, Congress has done virtually nothing to ensure them a "soft landing" -- to tide them over while fish populations rebuild. Any meaningful strategy aimed at rebuilding fish stocks will inevitably require grounding some boats and retiring others. This is a question Congress must address as it reworks the act. The reauthorization debate could also provide an opportune moment to begin thinking about ways to consolidate the many federal agencies scattered across the bureaucratic landscape that deal with ocean issues.
Updating Magnuson-Stevens is, of course, only a small part of a much larger task. Sooner or later, for example, we are going to have to confront the consequences of coastal sprawl -- ecologically destructive development patterns that seem to have turned huge stretches of our southern coastlines into one long gated community. But getting its legislative house in order is a good place for Congress to start making amends for years of neglect.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
Along With a Super Bowl, the N.F.L. Needs a Farewell Bowl

BYLINE:  By ANDRES MARTINEZ

 BODY:
Absent the Cincinnati Bengals, the National Football League could claim to have built the perfect socialist society. The Bengals, the N.F.L.'s most consistent franchise, have stubbornly resisted embracing the league's much ballyhooed parity. They haven't had a winning season since the last time a president named Bush talked of war with Iraq, in 1990. This is a remarkable non-achievement in a league so devoted to equality.
 Regardless of the size of their home markets, all teams get an equal cut of the N.F.L.'s TV riches. Mixing a free-agency system with a stringent cap on team payrolls is another equalizing force. To each franchise according to its needs, the N.F.L. believes, so it gives weaker teams earlier picks in the college draft and softer schedules. 
 This relentless march to equality has made it impossible for enduring dynasties to rule over the league. In contrast with baseball's pronounced divide between haves and have-nots, football fans everywhere know their team can be a contender in any given season -- everywhere, that is, but Cincinnati. Despite all those top draft picks, their soft schedule and a glistening new $450 million taxpayer-financed stadium, the Bengals finished the season with a 2-14 record. 
Last week the Bengals hired a new head coach, Marvin Lewis, a defensive genius who is a sound choice. Still, there are questions about just how much the coach alone can do to turn around a franchise seemingly committed to not winning. Bengals players have long complained that the team cuts too many corners. The scouting staff is too small, the organization won't hire a top-notch general manager, and while most teams engage in creative accounting to circumvent the salary cap, the Bengals' payroll is comfortably below it. 
One of the problems here, as with all forms of socialism, is one of inadequate incentives for any team that chooses not to be competitive. Regardless of their output, the Bengals receive their same cut of the TV money. Then they are rewarded for their losing ways in the college draft. Bengals fans, besides wanting their money back on the stadium, have asked the N.F.L. to intervene somehow, maybe going so far as to place the Bengals under U.N. receivership. 
What the league must do is infuse the Bengals with competitive fire. And one way to do that, while making the season a lot more exciting in the process, is to import the system of relegation used by most soccer leagues around the world. That entails demoting the worst team (in some leagues, it's more than one) to a lesser league, while promoting the lesser league's champion. Fiorentina, one of Italy's most storied soccer clubs, suffered such a demotion last season. In Spain this year, F.C. Barcelona's mediocre season has nervous fans wondering whether relegation could be in store for that team, one of the world's wealthiest sports franchises.
Such movement of teams between leagues strikes me as an all-American form of social mobility. The only problem, of course, is that unlike baseball, the N.F.L. lacks a ready-made minor league to absorb the losers. The Arena Football League plays its games indoors on a shorter field. The Canadian Football League plays on a longer field, and in a country where sensitivities about playing second fiddle run high. 
Still, the N.F.L. ought to find a way, even if it means taking over and upgrading one of these leagues or creating a new one. Another remedy, though less attractive, would be to force the sale of the worst team each year to new owners in a new city. That could inject much-needed economic Darwinism into the sport. Failing enterprises must be allowed to die. 
For their part, aspiring farm teams should be allowed to rise. Fans have appreciated the Horatio Alger-like careers of players like Kurt Warner and Tommy Maddox, quarterbacks who triumphed in lesser leagues before becoming N.F.L. stars. Affording the same upward mobility to, say, the Arena League's Grand Rapids Rampage, the C.F.L.'s Winnipeg Blue Bombers or a whole new team would bring a new level of dynamism to the league. 
Meanwhile, on this weekend when the N.F.L.'s top teams square off in the conference championships, fans would be treated to a third compelling game. The Bengals and the Detroit Lions, the season's second-worst team, would be facing off in the annual Farewell Bowl.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
Misery Finds Company, Even Among The Rich

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
On Feb. 14, if all goes as planned, Bob Guccione's 17,000-square-foot town house on East 67th Street will be auctioned off downtown in the gilt rotunda of the New York Supreme Court, under the watchful, albeit painted, gazes of Hammurabi and Moses. 
 Mr. Guccione, head of the ailing Penthouse magazine empire, is in deep financial trouble, and his town house is in foreclosure because he owes two lenders $16 million. He is in good if worried company. 
Foreclosures on residential property in some affluent Manhattan neighborhoods are on the rise. From 2000 to 2002, foreclosure actions against condominiums on the Upper East Side, between 61st and 86th Streets, from Fifth Avenue to the East River, rose to 45 from 32. On the Upper West Side, between 60th and 91st Streets, from Central Park to the Hudson River, they rose to 32 from 13, according to the Public Data Corporation of Manhattan, which has a database of real estate and lien records. 
 "We used to see a lot in Harlem and Washington Heights," said Jessica Davis, president of Profiles Publications, a foreclosure listing service in Jackson Heights, Queens. "Now we're starting to see foreclosures on the Upper East Side. We're starting to see a lot of co-ops going into foreclosure, which we hadn't seen in quite some time." 
 According to foreclosure auction listings from Profiles Publications, 10 properties (which include condominiums and town houses) and 15 co-ops in Manhattan below 100th Street, excluding the Lower East Side, have gone up for auction in the last four weeks, contrasted with seven properties and six co-ops in the same period two years ago. 
 "I think you have people in very high income brackets who overextend themselves," Ms. Davis said. "They think the good times are never going to end."
 Michael Schill, director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University, added that in the last 10 to 15 years, affluent homeowners have used tax breaks on home equity loans and easy money from banks to take out second and third mortgages. That is risky. 
 "If you borrow 80 or 90 percent of the value and then take out a 10 percent home equity loan," he said, "then you're 100 percent mortgaged. If property values go down a little bit, you may as well let the bank take it."
 The Corcoran Group, a New York real estate company, says sale prices for residential property in Manhattan climbed last year in all segments except at the high end. There, prices for co-ops fell 7 percent and condominiums 5 percent. 
 Job losses are also a factor. "There is less of a cushion," Mr. Schill said. "'I bought too high, and I lost my job.' I bet that is the story for a lot of people."
 Matt Bordwin, a vice president at Keen Consultants, which helps companies in financial trouble dispose of real estate assets, said: "In the last 12 months, it has become more difficult to sell very high end properties. There are less buyers out there."
 Still, things aren't as bad as they were in the late 80's and early 90's, when property values plummeted. Robert Manzari, a senior vice president at the Corcoran Group, who ran the foreclosure department from 1987 until 1995, said the bottom fell out of his foreclosure business in 1994, and it hasn't come back. "We used to get them in the old days if they didn't sell at auction," he said. "They don't get that far anymore." ERIKA KINETZ

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON WHEELS; 
One-Vehicle Gridlock: Hummer Arrives In the City

BYLINE:  By TOM VANDERBILT 

 BODY:
There are certain disadvantages to being an urban Hummer dealer.
 Take "Hummer Happenings." These, as Hummer of Manhattan's sales manager, John Bruno Jr., explains, are off-road rallies organized by dealers for customers. He hopes to play host to his first event this spring. 
 Off road in New York? Yes, there are times when driving on road here summons those favorite stretches of rutted desert ravine outside of Moab, Utah. But, Central Park aside, where could a group of vehicles accustomed to duty on the Afghan steppes find free-range r.p.m.'s in one of the densest metropolises on Earth? "It's a bit more difficult for us because we're so urban," Mr. Bruno conceded. "We're thinking South Jersey or maybe the Poconos."
 Yet Manhattan does have its own comparative advantages for the fledgling Hummer dealership, now in its fifth month of operation at 55th Street and 11th Avenue: an abundance of disposable income and a concentration of business leaders and celebrities. "As fast as I can get them, I sell them," Mr. Bruno said. "Everyone does business in New York." 
 He added that while most customers who have bought his available supply -- nearly 100 vehicles in just over four months -- are from New York, there is otherwise no typical buyer. "Everybody from movie stars to athletes to a dentist from Queens," said Mr. Bruno, who says the actors Russell Crowe and Harrison Ford are among his customers. "I just this morning delivered an H2 to a woman in her 60's in the Bronx."
 Most of Mr. Bruno's customers have bought the 2003 H2, Hummer's more civilian-oriented brand extension of the iconic H1, a vehicle originally commissioned as a replacement for the United States military Jeep. While the $100,000 H1 has a diesel engine and tires that self-inflate and deflate, the H2, half the cost of the H1, has plastic bumpers and heated seats. 
 The look of the H2 -- a high and aggressive chrome grill, flat paneling and squat, muscular silhouette -- is deceptive, Mr. Bruno said. "When you put it next to the other cars, you see it's actually smaller." The H2 is shorter than the Lexus 470, and less wide than the Lincoln Navigator. Unloaded, it weighs 6,400 pounds, but at more than 8,000 pounds fully loaded, it tops them all. The Navigator weighs just under 6,000 unloaded. 
 With its limited fuel economy, an estimated 13 miles per gallon, city, presumed off-road emphasis and sheer size, one would hardly think the H2 the ideal urban vehicle. Mr. Bruno disagrees. "It's easier to park than most vehicles, because there's not a lot of overhang over the wheels," he said. "You can pull right in without hitting other cars' bumpers."
 A brochure notes that at the Hummer Driving Academy, one can learn to overcome "obstacles both physical and psychological," including the "basics of ditch crossings, water crossings, boulder navigation, recovery techniques and other advanced maneuvers." But what about such urban obstacles as jaywalkers, bike messengers, gridlock and double-parked trucks? "You sit up high, you can see everything," Mr. Bruno said. 
 On a rainy Saturday afternoon earlier this month, there were few customers in the G.M. (parent of Hummer) showroom. One man studying the H1 was Percival Greenridge, the chief operating officer of a podiatry practice. He was drawn to the H1, not for Manhattan but for the Virgin Islands, where he spends half his time.
 While all of Mr. Bruno's customers for the H1 have been men, the H2 casts a wider net. "I've definitely sold this vehicle to more women than anything like it," he said. "They have a saying: 'It's not for the soccer mom, it's for the rugby mom." Hummer, in at least one of its ads, seeks out women: The spot shows a woman driving an H2 through an unidentified urban environment. The tagline reads: "Threaten Men in a Whole New Way."
 It's not just men who ought to feel threatened by the Hummer, says John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives, an advocacy group for pedestrians and cyclists. "Driving a Hummer on city streets is like flying a giant flag that says, 'I hate New York,"' he said.
 Suitability aside, Mr. Kaehny was given a possible omen of the Hummer's future in New York several months ago when he previewed the Taxi and Limousine Commission's new back-seat flat-panel television sets being tested for in-cab use. "The first commercial they had placed in their experimental models was for the Hummer," he said, "which was kind of amazing." 
 TOM VANDERBILT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; 
Montessori School With a Deficit May Be a Victim of a Y 's Deficit

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
Last month, just before winter break, parents and teachers at the Montessori Day School learned that starting this summer, the school would be dropped as a program of the Y.W.C.A. of Brooklyn, which has housed and supported it for 17 years. The news, they said, came out of nowhere.
 "We had no advance warning," said Joyce Evans, co-president of the school's P.T.A., adding that the Dec. 12 announcement came after the deadlines allowing parents to apply to other private schools had passed and too late to allow Montessori to apply for grants that would ensure its continuation. 
Ms. Evans and her co-president, Hayley Gorenberg, both of whom have children at the school, said they knew that the Y had had financial problems in recent years. But they had no idea until December that the school, which is on Third Avenue near Flatbush Avenue and which has a $1.1 million budget, was running a $200,000 deficit. Sara Smith, the education director, said she knew that school had a deficit, but didn't know the extent of it until the Y's announcement. 
 Barbara Turk, executive director of the Y.W.C.A. of Brooklyn, said the decision to drop the program had been made quickly, after auditors found the Y had been running deficits for years and owed nearly $450,000. "We're in a very serious financial crisis," Ms. Turk said, "so we were forced to make some very painful decisions." 
 The school is the only program currently losing money, Ms. Turk said, adding that renting out the 15,000 square feet the school occupies would produce needed revenue and even give the Y a modest surplus. "Certainly we told the parents and the teachers as soon as a decision was made," she said.
 But the P.T.A. presidents said they wished they had known of the discussions before the decision was made. 
 "We feel like if someone had sat down with us and gone over the numbers," Ms. Evans said, "we could have come up with a plan for a smooth transition that would maintain the integrity of the program."
 At the very least, they said, a warning would have given them time to apply for outside financing for the school, which offers day care and classes to about 100 infants, preschoolers and kindergartners, and charges up to $12,000 annual tuition. Instead, Ms. Gorenberg said, parents and teachers are in turmoil.
 Ms. Turk promised last week that the Y would give the school the right of first refusal as renters and asked the P.T.A. presidents to come up with a business plan for such a transition. Ms. Gorenberg said the school could probably pay rent on the space eventually, but not right away.
 Her aim, she said, is a plan under which the school would defer paying rent until it gets outside financing. "That way," she added, "the Y can hold on to the goodwill in the community, as opposed to having an explosion of bad will and anger in the community." TARA BAHRAMPOUR

GRAPHIC: Photo: School may be out for good at this Montessori in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. (Marshall Mantel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Markets Slide on Flat Economic Prospects

BYLINE:  By JEFF SOMMER 

 BODY:
It was the first losing week of the year for the three major stock indexes, as indifferent prospects for technology bellwethers and worries about the economy rattled the markets.
 Microsoft, I.B.M. and Intel reported stronger earnings than expected for the last quarter, but indicated that this year would be uneven at best. 
Microsoft's announcement that it would start to pay dividends had little effect on its stock price, which fell 8 percent for the week. A host of other computer, chip, and software stocks also dropped, pushing the tech-heavy Nasdaq market down by 71.53 points, or 4.9 percent, to close at 1,376.19 for the week. 
 Several economic reports were downbeat. Consumer sentiment declined in January, industrial production fell unexpectedly in December, and the trade deficit swelled to a record $40.1 billion in November.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 25.79 points, or 2.8 percent, closing at 901.78 for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 198.15 points, or 2.3 percent, to 8,586.74.
 Bond prices rose as yields fell. The 10-year Treasury note yield declined to 4.02 percent from 4.14 percent the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Only 26 Days to Valentine's Day. Log On.

BYLINE:  By JULIA MEURLING 

 BODY:
Too busy with work or family obligations, an increasing number of men and women are turning to the Internet to find romance. Nearly 25 million people visited dating Web sites last November alone, according to a recent study by comScore Media Metrix, which measures Internet traffic. 
 Unlike traditional matchmaking services, which can cost thousands of dollars and require a lengthy screening process, most online dating sites offer instant contact with singles for around $25 a month. 
 The surge in online dating has spurred some innovative options. Last year, a site called Match began organizing meet-and-greet events for singles in cities like New York and San Francisco. And just last week, Yahoo Personals began allowing members to post videos with their profiles. JULIA MEURLING

HEADLINE: The World: Korean Word Games; 
Carefully Chosen Invective

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
IN one string of purple invective last week, North Korea's state media threatened to turn Seoul into a "sea of fire," called Americans "infinitely greedy and beastly to the bone" and said the country's "unshakable revolutionary stand" called for answering "a hard line with the toughest line and a bullet with a shell."
 There is usually strong temptation, both in Seoul and in Washington, to tune out such overheated words. "It is very difficult to get through all the adjectives sometimes," said one Western diplomat. South Koreans, meanwhile, are so used to the language that they often seem blase about the threat, even though their capital lies just 40 miles from the world's most heavily armed frontier. 
 When people do focus, it tends to be on the weirdness of the vitriol, and important nuances are often lost. As a window on the country, North Korea's official propaganda may be tiny and fogged, but experts on the country's propaganda say it has always been used with great rigor to send messages to the outside world.
"We once had the same trouble with China, and until Nixon went there China was considered almost another planet, and when you think that way it tends to magnify and distort things," said one former American analyst. "That's where we are with North Korea. It isn't always that they are so opaque. It is that we can't stop convincing ourselves that they are aliens."
Many of North Korea's statements in recent weeks have been genuinely alarming, though. Some American analysts and close followers of North Korean statements say subtle details in the language hint strongly at a shift toward a much more hard-line stance.
For example, the experts say they detect signs that the decision has already been made to produce nuclear weapons using plutonium from the reactor at Yongbyon -- rather than, as some have suggested, to bluff in that direction as a blackmail tactic. Other statements, like talk about "saving the Korean nation," suggest North Korea is preparing to wrap its nuclear weapons in the colors of pan-Korean nationalism, in an appeal to sympathetic opinion and resentment of the United States in the South.
Particularly worrisome, these analysts say, is the resumption of mass rallies -- like the gathering of perhaps two million slogan-chanting people in Pyongyang on Jan. 11 -- outside of traditional calendar events. Such huge rallies are costly; taken together with the themes of the speeches and slogans, they suggest a switch of priorities from economic resuscitation and reform to confrontation.
"Kim Jong Il has not relied on rallies so much because of the dwindling economy," said Kongdan Oh of the Institute for Defense Analyses, an American organization. "This is not showmanship for foreigners, but a sign of real mobilization driven by the level of fear and uncertainty that they are facing since the Bush administration came to power."
Another analyst said he was reminded of the time, around 1966, when North Korea entered another era of confrontation with America, after the leadership transferred huge amounts of resources to the military from the civilian sector.
"If there really has been a shift, either in the physical makeup of the leadership or a mind shift, maybe this can't be turned around," said one longtime former American analyst of North Korea who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "They may have concluded that 'We've been through this before with the Americans already, we got security assurances before, and a new administration came in and they were worthless.' "
Analysts say some of the latest North Korean statements, though buried in sarcasm about a new Bush administration offer for dialogue, give reason to qualify such predictions. After weeks of unrelenting negativity, they speak of a solution to the crisis that would "clear both sides of their concerns."
For all of the difficulty in parsing North Korean language, the task for North Korea in understanding the United States may scarcely be easier, given how little understanding the North Koreans have of how an American government forms policy while navigating between conflicting points of view. In recent months, American media accounts and statements by senior officials have spoken of everything from putting a humanitarian squeeze on the country to, most recently, offering it a "bold initiative," meaning security guarantees and economic ties in exchange for much more stringent disarmament.
The labels have sometimes been confusing even to Americans, ranging from "hawk engagement" to "tailored containment," a name for Washington's policy that Western diplomats say Mr. Bush dismissed as wacky sounding.
In a society as closed and authoritarian as North Korea's, the leaders may be incapable of grasping why an American president cannot simply make up his mind on foreign policy and carry it out at will. "Americans have a hard enough time knowing who's on top, Rumsfeld or Powell," said a former Asia analyst for the American government. "Most of us don't understand our huge, complicated, modern society either, but we operate in a level of comfort. We assume that the cars will stay on the right side of the street. But the North Koreans worry that it might veer into the oncoming lane."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mass rallies, like this one in Pyongyang on Jan. 11, sent a signal about North Korea's shift of priorities. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NEW YORK STATE MISSES 2 DEADLINES ON SECURITY PLANS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
When the Federal Emergency Management Agency pledged $8.8 billion to help New York City rebuild after Sept. 11, 2001, it set aside a minimum of $418 million for the state to finance projects to bolster the metropolitan area's preparedness for any future terrorist attack.
 But in the 16 months since the attack that destroyed the World Trade Center, the state has not submitted a single project for FEMA to review, even though it has received scores of proposals from state, city and private agencies desperate to do everything from reinforcing bridges to shoring up bioterrorism efforts at local hospitals. 
 In fact, the state has missed two deadlines for submitting the proposals, and has been forced to ask for two extensions totaling six months -- requests that emergency management officials say have been rare in other disasters.
The failure so far to take advantage of hundreds of millions of available dollars when both the state and city are in fiscal crises has troubled many local elected officials, Democrats and Republicans alike, who worry that the delays and indecision will hurt the state's ability to make a case for any money in the future.
"The state needs to move on this so that people are assured that work is being done to remedy our vulnerabilities," an aide to a New York Republican lawmaker said. "People are frustrated that the state seems to be sitting on its hands." 
Some lawmakers are also angered by what they regard as the Pataki administration's unwillingness to even signal which projects it might ultimately submit.
"The state is like a sphinx," Senator Charles E. Schumer said. "No one knows why they are not spending the money yet."
State officials attributed the delays in part to the complexity of deciding how best to protect against terrorists capable of sophisticated and varied assaults. They also said that simply sifting through all the proposals, with costs totaling an estimated $6 billion, has taken an enormously long time.
"A project of this magnitude is far too important to rush," said Mollie Fullington, a spokeswoman for Gov. George E. Pataki. "The terrorist attacks on America were an unprecedented disaster, and this application clearly does not fit within the confines of a typical time period to prioritize projects for these funds."
As for the appearance of secrecy surrounding the projects, Ms. Fullington said many applicants did not want their requests to be disclosed publicly "because of the sensitive nature of the projects."
And Edward F. Jacoby Jr., director of the New York State Emergency Management Office, summarized the enormousness of the task in another way. "I've had to rethink my whole way of thinking about math in terms of billions, not millions."
Of the $21.4 billion that the federal government pledged in the months after the attack to help rebuild the city, $8.8 billion was to come from FEMA. As of last month, all but $366 million had either been spent or more or less formally allocated.
One of those allocations was the $418 million available under what is known as FEMA's Hazard Mitigation Grant Program.
In previous disasters, mitigation money has typically been used to retrofit buildings in earthquake zones or relocate houses in flood-prone areas. The amount of financing is determined by calculating the total cost of the disaster, then asking FEMA to authorize and supply an extra 15 percent of that total. FEMA pays 75 percent of the mitigation money, and local authorities 25 percent.
But Sept. 11, of course, was no normal disaster. And mitigation was likely to include things like installing blast-resistant windows and doors in skyscrapers and protecting emergency fuel supplies.
In the months after the attacks, Mr. Pataki pledged to push FEMA and the Bush administration to add more mitigation money -- allocations that could simply be added to the $8.8 billion package. State officials say they have received little feedback to date.
Within the last two weeks, however, city and federal officials have intensified their criticism, saying that the state has been too tentative and passive. They say that the delays not only leave the city vulnerable, but also jeopardize its chances of lobbying effectively for additional 9/11-related funds for police officers, firefighters and emergency workers on the front line of domestic security.
"Clearly we are living in the No. 1 target of the terrorists," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat. "We need more help than what the administration is giving us."
As it is, many agencies are already desperately counting on mitigation financing to help with their bottom lines at this moment of dwindling resources.
For instance, the Bloomberg administration is banking on $200 million from the hazard mitigation program and other federal sources to help close the budget gap. The city has also asked that the eligibility criteria -- now restricted, for the most part, to infrastructural work and disaster planning -- be broadened to include enhanced security measures like added police and emergency response units.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has proposed an estimated $1 billion worth of projects. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has submitted numerous proposals, too, but declined to make the details public.
There seems to be confusion within the Pataki administration as to whether state officials are looking seriously at projects outside the city.
The state's own mitigation handbook for the World Trade Center disaster notes that the money is supposed to be earmarked for projects in New York City or sites outside the city considered critical to its stability, like the city's reservoirs in the Catskill Mountains. Some state officials, however, have told Congressional aides that projects around the entire state are indeed being considered.
But Ms. Fullington, the spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said that "the governor has said that all the projects designated will be in New York City."
Assurances aside, few people outside Albany seem to know what projects are on the list. FEMA does not know. Elected officials do not know. City Hall does not know. Even state officials in Washington do not know.
Pataki officials also refused to release any specifics to two reporters, citing security concerns. Some clues, though, can be gleaned from a draft document prepared by the state on "Possible Terrorism Mitigation Measures," dated Dec. 12, 2001, and handed out to potential applicants. It identifies six priorities: 1) Protect Public Infrastructure and Utilities; 2) Protect Key Government and Health Care Facilities; 3) Continuity of Government and Business Operations; 4) Awareness Initiatives; 5) High-Rise Building Safety; 6) Protect Landmarks.
And as far back as November 2001, potential applicants received a letter from the State Emergency Management Office inviting them to apply.
But the state wound up missing its first deadline for submitting proposals: Sept. 11, 2002. It then missed a second deadline on Dec. 11, and now has been given until March 11 to submit its choices to FEMA.
If the state misses that deadline, a third extension will be more difficult to get, said Brad Gair, FEMA's federal recovery officer in New York. But Mr. Gair said he thought the state would meet the deadline.
"We're confident that there's no one more concerned about hazard mitigation than New York State," Mr. Gair said.
State officials say they are doing their best to wade through the applications -- a task complicated, they say, by an abundance of ideas that seem like good ones. But friction has arisen between the city and state as they negotiate which projects to finance, according to people knowledgeable about the discussions. One official described both Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Mr. Pataki as indecisive.
Once the projects are in, Mr. Gair said, FEMA is prepared and eager to process the applications as quickly as possible.
One thing that both Mr. Gair and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton suggested -- and indeed has been done in previous disasters -- is for the state to submit a few proposals at a time. That way, FEMA could begin processing the most vital projects.
"There is no reason why we should not be proceeding to collect those monies and put them to work right now," Mrs. Clinton said. "I'm somewhat bewildered as to why we're not moving forward on this, because failing to submit the applications that have come in might suggest to FEMA that we don't need the money."

PERSON: John M. Fox 

HEADLINE: John M. Fox, 90, Innovator In Developing Frozen Juice 

BYLINE:  By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
John M. Fox, a founder and president of the Minute Maid Corporation, which developed frozen orange juice concentrate in the late 1940's and made it popular within a decade, died on Jan. 9 in Winter Park, Fla. He was 90 and lived in Winter Park.
 At the end of World War II, Mr. Fox and four other businessmen set up a small company called Florida Foods Inc., which made the first commercial batch of frozen orange concentrate using a vacuum technique he had seen employed in Boston during the war to dehydrate penicillin and food for the military. 
 The original plan was to turn orange juice into a soluble powder, but this turned out to have an unpleasant taste. So instead, they reduced fresh juice to a thick concentrate, which proved far more drinkable when water was added. In 1947, the company changed its name to the Minute Maid Corporation.
Mr. Fox hired the singer Bing Crosby as the company's first spokesman and went door to door in his neighborhood in Hingham, Mass., giving out samples. First-year sales totaled $374,501, but by 1955 sales reached $106.5 million.
The company went public the next year, and built a headquarters in Orlando, Fla. After the company was sold to Coca-Cola in 1960, the headquarters were moved to Houston.
An immigrant from Britain, Mr. Fox had a second career in the food business after the sale of Minute Maid, becoming president and chairman of the United Fruit Company from 1960 to 1970.
At United Fruit, he discontinued the practice of shipping bananas on the stem, which resulted in heavy losses from bruising. Instead he had the fruit packed in specially designed cardboard boxes on the plantations and shipped directly to the distributors.
He also expanded the idea of branding the company's bananas, already famous under the Chiquita Banana name, by putting a blue company sticker directly on the bananas and other fruit. Today the company is called Chiquita Brands International.
Mr. Fox was president and chairman of H. P. Hood, a dairy products company in the Boston area, from 1970 until his retirement in 1978.
John Michael Fox was born in Esher, England, on Dec. 26, 1912, and came to the United States in 1914, settling with his parents in Atlantic City. After graduating from Colgate University in 1934, he worked for I.B.M. and then with the National Research Corporation, a product research company in Boston that developed a vacuum technique for dehydrating substances, among many other inventions. The vacuum method became the basis of the technique Minute Maid used for turning orange juice into concentrate.
Mr. Fox is survived by his wife, Floy; a daughter, Susan Castellini of Cincinnati; two sons, Stephen, of Peterborough, N.H., and Byron, of Mill Valley, Calif.; a sister, Nancy Burgess of Madison, Conn.; and 20 grandchildren, great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Rio Grande Choice: Take City's Water Or Let Minnow Die 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
A three-inch-long endangered fish is standing between this city and its plans for a well-watered future.
 The fish, the silvery minnow, native to the Rio Grande, has been the subject of years of court battles. But now a federal appeals court is about to decide whether, to save the fish, Albuquerque must give up drinking water it has set aside behind a federal dam for the years ahead. 
 The case poses the most direct confrontation yet between the Endangered Species Act, which ranks the protection of threatened animals and plants above human needs, and the water rights held by cities like Albuquerque in Western states where water is becoming increasingly scarce.
Among the states that have joined with the city of Albuquerque and the State of New Mexico in asking the court to reserve the water for people are Colorado, Idaho, South Dakota, Oklahoma, Nebraska and Wyoming. Their actions reflect wide expectation that the ruling could have broad implications, with a potential impact on scores of federal water projects and endangered species in 17 Western states. 
The mayor of Albuquerque, Martin Chavez, says the case involves "the highest stakes imaginable" for his city, whose rights to the water stored behind the dam date back to a 1962 contract with the federal government. The city now relies wholly on water pumped from the ground at rates that cannot be sustained. But under a $200 million transition plan that would leave the city using ground water as a small part of its supply, the water behind the dam would become essential.
Environmentalists who are challenging the city, however, say the water right is not absolute and can be superseded by the need to address the threat to the fish, once the most plentiful in the river. Like the flow of the Rio Grande itself, the minnow's numbers have dwindled, to the point where experts say the fish will not survive in the wild if the river, heavily tapped by farmers and others and now stricken by drought, is allowed to go dry. The river nearly did go dry this fall along a 60-mile stretch south of Albuquerque, which is the most critical habitat for survival of the minnow.
If the drought continues, only the release of water that Albuquerque and other users have stored behind the federal dam could keep enough water in that section of the river to sustain the minnow. While agreeing that an order forcing the release would be a radical step, the environmentalists say it would bring about a reckoning that is both necessary and long overdue.
"In my view, we can either come to terms with our problems while we still have a river, or we can wait until we no longer have a river," said Aletta Belin, a Santa Fe lawyer who represents a coalition of environmental groups that are suing the city, the state and the federal government to force the water release.
The intensity of feeling on both sides of the issue recalls other bitter fights over endangered species like the snail darter and the spotted owl, as well as the current battle involving the Klamath River in Oregon and California, where a threat to the sucker fish in 2001 prompted the federal government to withhold irrigation water from hundreds of angry farmers.
But never before has the plight of an endangered species threatened to cut into a large city's supply of drinking water. In New Mexico, that specter is seen as so alarming that several of the state's political leaders, including both its Republican and its Democratic senators, have warned that they may seek to override any adverse court decision through a convening of the so-called god squad, a rarely used federal panel with the power to override the Endangered Species Act when saving a species would cause intolerable economic harm.
The Bush administration, in its court arguments, has sided firmly with Albuquerque in arguing that the plight of the fish does not give the federal government the power to abrogate the city's right. But Gale A. Norton, the interior secretary, has also made clear that she expects the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit to set a clearer line in such water disputes.
"This case will help us understand what the rules are" when it comes to accommodating human needs and protecting endangered species, Ms. Norton said in New Mexico last month.
The appeals court is reviewing a ruling by a judge in New Mexico, James Parker of Federal District Court, who sided with the environmentalists in September by ordering the release of about 10,000 acre-feet of the water, about one-fifth of Albuquerque's annual allotment.
The water, stored by the federal Bureau of Reclamation behind Heron Dam in northern New Mexico, was to have flowed down the Rio Grande past Albuquerque to guarantee a minimum flow in the stretch deemed a critical habitat for the minnow. But before it was released, the appellate court stayed the ruling, in response to protests by Albuquerque and other litigants, including an irrigation district in central New Mexico, who argued that Judge Parker had exceeded his authority.
In a stroke of good fortune for the fish, and contrary to most predictions, rainfall this autumn and winter has kept enough water in the Rio Grande for the minnow to survive, the objective that Judge Parker intended to secure through the water's release.
But snowfall in the mountains this winter has been far below normal, meaning that by early summer, the Rio Grande's flow is likely to drop again toward a critical point. 
The September ruling would have required the release of only about one-fifteenth of the water now stored in the dam, and only about half of that water is claimed by Albuquerque. In the most immediate sense, such a release would not have a direct effect on Albuquerque, because it has not yet begun to use any of the water in the reservoir. 
But city officials argue that the release will take away water that Albuquerque will need beginning in 2006. That is when the city is to reduce the water pumped from the aquifer on which it is now wholly dependent to about 20 percent of its supply and begin to rely on the water behind the dam.
And in the future, the Albuquerque officials warn, an established federal right to deliver less than the contracted amount of 48,300 acre-feet per year would leave the city no option but to turn back to the aquifer, which is already so depleted that at current rates of pumping, it is not expected to last more than another 25 years.
"The federal government would be sitting in the position of deciding whose water and how much of whose water can be used by the fish every year, and how much is left for everyone else," said John Stomp, Albuquerque's director of water resources.
"And in the long term, by its enforcement of the Endangered Species Act," Mr. Stomp said, "the federal government would be creating an environmental catastrophe, through depletion of the aquifer and land-surface subsidence."
By contrast, Mr. Chavez, the mayor, has said a favorable ruling would leave Albuquerque with enough water to sustain its population "for generations and generations and generations to come."
Albuquerque, with a population of about 450,000, lies on the Rio Grande, but the water at stake in this case originally comes from another river, the San Juan in Colorado, on the western side of the Continental Divide. Water rights from the Rio Grande, which were divided in the 1930's among Colorado, New Mexico and Texas, along with Mexico, are so oversubscribed that the city of Albuquerque has never held any. The contract for the San Juan River water was Albuquerque's effort to line up an alternative source of surface water as insurance against the time the aquifer runs out.
Through a federal diversion project whose costs are being reimbursed by Albuquerque and other users, an annual allotment of water from the San Juan River is now rechanneled across to the eastern side of the Continental Divide and into New Mexico's Chama River, where most of it is stored behind the Heron Dam. From there, Albuquerque and the minnow's critical habitat lie downriver, along the Rio Grande.
Over the years, with the aquifer supplying its municipal needs, Albuquerque has generally leased its rights to the San Juan water to others, most often farmers. But with its transition to reliance on surface water looming, the city says it no longer has any excess, either for crops or for the fish.
The Fish and Wildlife Service first listed the silvery minnow as an endangered species in 1994, and efforts to save the species in recent years have indirectly involved the use of Albuquerque's water, through an arrangement in which farmers who have had to give up Rio Grande water for the fish have made up the difference by leasing water that the city has not used.
But while Albuquerque has also joined in efforts to save the fish in special fisheries, it has not done much to rein in its own heavy water use, with rates that are among the highest in the region. The same is true of New Mexico as a whole, a state whose water resources are severely limited, but that is only now beginning to try to assess the amount of water it uses and the amount that might be available in the future.
For those reasons, some experts who are sitting out the fight over the silvery minnow are trying to turn attention to the need for more realistic long-term planning that they say the case has helped to expose.
"One of the reasons we got into this mess is that we haven't been very good about managing our water," said Consuelo Bokum of 1,000 Friends of New Mexico, an advocacy group that focuses on land use, growth and water issues but has not taken a position on the endangered species case. "I'm convinced that we've let things go too long without being very strict."

HEADLINE: Commission to Urge Freezing Some Medicare Payments 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
To slow the growth of Medicare, an influential federal advisory panel will soon recommend that Congress freeze payments to nursing homes and home care agencies and reduce the cost-of-living allowance that hospitals are scheduled to receive next year.
 Republicans in Congress and Bush administration officials welcomed the proposals, saying they would save money for taxpayers and the Medicare trust fund. But health care providers expressed alarm, saying the proposals could reduce access to care for millions of the elderly and disabled. 
 The panel, the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, recommended a 2.5 percent increase in Medicare payments to doctors next year. Payments to doctors were cut 5.4 percent last year, and a further cut of 4.4 percent is scheduled to take effect on March 1. 
Doctors are lobbying Congress to block that reduction. The Senate is poised to approve a proposal by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, to keep doctor payments at 2002 levels for the rest of this year. It is unclear whether the proposal, part of an omnibus spending bill, will ultimately become law.
In a draft of its annual report, to be sent to Congress in March, the commission said that "Medicare payments for hospital services are at least adequate" to cover the costs of efficient providers. Payments to nursing homes and home health agencies appear "more than adequate" to cover the costs of treating Medicare patients, the panel said.
Medicare payments to home health agencies were cut 4.9 percent on Oct. 1, and nursing homes say their payments were reduced an average of 10 percent at that time. Experts on the staff of the commission said that home care agencies and nursing homes had been able to control their costs without reducing the quality of care.
At a meeting this week, many of the 17 commissioners said Medicare had no obligation to make up for underpayments by other insurers, like Medicaid, the federal-state program for low-income people.
"We should not use Medicare dollars to offset Medicaid losses," said the commission chairman, Glenn M. Hackbarth. He added, "I don't see evidence to support the claim that our recommendations would impede access to quality care."
With growing federal deficits, Republicans are eager to slow the growth of Medicare, but they face political pressure from two sources: elderly people demanding coverage of prescription drugs and health care providers lobbying for higher Medicare payments.
Congressional aides said the commission's advice would make it easier for some lawmakers to resist the pressure from hospitals, nursing homes and home care agencies.
John C. Rother, policy director of AARP, said: "The commission is a highly respected group whose recommendations usually carry great weight in Congress. Its recommendations will help Congress resist the otherwise overwhelming political pressure to raise provider payment rates."
AARP, the group formerly known as the American Association of Retired Persons, says Congress should not increase payments to providers without ensuring that older Americans get drug coverage.
Richard J. Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association, said his members were "tremendously disappointed" with the commission's proposal to reduce the annual inflation adjustment for hospitals. The commission, he said, underestimated the "enormous cost pressures" on hospitals from technology, pharmaceuticals, malpractice insurance and disaster preparedness.
One commission member, Carol Raphael, president of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, the largest nonprofit home care agency in the nation, expressed grave reservations about the proposed freeze in payment rates for home care.
At a time when chronic illness is more prevalent and the population is aging, Ms. Raphael said, fewer people are using Medicare's home health care provision. The number of Medicare beneficiaries receiving home care declined to 2.2 million in 2001, from 3.5 million in 1997.
"This is very puzzling," Ms. Raphael said. She suggested that some home care agencies may have become more selective, avoiding high-cost patients who have Alzheimer's disease, serious wounds or complicated forms of diabetes.
James C. Pyles, a lawyer for the American Association for Home Care, said: "More than 1.3 million people have been eliminated from the rolls. They include some of the sickest patients, those who really need the benefit."
The staff of the commission and the chairman proposed cuts in Medicare payments to teaching hospitals, but by a vote of 9 to 6, the panel rejected that idea.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents 96 teaching hospitals, said, "The staff recommendation would have been devastating to academic health centers and teaching hospitals."
Medicare pays $5.1 billion a year to teaching hospitals for some of the extra costs they incur. The commission staff said such hospitals were overpaid because the extra costs totaled just $2.5 billion.
The commission expects a 3.5 percent increase in the cost of goods and services used by hospitals of all types next year. But it said hospitals could get by with an inflation update of 3.1 percent for inpatient care and 2.5 percent for outpatient services. Together, it said, those recommendations would save $250 million to $800 million next year and could save $1.2 billion to $6 billion over five years.
Hospitals, like doctors and nursing homes, "should be expected to improve productivity," the panel said.

HEADLINE: Somalia Talks Are Stormy, But They Still Inch Ahead 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: ELDORET, Kenya, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The peace talks unfolding here aimed at ending Somalia's long civil war have turned as chaotic as the country itself. Warlords are trying to oust the mediator. Hotels are threatening to evict delegates over unpaid bills. The police were recently ordered to expel the many Somalis who arrived without invitations.
 The negotiations, now in their fourth month, were troubled from the start. 
 Hundreds of extra delegates showed up in October, prompting a brisk sale in bogus credentials. There have been walkouts, shouting matches and a protest during Ramadan by the management of a hotel holding unpaid bills that left unfed many delegates from the largely Muslim country who had been fasting all day.
"The tragedy of it all is that it's probably better positioned than any conference in the past to accomplish something," said one of the handful of Western diplomats tracking the negotiations. "I wouldn't say it's hopeless, although it certainly looks hopeless when you're there."
The country looks just as troubled. It has no national government to speak of, a form of limbo that has existed for a dozen years. Instead, heavily armed warlords rule by brute force, a throwback to medieval times. Although most Somalis are desperate for an end to more than a decade of anarchy, they still associate more with clan than country.
 On Friday, the United Nations condemned a series of killings of children and kidnappings in Somalia, where gunmen have killed several schoolchildren in attacks on buses in the last month. 
The United States ignored Somalia in the years after 1993, when 18 American soldiers were killed in an aid mission that went awry. But Somalia's importance to the West has grown with the onset of the American-led campaign against terrorism. Somalia's long coastline, porous borders and strategic location just across the Gulf of Aden from Yemen, not to mention its lack of a central government, make it an ideal breeding ground for militants.
The Americans have been monitoring the talks, which have offered some slivers of hope despite the confusion.
These talks have attracted more of the important Somali players than any of the dozen or so past peace conferences convened since 1991, when the dictatorship of Muhammad Siad Barre was overthrown.
The Eldoret talks also have made some tangible progress, like an agreement to cease hostilities, albeit one that has been repeatedly violated. Now, the talks are getting down to the basics of what a united Somalia would look like. Organizers say they expect a final plan to emerge later this year, although the process has been slow. "It's getting frustrating," said Muhammad Sheik Gabiou, a Somali constitutional law expert who has been involved in past efforts to bring order to the country. "Somalis like to talk and talk and talk, even when they don't know what they're talking about."
Kenya, Ethiopia and Djibouti, Somalia's neighbors, are sponsoring the talks through an organization known as the Intergovernmental Authority on Development. The European Union, the Americans and others are providing financing, although they have withheld some funds recently as the talks have spiraled out of control.
Numerous hotels have not been paid for many of their costs. To protest, the management of the main conference site, the Sirikwa Hotel, in late November closed the buffet that Somalis descend on every evening. The Kenyan Foreign Ministry was forced to intervene to get it reopened.
Recently, some warlords tried to replace the Kenyan mediator, Elijah W. Mwangale, accusing him of repeatedly changing the official number of delegates, now set at 396.
The last semisuccessful Somali peace talks were held in 2000 in Djibouti. One result was a transitional government, including a president, Abdikassim Salad Hassan, and a 245-member assembly, although most of the warlords boycotted the talks and worked to undermine the results.
That transitional body, which has controlled pockets of Mogadishu but little else, formally dissolves in August. Two regions in the north, Somaliland and Puntland, have elected their own leaders. In the rest of the country, warlords continue to fight for turf.
Despite the broad representation at the Eldoret conference, officials from the self-proclaimed Republic of Somaliland have boycotted the talks, focusing instead on their own elections. Frustrated warlords also have begun to go back to Mogadishu, leaving no indication of whether they will return.
But the many Somalis who remain in Eldoret are trying to agree on a loose federalist structure that balances the country's many clans.
"We're making progress," said Awad Ahmed Ashara, a minister in the breakaway Puntland government. He and others want the rest of the world, especially the Americans, to join the give-and-take in Eldoret.
"We feel the Americans are reluctant to get involved," Mr. Ashara said. "They are worried about Somalia being a haven for terrorists, but they're not helping the process. We'd like to hear something from the White House."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-19-03: CLOSE READING; 
When Diamonds and Escalades Are O.K.

BYLINE:  By Rob Walker; Rob Walker is a contributing writer for Slate and Money.

 BODY:
By most appearances, the year just ended was a bad one for "bling bling." A slang term that has made its way from hip-hop culture to the mainstream, bling blinging is most easily understood as flaunting that $1 million Piaget diamond-crusted watch. It doesn't tell time any better than a plastic Casio; it does send a clear message that the wearer has money to burn. The phrase was popularized in a song by rappers from the Cash Money Millionaires stable and was in part a catalog of obnoxiously flashy possessions (a private plane, for example).
 Of course, that song dates from 1999 -- the good old days, when rap artists were hardly the only ones bingeing. Twenty-something stock tycoons, Wall Streeters and various staid old white guys in charge of huge corporations bling-blinged all through the 1990's, and nobody complained. That was partly because they seemed to be fueling an economy that was good for everybody and partly because so many people saw skyrocketing individual wealth not so much as a problem but as something to get in on. It is only natural that a couple of years of crashing stocks, rising unemployment and corporate fraud -- and, of course, the wrenching personal reprioritization that Sept. 11, 2001, inspired in many -- might turn us into a nation of Thorstein Veblens, with little tolerance for such conspicuous consumption. 
 Evidence of an anti-bling mentality is all around. The neo-grunge, thrift-store style of Avril Lavigne, for example, is shouldering aside the glittery flash of Britney Spears on the radio and in retail outlets across America. There is the form that the vogue for C.E.O. bashing has taken: Dennis Kozlowski ended up with the words "Oink Oink" over his picture on the front of The New York Post not because people were upset with -- or even understood -- what he is accused of doing wrong as the C.E.O. of Tyco but rather because it came to be known that he owned a $15,000 umbrella stand. And in her latest hit song, even Jennifer Lopez seems a little nervous. In what seems to be a stab at humility, she assures that "I love my life and my public" and encourages us not to be "fooled" by her diamond life because deep down she's "still Jenny from the block."
But wait a minute. In the video for that song, Lopez positively revels in the trappings of extreme wealth -- the diamonds, the limos, the fur coats, the boats, the Champagne. If J. Lo really thinks her public might punish her for losing touch with "the block," then why rub our noses in her flagrantly bejeweled lifestyle on MTV? Her "public" doesn't seem to mind, having pushed the slender tune near the top of the charts. How does she get away with both sickening riches and humility? Dennis Kozlowski, among others, would like to know. 
The answer is that despite appearances to the contrary, deep down Americans don't really have a problem with conspicuous consumption per se. It is all in the packaging: we're O.K. with bling bling so long as we believe it has been earned. Lopez makes for an interesting case study because her public image is simultaneously middle of the road -- as the star of the bland romantic comedy "Maid in Manhattan" -- and streetwise, as a pop singer who collaborates with rap artists and borrows liberally from hip-hop culture. It is the latter point that matters, because even now hip-hop culture remains a safe haven for ridiculous expenditure.
Bling king Sean (P. Diddy) Combs, for instance, has lately been photographed jet-skiing in his bathrobe on the French Riviera, and he has bragged about his extensive list of demands (flowers, mirrors, tequila, multiple copies of "Scarface") for being the host of a music-awards show. Snoop Dogg, styling himself a kind of Hugh Hefner, has taken to drinking from a goblet covered with rhinestones. Then there is Nelly, another rap artist selling millions. If hip-hop was once "the CNN of black America," as Chuck D memorably put it, Nelly's new single is basically an infomercial. Titled "Air Force Ones," it is an ode to shopping for a style of $80-and-up Nike shoe -- buying by the case when possible -- and includes what must be the least impressive boast in the history of rap: "Walk in the mall and they know what I'm 'bout to say." The song is a smash and has sparked such a run on the shoes that The Wall Street Journal says some Foot Locker employees have been accused of "scalping" pairs at $200 a pop. Fatigue among hip-hop fans with endless raps about Courvoisier, diamonds and Cadillac Escalades is said to have played a role in the embrace of Eminem's less-brand-oriented subject matter. But if some hip-hop fans see flashy spending as worthy of condemnation, others clearly see it as worthy of emulation. 
"Using objects to make connections between people and establish one's authority is an ancient and universal form of human behavior," Thomas Hine argues in the recent book "I Want That! How We All Became Shoppers." He notes that those who possess "key objects" -- the crown, the mantle, the Piaget watch -- "have been the rulers and wizards of their peoples." The subtext of the song "Bling Bling" was that the Cash Money Millionaires had clawed their way out of a brutal New Orleans housing project to become multiplatinum stars, and indeed some variation on that is the theme of much hip-hop. Often it is not even articulated; it goes without saying that the squandering protagonist is a rags-to-riches figure who beat overwhelming odds and has every right to the fruits of that success.
But the bad news for Dennis Kozlowski is that our tolerance for $15,000 umbrella-stand owners drops to zero if such "key objects" are not earned. Like many a hip-hop star, Kozlowski rose from humble origins, too, and according to his lawyers, he has done nothing wrong. But the overwhelming consensus is that somehow or other he and his peers cheated their way to wealth. So it is too late for Kozlowski to pose as Denny from the block. Sure, Sean Combs was once accused of hitting a record executive with a chair and a Champagne bottle, but at least he has never smacked your 401(k) around. 
This is why the new and supposedly humble incarnation of J. Lo -- who once included a 45-foot trailer with white sofas, a VCR and green seedless grapes as part of her specific demands for participating in a charity project -- should be taken with a grain of salt. When she sings "I used to have a little, now I have a lot," what she is saying is "and therefore, I deserve it all."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Marriage Penalty, Except When It Isn't

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IF politicians of almost every stripe agree so readily about an issue, it is usually worth a closer look.
 Such is the case with an important but barely debated component of President Bush's $674 billion tax-cut plan: relief from the "marriage penalty." 
 It is hard to find an idea with more mom-and-apple-pie appeal. Who wants to be against marriage? Who wants to be for higher taxes? Who would defend a tax burden that seems both unfair and capricious, a result of anomalies in the law? 
As any two-income married couple knows, the marriage penalty kicks in when the husband and wife combine their incomes on a joint tax return and suddenly find themselves in a much higher bracket. A couple who together earn $80,000 owe hundreds more than two singles who each earn $40,000.
Small wonder that Democrats, who have attacked Mr. Bush's overall plan as reckless and overwhelmingly tilted toward the rich, have said virtually nothing about plans to alleviate this problem.
But for all the complaints about the marriage penalty, the current tax code is in many ways heavily biased in favor of married couples, especially those with children. Tens of millions of families actually receive big marriage bonuses, which would become even bigger under Mr. Bush's plan.
Consider the tax loads of three different households, each with an annual taxable income of $60,000. In an analysis prepared last week by Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, a single person with no children would owe $7,943 under current law and receive a tax cut of $345 under Mr. Bush's plan.
By contrast, a married couple who have two children and file jointly would pay $3,300 under current law and $2,400 under the Bush plan. Did someone say marriage penalty?
Defenders point out that the married couple have more mouths to feed, more clothes to buy and more house to pay for. But consider the third household: a single mother with one child. She would have to shoulder child-care expenses that a married couple with a stay-at-home parent would not. Yet she would owe $1,800 more than the married couple under current law, and her tax cut would be about half that of the married couple.
The big winners under current law and the Bush plan are the Ozzie and Harriets -- married couples with only one breadwinner and two or more children.
Two-income married couples are in some respects the biggest victims of the marriage penalty, and their problems do not disappear under the Bush plan. Single people pay the highest taxes of all, under current law and the Bush plan, though a single person earning $60,000 may still end up paying less than a husband and wife who together earn the same amount.
There are technical reasons behind all this, but they seem to stem from a surprisingly intense political battle waged by influential conservative groups determined to encourage stay-at-home moms.
"The people who are treated the best are families with stay-at-home spouses, who, not surprisingly, are an important constituency for Republicans," said Edward J. McCaffery, a law professor at the University of Southern California and the author of "Taxing Women" (University of Chicago Press).
As far as two-income couples are concerned, "the more equal they are as earners, the higher the penalty will be," Mr. McCaffery added.
ONE big reason for the bigger tax burden may be the role played over the years by Phyllis Schlafly, the indefatigable foe of feminism and of anything in the tax code that encourages women to leave their children for outside work.
Ms. Schlafly has pushed for child tax credits, which are given for each child in the family and would be increased to $1,000 from $600, and opposed tax breaks for the costs of child care, which are not being expanded.
She has fought for years to ensure that marriage-penalty relief flows to families with stay-at-home moms as well as two-income households. Mr. Bush's plan would raise the standard deduction for any married couple. When he proposed a special 10 percent tax break for two-income families in his 2001 tax bill, Ms. Schlafly raised a storm and helped kill the idea.
"Giving a tax cut only to two-earner couples would send the radical feminist message that the government sees no value in a homemaker's work at home," Ms. Schlafly wrote at the time, urging her supporters to write and call important Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee.
The upshot is good news for the Harriet Nelsons of the country, unless, of course, Harriet decides to be a lawyer and make some money herself.
