HEADLINE: China Arrests North Koreans Headed for the South and Japan 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
The Chinese police arrested more than 60 North Koreans in China on Friday and Saturday as they were preparing to board two fishing boats purchased to smuggle them to freedom in Japan and South Korea, human rights workers and activists said today.
 The boats were to have been used in the first in a series of illegal boat crossings organized and financed by human rights activists, who want to help North Koreans escape their impoverished homeland. 
 The activists see the refugee crossings as dramatic events that can vividly illustrate what they call the repression and suffering in North Korea.
In the past the activists have helped groups of North Koreans storm into foreign embassies in Beijing, where they have obtained political asylum. Inevitably those dramas play out with television cameras rolling. 
"We are trying to create more solidarity with these people," said the Rev. Douglas Shin, a Los Angeles-based pastor who has worked with North Korean refugees for years. "And we almost succeeded. Nothing really bad happened. Next time will know how to do it better."
The two 20-ton Chinese fishing vessels were purchased and outfitted for $5,000 each by a consortium of seven foreign private organizations, representing four countries, Mr. Shin said. 
They were to have departed on Saturday from the Chinese port of Yantai; by Friday, 48 North Koreans were assembled at safe houses there in preparation.
One boat was to have set a course for Cheju, an island belonging to South Korea, where Chinese fishing boats frequently drop anchor without proper documentation, Mr. Shin said. The second was to have headed for Sasebo, a Japanese island that is home to a large United States military base -- a destination Mr. Shin called "a symbolic gesture to make this an international issue."
Northeastern China has a large ethnic Korean population, allowing North Koreans who have illegally sneaked over the border into China to blend in with relative ease. Indeed, the entire group took the public ferries to Yantai in the days before.
But on Friday night, the Chinese police began raiding the safe houses and arresting the North Koreans, apparently tipped off by a Chinese informant who had helped the group, Mr. Shin said.
As of today there were 48 North Koreans in detention in Yantai, including families with women and children, according to Doctors Without Borders-Korea, one of the organizations that assisted the refugees. 
It said three foreigners who were accompanying the North Koreans were also arrested, including Jae Hyun Seok, a South Korean freelance photographer who regularly works for The New York Times.
Reached by telephone, an official from the Yantai Public Security Bureau denied any knowledge of the arrests.
"The case of this group of 48 North Koreans is most revealing," said a statement released today by Doctors Without Borders. "It unveils the distress of the North Korean refugee population in China and the urgent need to provide them assistance."
Mr. Shin said a further 13 North Koreans who had planned to be on the boats had been arrested before they got to Yantai, in the border province of Jilin. 
He said that at least some of them had been turned over to the North Korean authorities.
In the last five years, hundreds of thousands of North Koreans have fled illegally over the border into China. They come to escape the severe food shortages that have plagued their homeland for nearly a decade, but increasingly they come for a taste of relative freedom as well. 
While some stay just long enough to collect provisions, others live in China for years, performing low-wage jobs, learning Chinese and blending into the large ethnic Korean population in the border area.
But as their numbers have risen, many refugees have come to live in fear of Chinese police raids aimed at ferreting them out and repatriating them. 
Such raids have increased since last year, when groups of North Koreans started storming foreign embassies in Beijing, embarrassing the Chinese.
The number of North Koreans seeking political asylum in South Korea has nearly doubled annually in recent years, to about 1,000 in 2002. More than 100 of those arrived via embassies in China, but a larger number were smuggled in, some by stowing away on boats or by paying smugglers.
China says the North Korean are economic migrants who should be sent home. 
But rights groups insist that they are political refugees who deserve asylum, since they are often interrogated and arrested once they are back in North Korea. Those who have fled repeatedly or have had contact with foreigners may face severe punishment, even death, the rights groups say.

HEADLINE: Ex-President Of Serbia Surrenders To Tribunal 

BYLINE:  By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
The former Serbian President, Milan Milutinovic, surrendered today to the United Nations tribunal, which has charged him with crimes against humanity related to the 1999 conflict in Kosovo.
 He was the last ally of Slobodan Milosevic to hold high office and had enjoyed immunity from prosecution until he stepped down in December. 
 Mr. Milutinovic, who became Serbia's president in 1997, arrived here on a special plane provided by the Yugoslav government. Belgrade has been lobbying on his behalf for special concessions, like release on bail until his trial begins. 
He was meeting today with the tribunal's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, but no details were immediately forthcoming on the conditions of his surrender. When Mr. Milutinovic appears in court on Wednesday, tribunal judges will probably decide if he can return to Belgrade pending trial. His health may be a factor: the Serbian politician has already had heart surgery and is said to require medical supervision.
For now, Mr. Milutinovic, 60, is being held at the same United Nations prison here as his one-time patron, Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslavian president. 
Mr. Milosevic also has a heart condition, and tribunal officials said today that his trial remained suspended while he fought another bout of flu. Mr. Milosevic's high blood pressure and heart disease make him prone to infections and fatigue, according to one of his legal assistants. Hearings last year were repeatedly interrupted by Mr. Milosevic's health problems, prolonging already lengthy proceedings.
It was not clear whether Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Milutinovic are allowed to meet in the three-story United Nations jail here, where Serbs, Croats and Bosnians often mingle. Although Mr. Milutinovic was a member of the Milosevic inner circle, he was widely regarded as a figurehead who attended meetings but seldom involved himself in decision making or operations. 
As the head of the Serbian delegation to talks with the Kosovar Albanians at Rambouillet in February 1999, before NATO bombed Yugoslavia, Mr. Milutinovic bore the brunt of Western efforts to force Mr. Milosevic to withdraw his forces from Kosovo. But he was unwilling, and probably unable, to persuade Mr. Milosevic to back down. He ended his speech at the summit with the words: "Que sera sera."
He hopes to fashion his defense around his reputation for disengagement in government affairs, and has denied the prosecution's charges of crimes against humanity, including deportation, murder and persecution. During the Serbian crackdown of the late 1990's, which Belgrade said was necessary to maintain control over its province of Kosovo, some 800,000 ethnic Albanians fled Serbian police and military violence and hundreds were killed.
This week, the Belgrade government has made much of its cooperation with the tribunal by helping ensure the arrival of Mr. Milutinovic here. But this may be as much a signal to Washington as it is a good-will gesture. The United States has said Yugoslavia risks losing economic assistance after March 31 if it does not arrest war crimes suspects and cooperate with the tribunal. But Belgrade has not yet detained others indicted by the tribunal, including the former Bosnian Serb military chief Ratko Mladic, who is often seen in Belgrade. The former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, has also been seen in Yugoslavia, but he reportedly spends most of his time in hiding in eastern Bosnia.

Fiat, Trying to Cut Debt, Weighs Spinoff of Car Unit
The chairman of Fiat, Paolo Fresco, left, said that the company was considering plans to split off its automobile division and raise the cash needed to restore it to profitability. Mr. Fresco said the goal of the spinoff would be to "recapitalize our core businesses, starting with Fiat Auto, but not only Fiat Auto."
 Mr. Fresco has been trying to sell assets to ease Fiat's financial troubles. Recent divestitures enabled Fiat to pay down its net debt below $3.2 billion. Sharp reductions in debt were a condition set by creditors. Page C2. 

Courts Debate Internet Bans
Courts are increasingly facing the question of whether people who use a computer and the Internet to commit a crime can be barred from using the Internet after they have served their sentences. A1.

Lawmakers Pressure Bank of Japan
The failure of the Bank of Japan to halt deflation -- after having kept short-term interest rates effectively at zero for more than four years -- has turned into a political battleground. Japanese lawmakers are prodding the central bank to find a way to do even more to stimulate the sagging economy. C11.

Ontario Halts Sale of Utility Stake
All but putting an end to a deregulated electricity market in Canada's industrial heartland, the government of Ontario said that it would not sell a stake in Hydro One. Less than a year ago, the government said that it intended to spin off the utility. C10.

Pemex Faces Troubles of Its Own
For more than 60 years, Pemex has been Mexico's economic lifeblood. It controls every gas pump in Mexico, and it sells nearly as much oil to the United States as Saudi Arabia does. Today, with some oil producers like Iraq and Venezuela facing crises, Mexico looks like a steady source of oil that the United States may be tempted to rely on even more. But the oil company is in danger of breaking down. A1.

The surge in oil prices caused by a loss of production in Venezuela and the possibility of an American-led attack on Iraq has created a rare spectacle: the president of OPEC complaining that oil prices are too high. C13.

Oil Terminal in Latvia Lacks Oil
What little oil has been reaching Ventspils, Latvia, from Russia in recent weeks has come by rail. Transneft, the sole supplier of oil, says it has stopped delivering to Ventspils because it is now supplying oil to its own new terminal at Primorsk, on the Gulf of Finland. C4.

Using an unexpected vacancy in its senior management ranks to cement a change in strategic direction, the NEC Corporation named Akinobu Kanasugi as its president. Mr. Kanasugi, 61, has run NEC's subsidiary in those fields, NEC Solutions, for three years. C11.

When Egg Banking began marketing a credit card in France that paid customers 1 percent of their purchases, it came up with a campaign that tried to disprove preconceived notions. In the process, the campaign unleashed a firestorm of protest. Advertising. C14.

Markets overseas slid lower as fears about war and downbeat corporate outlooks for companies like Royal Dutch/Shell raised investor concerns about a stumbling economy in the coming months. C4.

In surveys, Singapore Airlines usually ranks at or near the top for its food. Not for nothing, then, is Singapore emphasizing its commitment to dining, at a time when many airlines have ended food service or have started selling meals. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C13.

HEADLINE: Schools Resegregate, Study Finds 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 20 

 BODY:
Sanetra Jant still wonders where all the white kids went. Only last spring, they made up a quarter of her class, not to mention her friends. And then, poof, they were gone.
 "I don't know why they left," said Sanetra, a fourth grader at Reid Park Elementary School. 
 Last year, before a federal appeals court ended three decades of judicial-supervised desegregation by the district, Sanetra's school was 68 percent black. Now it is almost entirely black, and the many white pupils who once rode in on yellow buses number one in a hundred. 
"Maybe they didn't like it here," Sanetra said, knitting her brow in thought. 
If there is any one place to witness the changing racial composition of the nation's public schools, perhaps it is here, in the city for which the Supreme Court first endorsed the use of busing to desegregate.
Dozens of Charlotte schools have basically changed color in the months since the appeals court lifted the desegregation order, and though few other places have seen swings so rapid, the city offers a time-lapse view of the steady transformation of the nation's schools.
According to a new study by the Civil Rights Project at Harvard University, black and Latino students are now more isolated from their white counterparts than they were three decades ago, before many of the overhauls from the civil rights movement had even begun to take hold.
Nationally, the shift is a result of several factors: big increases in enrollment by black, Latino and Asian students; continuing white flight from the nation's urban centers; and the persistence of housing patterns that isolate racial and ethnic groups. But another big factor, the Harvard study found, has been the termination of dozens of court-ordered desegregation plans.
Spurred by Supreme Court decisions at the start of the 1990's, lower courts have lifted desegregation orders in at least three dozen school districts in the last 10 years. Little Rock, San Diego, Denver and Miami have all come out from under court supervision, and next month a federal judge will reconsider the integration plan in Chicago, the nation's third-largest school district.
A chief principle in the voiding of these orders is one established by the Supreme Court a decade ago: that school districts can be considered successfully desegregated even if student racial imbalances due entirely to demographic factors, like where children live, continue to exist.
Largely as a result, black students now typically go to schools where fewer than 31 percent of their classmates are white, the new Harvard study found. That is less contact than in 1970, a year before the Supreme Court authorized the busing that became a primary way of integrating schools.
Latino students, who have rarely been a focus of desegregation efforts, now attend schools where whites account for only 29 percent of all students, compared with 45 percent three decades ago, according to the study, which draws on Education Department data through the 2000-1 school year.
And while white children increasingly come into contact with minority students, mainly because of the tremendous population growth among races that had only marginal representation decades ago, they are still America's most segregated group, the study found. On average, white students, who make up about 61 percent of the nation's public-school population, go to schools where 80 percent of their classmates are white.
The consequence is a nation in which every racial group that is big enough to be described as segregated generally is: Blacks, though only 17 percent of public-school children, typically attend schools where they are in a majority. The same is true of Latinos, who are about 16 percent of the student population. Even American Indians, a mere 1 percent of public-school children, go to schools where nearly a third of all students are Native American. 
Asians, the study says, are the most integrated group, attending schools where the races are somewhat more commensurate with their national representation. But they, too, are disproportionately grouped together, for though they are only about 4 percent of public-school children, they typically go to schools that are 22 percent Asian. 
"We call our schools racially isolated, but it's really just a euphemism for being segregated," said Mary Frances Berry, chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. "It has to be regarded as unhealthy. At a time when the society is becoming increasingly diverse, it bodes ill to have increasingly segregated schools."
Many researchers cite sweeping demographic changes, not public policy, as the leading force behind racial separation in the schools. The percentage of students who are members of minority groups has almost doubled in the last 30 years, and, whether as a legacy of enforced segregation, a function of economics or an expression of personal choice, they live largely apart from whites, and often from one another. 
Not only did the exodus of white families from cities continue throughout the 1990's, but new suburban enclaves of minorities, particularly African-Americans, also formed, expanding the ring of largely segregated communities beyond the urban core. 
But demographics alone cannot account for the rapid segregation of schools, according to the study. As elsewhere, the growth in population among minority students in Southern states has outpaced that of white students for years, and yet the region remained among the nation's most integrated throughout the 1980's, the researchers found. Only in the last decade or so, as courts have declared the schools integrated enough to dissolve desegregation orders, has the segregation between black and white students begun to grow.
"You can't talk about the changes that have happened without talking about the effects of the court orders, particularly in the South," said Erica D. Frankenberg, one of the authors. "The correlation is too strong." 
Quite apart from the argument that the school districts are not responsible for correcting neighborhood segregation, some white parents have challenged desegregation plans for considering race at all. Here in Charlotte, white parents filed suit in 1997 contending that their children were being discriminated against because they could not go to schools of their choice. A federal appeals court ruled in their favor in 2001, lifting the district's plan. The Supreme Court declined to hear the case last year, making this fall the first in three decades in which the system did not use race to help determine where children went to school. 
The effect was immediate, as schools quickly began to mirror their largely segregated neighborhoods. But while Janice L. Lewis, the principal at Reid Park Elementary here, would welcome the day when she presides over a diverse student body once again, she has few worries that lacking one hurts the caliber of her shiny, almost-new school.
Sprawled out over 18 acres of frost-nipped lawns and untouched trees, Reid Park defies the image of an "inner-city school," as it is often called. Its spacious hallways echo a kind of focused calm that many private schools would envy.
Yet it does have a characteristic common to racially segregated schools: poverty. On average, blacks and Latinos attend schools where roughly 45 percent of the students are poor, compared with 19 percent among whites, a reflection of racial discrepancies in income, the study found. At Reid Park, the number is even higher, with more than 8 in 10 students poor enough to qualify for free or reduced-price lunches.
While few openly question the social importance of integrated schools, as a catalyst for breaking down stereotypes and encouraging tolerance, the debate over academic benefits of integration is a fiery one, often infused with as much ideology as evidence. Some researchers, liberals and conservatives alike, argue that breaking up concentrations of same-race children tends to improve academic performance, especially among black students. Others reject the notion, contending that mixing student populations guarantees little but longer bus rides. 
A conviction that predominantly minority schools suffer from scant resources remains one reason why civil rights lawyers are determined to keep desegregation orders in place where they can.
"The bottom line is that all of our experience with desegregation came not from serendipity but through deliberate efforts to change what had been put in place," said Theodore M. Shaw, associate director of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. "In that respect, it's also true that if we're going to do anything about racial segregation in the 21st century, it's not going to happen serendipitously."

HEADLINE: Bush Proposal May Cut Tax On S.U.V.'s For Business 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's economic plan would increase by 50 percent or more the deductions that small-business owners can take right away on the biggest sport utility vehicles and pickups.
 The plan would mean small businesses could immediately deduct the entire price of S.U.V.'s like the Hummer H2, the Lincoln Navigator and the Toyota Land Cruiser, even if the vehicles were loaded with every available option. Or a business owner, taking full advantage, could buy a BMW X5 sport utility vehicle for a few hundred dollars more than a Pontiac Bonneville sedan, after the immediate tax deductions were factored in. 
 Tax experts and environmentalists say the plan would provide incentives for businesses to choose the biggest gas-guzzling trucks because it takes several years to depreciate the cost of passenger cars and smaller sport utility vehicles. The ramifications of the Bush plan on S.U.V. buyers were reported today in The Detroit News. 
The potential lift for sales of big S.U.V.'s comes amid rising tension in the Middle East and increasing criticism of S.U.V.'s from environmentalists and regulators. 
But a top budget official said today that the administration might be open to changes in the tax code that would bring cars more in line with big trucks. 
"We have an open mind about whether the deduction for cars needs to be refined," said Dr. John Graham, the administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs in the Office of Management and Budget.
The tax code now caps deductions for most automobiles. But the largest vehicles -- those that weigh more than 6,000 pounds fully loaded -- are exempt because the relevant portion of the code was written in the 1980's, before the rise of the sport utility vehicle, and was intended to exempt big pickups needed on work sites. Now the tax incentives also give business owners not involved in hauling -- doctors, real estate agents, accountants -- more incentive to buy the biggest S.U.V.'s instead of smaller ones, or cars. 
The proposal "makes a glitch in the tax code much worse and it benefits rich businessmen who want to buy massive S.U.V.'s," said Aileen Roder, program director for Taxpayers for Common Sense. "In essence we're buying these vehicles for these businesses."
But the administration says that greater business deductions will be a potent economic stimulant.
"Many small businesses have genuine needs for large vans, pickups and S.U.V.'s, whether it be for a farm, sales or industrial application," Dr. Graham said. "An updated tax deduction for small businesses is certainly needed."
Consider the Hummer H1 as an example of the new deduction. It is one of the largest and most expensive S.U.V.'s, with a base sticker price of $102,581, including destination charge. Under the Bush plan, small-business owners could use all of an annual $75,000 capital equipment deduction toward the purchase; the current equipment deduction allowance is just $25,000. 
That is in addition to thousands of dollars in other deductions. Under existing rules, a business could deduct 30 percent from the base price left after the capital equipment deduction, a benefit put in place as part of a post-Sept. 11 stimulus package. In the case of the H1, that would be a further deduction of $8,274.
Finally, 20 percent could be deducted from what is left, part of the business deductions available for automobiles. For the H1, that would be $3,861 more in deductions. 
The total would be more than $87,000 in deductions, or about $33,500 in savings in federal taxes alone for buyers in the highest bracket. Under current rules, just less than $60,000 could be deducted. 
Deals for cars and small sport utility vehicles are much less appealing. Currently, a business can deduct no more than $7,660 for a car in its first year of service, $4,900 in the second year and less in the succeeding years. The Toyota Prius, which uses a fuel-efficient blend of gasoline and electric power, is eligible for an additional $2,000 clean vehicle deduction. That means a business owner could deduct under half of the $20,500 sticker price of the Prius in the first year of purchase, for about $3,700 worth of federal tax savings for those in the highest tax bracket. 
David Friedman, an engineer and analyst at the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group, said the increased deduction for big vehicles was "yet another loophole that the government is keeping open that is increasing our oil dependence." 
"Before, it was large enough to drive a small S.U.V. through," he added. "Now it's large enough to drive a Hummer through."
Without altering the treatment of cars in the tax code, the Bush plan could run counter to the administration's recent decision to force automakers to improve the fuel economy of S.U.V.'s, pickups and minivans by 7 percent by middecade. 
That is probably why the administration is open minded when it comes to reviewing the tax treatment of different kinds of vehicles.
Dr. Graham reiterated today that the administration was also considering further fuel economy measures. S.U.V.'s and pickups that weigh more than 8,500 pounds fully loaded have been exempt from federal fuel regulations. But the administration "is currently investigating whether those rules should be extended to larger light trucks" weighing as much as 10,000 pounds, he said.

HEADLINE: A Casino in the Catskills May be Good for the Economy but Bad for the Traffic 

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: GOSHEN, N.Y. 

 BODY:
As Sullivan County inches closer to its long-held dream of welcoming casinos, people in Orange County, its neighbor here to the southeast, are starting to ponder what gambling in the Catskills will mean for them. In a word, traffic.
 Sullivan County hopes to attract lines of gamblers disgorging coins and dollars and breathing new life into its anemic economy. Orange County expects to reap only lines of cars along Route 17, its main east-west artery, clogging connecting roads and fouling the air. 
 The problem is that Route 17, or the Quickway, as locals call it, is already filled with cars on weekends, as people from New York City travel to and from the Catskills. "It's literally bumper-to-bumper, particularly in warm weather," said the Orange County planning commissioner, David E. Church. 
Orange County registered its concern with a strongly worded letter last fall to the Sullivan County town of Thompson, which recently accepted the environmental findings for the planned Mohawk casino and resort. The casino is being developed by the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe and Park Place Entertainment Corporation, one of the largest casino operators. 
According to Mr. Church, the environmental statement did not consider the effects of traffic in the wider region. It also failed to show how much traffic would be increased by other developments on the drawing board, including a proposed arts center and another possible casino in the same Sullivan County town, he said. 
Orange County officials estimate that the Mohawk casino will bring 12,000 more car trips through the county each day. They base that on the developer's assertion that the majority of traffic to the casino will be from the east along Route 17.
"Yet," Mr. Church wrote in his letter, "the impact to travel and safety on Orange County highways -- the gateways to Sullivan County -- are ignored" in the statement.
The supervisor of Thompson, Anthony P. Cellini, said the town would try to be "good neighbors" and "mitigate whatever the concerns are" in Orange County.
Because Orange County has no authority over the casinos, Mr. Church fears that his county eventually may have to "grin and bear" the traffic. Yet, he and others are suggesting ways to keep the traffic moving, from incentives for using buses to a light rail system.
A spokesman for Park Place Entertainment, Robert Stewart, said the $500 million Mohawk casino, which is to include a 750-room hotel and 165,000 square feet of casino space, would not significantly alter traffic on Route 17.
"The issues of traffic congestion on Route 17 extend far beyond any incremental traffic that's going to be created by the construction of the Mohawk casino," Mr. Stewart said. "There is traffic that clogs Route 17 already south of Sullivan, and we think a comprehensive examination is really what's called for."
He added, "We certainly would support working with the state of New York on those issues." 
The clicking of the first roulette wheel may not be heard for some time, perhaps years. Casinos need approval from the Bureau of Indian Affairs, and the projects still face legal challenges from gambling opponents.
Still, the consensus among many residents of both counties is that casinos are coming. After moving in fits and starts since the mid-1990's, progress toward a Mohawk casino in particular has accelerated. Suzanne Morris, a spokeswoman for Gov. George E. Pataki, called it the "only serious proposal out there right now."
In 2001, the State Legislature approved six Indian casinos in New York, including up to three in the Catskills. That year the St. Regis Mohawk tribe signed an agreement with Park Place Entertainment to build and run a casino at Kutsher's Country Club, one of the few remaining resorts in the Catskills. 
To be sure, many Orange County residents are supportive of the economic benefits casinos would bring to Sullivan. For years resorts in the Catskills, and Sullivan County, formed what was called the borscht belt because of the many Jewish New Yorkers who vacationed there. One by one, most of the county's hotels and resorts have closed.
Now, some business owners in Orange County are hoping for some gains from the Sullivan developments. "It will bring more people to the area for jobs, which will mean more homes and more shoppers," said Jennifer DiMarco, who owns an upscale stationery store in the county seat here.
That is exactly what others dread, though. Three towns in Orange County now have building moratoriums in place after experiencing years of runaway home construction, Mr. Church said. In recent years, the county has attracted many home buyers priced out of Manhattan, Westchester County and northern New Jersey.
"The Catskills have gotten more popular, and 9/11 made people look for the safety and security of a more remote location," Mr. Church said. "We can't build houses fast enough to meet the demand. It's just tremendous. And the bulk of it is single-family housing, which is very car-dependent."
In the quaint downtown here, where the turn-of-the-century look of the streets could be part of a Frank Capra film, people on their lunch breaks said they were bracing for traffic tie-ups on Route 17 once the casinos are built.
"From 3 o'clock Thursday afternoon until Sunday evening, it's horrendous now for the locals, just horrendous," said William Smith, a computer technician who lives in Harriman. "You can't even get on. The casinos are going to make it a lot worse." 
But Mr. Cellini, the supervisor of Thompson, pointed out that Sullivan County residents had to wade through Orange County's traffic "when we drive back from New York City." And "they didn't consult us" on their housing boom, he added.
"Success," he added, "is a traffic jam."

(Photographs by Chris Ramirez for The New York Times) Map of New York State highlighting the town of Thompson: Plans for a casino in Thompson upset Orange County.

HEADLINE: Years of Chaos, Piled in Newark Child Care Office 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI and LESLIE KAUFMAN 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 19 

 BODY:
Inside the cramped offices of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services in Newark, the signs of chaos are not subtle.
 Caseworkers assigned to investigate allegations of child abuse sit before broken computer terminals and beside file cabinets crammed with infant formula, baby shampoo and economy-size tubs of diaper-rash ointment. In a daily rush, runaways, counselors, troubled parents, social workers, abused children, nurses and bureaucrats all hurry through hallways where case folders are stacked openly in haphazard piles against the wall. 
 Pillars throughout the office display the kind of handwritten notices commonly seen on telephone poles announcing a rummage sale or lost pet. "Missing file," the signs read, then list the names and case numbers of people whose problems the state has lost track of amid the relentless crush of new crises. 
The disarray plaguing New Jersey's child welfare system, and its potential consequences, became tragically apparent earlier this month, when a 7-year-old, Faheem Williams, was found dead in the same basement of a home in north Newark where two of his bothers had been locked in, starving and beaten.
A caseworker had closed a child abuse allegation into the family last February without ever visiting the children, and the furor over that decision prompted Gov. James E. McGreevey to order an overhaul of a state child welfare system that has floundered through decades of mismanagement and neglect. But an examination of the Newark office, so overloaded with difficult cases and miserable working conditions that some caseworkers call it the "belly of the beast," offers an indication of the enormousness of that task.
The failures in the Williams case occurred within a unit that state officials and caseworkers concede is so poorly equipped, badly managed and understaffed that breakdowns are accepted as daily routine.
When state officials arrived last week to assess the office, only 2 of the 18 computer terminals worked, and the computer system was not working for 80 percent of the workday. Even when the computer system is operating, it is too outdated to track thousands of open cases, forcing one supervisor to manage her employees by maneuvering 250 Post-it notes on the wall of her office cubicle.
There are only 22 beds for teenage runaways in Newark, frequently forcing caseworkers to waste days driving to shelters as far away as Atlantic City or Bridgewater.
Until last week, the electronic office keys issued to caseworkers were programmed to forbid them access to the building on weekends, and those workers who remained after 5 p.m. could not unlock the bathrooms.
As the system staggers on, the Newark office gets an average of nine new child abuse allegations a day, compounding the problems.
Supervisors concede that cases often languish four or five months before being reviewed. Caseworkers say they are so overwhelmed that they have little choice but to perform slipshod investigations.
"What you have here," said Kevin Ryan, whom Mr. McGreevey assigned to take over the Newark office last week, "is an infrastructure completely overwhelmed by the volume and complexity of problems thrown at it every day."
Child welfare agencies in cities and states across the nation wrestle with sporadic financing and onerous caseloads, but New Jersey's has proven particularly resistant to reform over the past two decades. Despite panels and periodic attempts to overhaul the system, New Jersey still assigns caseloads far higher than recommended by experts and remains one of a handful of states not to use federal financing for a computerized case-tracking system.
Because Newark is New Jersey's largest city, and home to some of its most complex social problems, the social service offices here stand as a vivid example of the way those systemic flaws bog down supervisors and staff members. Newark's three DYFS offices received 3,104 abuse and neglect complaints in 2001, and 1,004 of those were substantiated.
A review of the division across the state last month found 1,358 case files in which the state had not yet verified whether an abuse or neglect allegation was true, and 431 of those were from the Newark office.
Mr. Ryan has made his temporary headquarters in District Office No. 2, where the Williams case had been handled, and said he was stunned to find so many lingering problems whose solutions seemed so obvious.
Mr. Ryan cited staff cars as an example. A shortage of cars was so acute that caseworkers were forced to place their names on a long request list, then wait for a dispatcher to call when a vehicle became available, said Reggie Jones, a Newark caseworker.
"You can't get up to go to the bathroom or look out the window because if they call you back they only give you three minutes," Mr. Jones said, adding that it was common to see caseworkers barreling down the stairs at breakneck speed to get a car before it was reassigned.
Mr. Ryan quickly ordered new cars, so the 420 employees who work out of the various Newark offices had easier access to the families they were supposed to supervise. The state also sent in 222 new cellphones, to enable caseworkers to confer with supervisors when handling a complicated situation in the field. Building security managers were ordered to reprogram the key cards, allowing caseworkers into the office -- and the bathrooms -- on demand. There are plans for new computers.
Mr. Ryan also began revamping the case assignment system, which had doled out new complaints at random, and is devising a method to steer cases to different caseworkers depending on their strengths, weaknesses and existing caseloads.
"So much of the problem here was just management," he said, "that it actually makes me optimistic that we can turn things around here."
But there is little to suggest that others in the office share that optimism. As Mr. Ryan formulated his plans in the district director's office on Thursday, a therapist hired by the employees' union was in a conference room down the hall, counseling four beleaguered caseworkers.
Their voices crackling with frustration and resignation, they recounted workdays of petty humiliations: school counselors who call in abuse complaints after sending the children into the homes where they were allegedly mistreated; a family court system so overburdened that caseworkers often waste days waiting to testify; a shortage of shelter space; hostile families and dangerous neighborhoods.
One caseworker said that last summer she was assigned to remove a child from a family in a neighborhood so violent that a police officer refused to accompany her unless he received backup. Another caseworker, who spoke on the condition that her name not be published, looked on and shook her head in disgust.
"If it's dangerous, I just don't go," she said, defiantly. "I've got kids. If I get killed out there, who's going to take care of them?"
Caseworkers and supervisors say that the system's troubles have outlasted so many attempts at reform that few believe Mr. McGreevey has the endurance necessary to deliver on his promise to fix it once and for all. Elected officials are quick to impose new regulations for handling child abuse complaints, caseworkers say, but rarely send resources.
The difficult nature of the work, and modest pay, have resulted in a turnover rate of nearly 20 percent, state officials say, which only worsens the problem. With a shortage of experienced caseworkers, the constant parade of trainees has led to a uneven distribution of workload. Some workers handle 10 cases, while others, the state admits, must contend with more than 100.
But the most persistent complaint is the pressure to close cases.
Many workers say caseloads are brought up at annual evaluations and cited as factors in determining whether a raise or promotion is granted. These workers argue that the pressure to close is a bureaucratic counting game that focuses on the total numbers rather than the complexity of the cases or thoroughness of investigations.
Late last year, when a snowstorm forced the state to close all government offices early, the manager of the Newark office said that caseworkers with more than 50 cases must remain. Employees complained to their union, and all the caseworkers were allowed to leave, but the message was clear.
"The pressure to close cases is outrageous," said Dominick Antonicello, who spent 20 years working in the Newark office and was recently transferred to Bloomfield.
Workers say that family services officials in Trenton were so intent on lowering caseloads that they issued a memo in July 2002, instructing caseworkers that in some circumstances, they were permitted to close old cases even if they had not personally visited the families in months. Although the memo was issued after the Williams case had been closed, caseworkers say it indicates the kind of atmosphere that has existed in the Newark office for years.
Mr. Ryan said that on his first day in Newark, he met with staff members and informed them that they should immediately consider thorough investigations their primary obligation, rather than reducing caseloads. But Mr. Ryan conceded that the agency had pressured caseworkers in so many ways that it would take a sustained effort to truly change the focus of the office.
"This is not McDonald's," he said. "If you want to close a case, you have to visit the families, period. We're still trying to understand all the different factors that led them to feel pressured. And I will not leave here until that message gets through."

 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

France Rules Out Voting To Support an Iraq War
In unusually blunt terms aimed at preempting the United States, France said that it would not support any Security Council resolution for military action against Iraq in the coming weeks. France's foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin, would not rule out the possibility that France would use its veto power if the United States presses the Council to authorize war against Iraq for failing to disarm. A1

Inspectors Win Commitments
Iraq said it would urge its scientists to agree to private interviews with United Nations arms inspectors, bowing to a major American demand on the eve of a report by the inspectors next week to the Security Council. The undertaking by Iraq, which seemed intent on convincing states in the United Nations that Iraq is willing to compromise, was among 10 specific commitments made to the inspectors. A1

Yasar Yakis, Turkey's foreign minister, said that his government had decided to allow the United States to use Turkish bases for an attack on Iraq, but that Turkish public opinion was forcing them to scale back the American plans drastically. A10

Warning From Rumsfeld
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said that diplomacy might yet resolve the nuclear stand-off with North Korea, but he warned in stark terms that in the case of Iraq, all of the options -- except the use of force -- were nearly exhausted. A10

So grim has life suddenly become in war-torn Ivory Coast that about 1,000 Liberian refugees have rushed into the United Nations compound in Tabou over the last three days and volunteered to do the unimaginable: return to Liberia, where its own war continues unabated. A3

The funeral of a Jewish settler slain by Palestinian gunmen on Friday night turned into a riot that stunned even normally contentious Israel. There were a series of struggles over where the body would be buried -- including an aborted race with the body in a car toward Jerusalem. A8

Eight back-packing American sky mountaineers on helicopter tours of the jagged Selkirk Mountains of western Canada were buried and killed by an avalanche, according to local officials. Two others were injured. The mountaineers were on tours organized by Selkirk Mountain Experience. A3

HEADLINE: Conservative Positions by Bush Could Cost Votes From Center, Moderates Warn 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
President Bush's decision to take strong conservative positions on an array of foreign, economic and social policy issues is drawing warnings from moderates within his party that he could alienate the centrist voters he needs for his re-election.
 As he prepares for the second half of his term -- he was sworn in two years ago today -- Mr. Bush hardly lets a day go by without pleasing his supporters on the Republican right. He has maintained a hard line against Iraq even as much of the rest of the world urges him to slow down. He has proposed a new round of tax cuts that pleasantly surprised even ardent supply-siders. He has denounced quotas in affirmative action programs. On Wednesday, the 30th anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision, he plans to make a supportive statement to demonstrators rallying against abortion. 
 By most measures, Mr. Bush's political standing remains enviable as he and his Democratic challengers begin to gear up for the 2004 race. He has continued to reach out to moderates on a few issues like education and health care while avoiding the festering discontent among conservatives that helped doom his father's bid for re-election in 1992. Moreover, Mr. Bush's advisers said, his leadership and ambitious initiatives will resonate more with voters of all stripes than will criticism about where a policy sits on the ideological spectrum. 
But with each conservative principle he emphasizes, Mr. Bush risks alienating crucial constituencies in the center, like working women, suburbanites and Hispanics, that he needs if he is to maintain a governing coalition for his party and firm up his own electoral prospects, analysts and activists in both parties said.
"We believe our party is on a collision course with the electorate, and as Republicans that concerns us greatly," said Jennifer Blei Stockman, national co-chairwoman of the Republican Pro-Choice Coalition, a group that favors abortion rights. "While the party is feeling very strong after the 2002 elections, that could be the last gasp before the reality of what they've been doing with the right wing of the party really hits."
Internal splits over ideology and particular issues are nothing new in either major party, and it is by no means certain that the moderates who backed Mr. Bush in 2000 would abandon him in 2004. Still, any signs of diminished support from moderates, independents and conservative Democrats could make it harder for Mr. Bush to push through his legislative agenda and lead a united party into the presidential campaign.
In the Senate, moderate Republicans like Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island and Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, who could hold the balance of power in the narrowly divided chamber, are already working across the aisle to scale back Mr. Bush's proposed $670 billion tax cut.
At the grass-roots level, Republicans involved in domestic issues like the environment said Mr. Bush was turning out to be more conservative than they had hoped.
"The administration is playing to a base of hard-core ideologues who have this bizarre notion that conservation and environmental protection are left-wing plots against the American way of life," said Jim DiPeso, policy director of Republicans for Environmental Protection, an advocacy group.
As he has since the 2000 campaign, Mr. Bush is working to avoid being stuck with simplistic portrayals of himself as an ideologue. He has tried to soften the edges of conservative decisions by, for example, sidestepping in his critique last week of the University of Michigan's affirmative action program the compelling question of whether race should remain a consideration in college admissions. 
At the same time, he has continued to emphasize a willingness to reach bipartisan compromises on issues like education and health care, and to show a concern for lower income people by holding events like one this month that brought to the White House women who had moved off welfare and into the work force.
As a result, it is hard to find any more consensus now than there was on Inauguration Day as to whether his "compassionate conservatism" is a new way of approaching the issues or, as liberals would have it, the same old right-wing package in deceptive new wrapping.
For all his strengths, Mr. Bush faces some worrisome signs. His overall approval ratings, though still high, have been falling, as have figures on his handling of the economy, a politically potent issue even in wartime.
Indeed, with so much of his reputation riding on his role as commander in chief, a war in Iraq that is bloodier, longer or less conclusive than expected could have considerable political consequences, especially if the economy does not strengthen soon.
"If you operate on the premise that administrations have to grab hold of the center, then you have to wonder what George Bush is doing," said Leon E. Panetta, who was chief of staff in the Clinton White House, which was often ruefully credited by Republicans with successfully blurring ideological lines.
In some ways, Mr. Bush is trying to redefine or neutralize traditionally Democratic issues like education and health care in the same way that Bill Clinton tried to co-opt Republicans on crime, welfare and fiscal responsibility. But there is a big difference between the ideological pressures on the current administration halfway into its term and those facing Mr. Clinton at the same point in his presidency.
After the Republican sweep of Congress in 1994, Mr. Clinton was forced to the center as a matter of political survival, a development that almost certainly helped him in 1996. After the Republican victories in the House and Senate in 2002, Mr. Bush faces the task of keeping conservatives in general and the House Republican leadership in particular from pulling him and his party away from the vote-rich center.
"Bush's base is further to the right than where many Americans are outside the South," said James A. Thurber, director of the Center for Congressional and Presidential Studies at American University in Washington. "That makes it difficult to seek votes from Hispanics, African-Americans, single women, yet Republicans need to do that in order to grow."
The president's supporters said his ideological straddle reflected not so much political calculus as genuinely eclectic thinking. They said Mr. Bush's approach was rooted in conservative orthodoxy but influenced by a belief that there is a legitimate role for government in addressing society's needs and an imperative for the Republican Party to stand for tolerance.
Mr. Bush, they said, sees no contradiction in delivering a politically fatal blow to Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi for statements that appeared to embrace the segregationist appeals of Strom Thurmond's 1948 presidential campaign, then renominating a judge who has been a lightning rod for criticism from civil rights groups. He has no trouble proposing a big tax cut at a time of rapidly rising budget deficits and then proclaiming himself an advocate of fiscal responsibility.
This is not a president, they said, at risk of being paralyzed by cognitive dissonance.
"I have had the sense with Bush that this compassionate conservative thing is not so much a deliberate strategy as it is the complicated mix of his own personal beliefs," said Mickey Edwards, a former Republican congressman who is now a lecturer at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, has frequently described Mr. Bush as a "different kind of Republican." The obvious follow-up question has always been: Different from what?
"Different from a stereotypical Republican," Mr. Fleischer said, "particularly the image of Republicans that Bill Clinton tried to create, which was heartless and not focused on the human condition."
Far from tacking right and left in search of political gain, Mr. Fleischer said, the president has shown consistency.
"Look at the ruling on Michigan," he said, referring to Mr. Bush's Supreme Court brief last week on the affirmative action case. "All you needed to do was to look at his record as governor of Texas: diversity without quotas."

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Vivendi's Chief And Partner Spar Over Asset Sale

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
The honeymoon may be waning for Jean-Rene Fourtou, the chief executive of Vivendi Universal, and Barry Diller, the media mogul in charge of the company's entertainment businesses.
 When Mr. Fourtou announced his new strategy for Vivendi in September, he joked that he was on the best of terms with Mr. Diller, whose relationships with other business partners have often been tempestuous, saying: "I love him. He loves me. We repeat this to each other twice a day." 
 While the executives say they are still on good terms, tensions have erupted more recently over an effort to renegotiate a partnership agreement that gives Mr. Diller the ability to make the sale of Vivendi's entertainment assets -- namely the Universal movie studios, theme parks and cable channels -- prohibitively expensive.
In the event of a sale, Vivendi would owe Mr. Diller a disputed amount to cover tax liabilities. Mr. Diller has put the figure at $2 billion, people involved in the negotiations said, but Mr. Fourtou says the amount is closer to $1 billion. Moreover, a loophole in the contract might absolve Vivendi of any payments if the sale were structured in a certain way -- as a single package, for instance, rather than as separate entities, people close to Vivendi said. That interpretation, however, is at odds with Mr. Diller's reading of the agreement.
And that is not the only disagreement. Another one centers on $620 million that Mr. Diller says Vivendi owes his company, USA Interactive, which was created when USA Networks merged its cable, film and studios with Vivendi's entertainment businesses. 
Spokesmen for Vivendi Universal and USA Interactive declined to comment on the negotiations.
Mr. Fourtou is in New York this week for regularly scheduled meetings with Vivendi executives, including Mr. Diller, people close to the company said. Though not specifically on the agenda, the future of Vivendi's entertainment businesses and the unwinding of the partnership agreement are expected to be chief topics, these people continued.
Reworking the partnership agreement as a prelude to a sale of the entertainment businesses, either to a rival or to shareholders through a public stock offering, is a top priority at Vivendi now that the company has reduced its debt to a more manageable level. Net debt is expected to fall to 16.2 billion euros ($17.3 billion) this year, down from 22.4 billion euros ($23.9 billion) as of July 2002, according to Sanford C. Bernstein. Those figures include the 4 billion euros that Vivendi will have to spend to take control of Cegetel, a French phone company, from the Vodafone Group.
Several potential suitors have approached Vivendi about buying its entertainment businesses, either in pieces or as a whole package, including Marvin Davis, a wealthy oil entrepreneur who once owned the Fox movie studio; NBC, a unit of General Electric; Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer; and Liberty Media, the cable company controlled by John C. Malone.
But whether any of them will make a credible proposal remains unclear. Though Mr. Davis initially offered to buy all of Vivendi's entertainment businesses for $15 billion plus the assumption of $5 billion in debt, he has not yet secured financial backing. And lining up that kind of money in the current economic climate is no easy task.
Other suitors are interested in acquiring the best parts of Vivendi's entertainment businesses, not the more problematic divisions like the Universal Music Group, making any deal less palatable. NBC, for instance, has expressed an interest in Vivendi's cable channels, while MGM has focused on the film studios, a person close to Vivendi said.
Liberty Media, which is interested in merging its Starz Encore cable network with Vivendi's entertainment businesses, is a more serious contender and may have the support of Mr. Diller, who could wind up with an expanded role at the combined companies.
But because of Mr. Diller's reputation as a shrewd negotiator, Vivendi executives are nervous about coming out on the short end of any deal. And so they are keeping their options open, in part to exert some pressure on Mr. Diller and also as a way to place a value on the businesses should they ever be spun off in a stock offering.
Mr. Davis is expected to return to Paris at the end of the month for another round of talks, before a Vivendi board meeting. "It never hurts to have someone waiting in the wings," one person close to Vivendi said.
Even if a credible offer did materialize, any sale would have to wait until Vivendi straightens out its partnership agreement with Mr. Diller. And so far those negotiations are producing more questions than answers, people involved in the discussions said. One issue is whether Vivendi would be required to pay the taxes Mr. Diller would incur on the gain from any sale of the entertainment businesses.
In one interpretation of the contract favored by Vivendi executives, Vivendi would not be liable for those taxes if it sold the entertainment businesses as a single package. Mr. Diller's reading of the contract is that a payment would be due regardless of how the assets are sold, a person close to him said.
Vivendi does acknowledge that it would owe Mr. Diller some money if the businesses were broken up and sold piecemeal, but the amount of that payment is another sticking point. Mr. Diller puts the figure at $2 billion. But people close to Vivendi say the amount is closer to $1 billion, given that the value of those businesses has declined since the partnership agreement was signed in December 2001.
At least one discrepancy over the reading of the partnership pact has bubbled over into the public domain. In a December filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, USA Interactive accused Vivendi of withholding payments valued at $620 million, part of the taxable income of the entertainment assets that are supposed to be distributed to the partners at the end of each year. Vivendi disputes that assertion.

HEADLINE: The Axis of Oil 

 BODY:
With all due respect to President Bush and Congressional Democrats, this month's most notable stimulus plan for the American economy did not emanate from Washington but from Vienna. The recent decision by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to provide an additional 1.5 million barrels a day to world markets should help make up for the shutdown of Venezuela's oil industry, the source of 13 percent of America's imports. The move also signals Saudi Arabia's willingness to ensure the flow of affordable crude in the event of war with Iraq. 
 Beyond its immediate benefits, the Saudi decision is a further reminder of how closely our fortunes are tied to the good offices of the big producers three decades after the oil shocks of the 1970's. That the Saudis and other Middle East producers have had to come to America's rescue in the wake of Venezuela's political crisis is rich in irony. Venezuela was counted on as a buffer against disruptions in deliveries from the Persian Gulf. 
 America's current predicament -- it confronts the possibility of losing both Venezuelan and Iraqi oil at the same time -- is thus instructive on two counts. It provides another powerful incentive, if any more were needed, to tighten fuel efficiency standards and to push more aggressively for the long-term development of alternative fuels. Since the United States has less than 3 percent of the world's proven oil reserves, the only sure road to greater self-sufficiency is through reduced consumption and new technology.
The other lesson is that the importance to the global economy of the big Persian Gulf suppliers, especially the Saudis, has not been diminished, however much we like to regard ourselves as "buffered" by Mexico, Venezuela or even Russia and the other former Soviet republics. Like it or not, the Saudis retain as much leverage as they ever have over global energy markets. Their share of current output may have declined, but the Persian Gulf area still claims two-thirds of the world's known reserves. And because it commands the bulk of the world's spare capacity in the near term, Saudi Arabia acts as a central banker when it comes to oil, determining the market's liquidity. 
For now, at least, OPEC is helpfully trying to keep prices between $22 and $28 a barrel. It knows that allowing prices to hover above the $30 mark hampers global economic growth. But given America's thirst, even the cartel cannot fully ensure our economic recovery in light of the great uncertainty Venezuela and the Iraqi crisis create for energy markets. Fuel costs affect vast swaths of the economy, so at a time when it's anyone's guess whether oil will cost $20 or $60 a barrel six months from now, too many businesses are simply putting off any spending decisions. 
If war is averted, oil prices are sure to decline, perhaps dramatically once Venezuela's crisis is resolved. A quick war that knocks Iraq's two million daily barrels off the market for a time could result in a short-term spike in prices, followed by a steep decline as Iraq, home to the world's second-largest reserves, increases production afterward. A protracted conflict in which Iraq attacks its neighbors' oilfields would be likely to trigger another economic recession, with oil prices exceeding $50 a barrel. 
This isn't solely of concern to the West. China, with its mounting need for Middle East oil to fuel its economic growth, stands to lose as much as anyone. The fact that this once self-sufficient energy consumer will soon become the world's second-largest oil importer is creating an affinity of interests between Washington and Beijing, much as it does between Moscow and Beijing. 
One positive aspect of the current uncertainty is that it reinforces the need for Washington and its cold-war adversaries -- Russia and China -- to work closely together on energy policy. At home, it should also prod the Bush administration to address sensible measures to encourage efficiency.

HEADLINE: Mayor Girds For Showdown With Unions 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Kicking off a round of labor negotiations that is expected to be the toughest since the 1970's fiscal crisis, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has angered the city's unions by insisting that he will not grant raises unless they are financed by increased productivity.
 Mr. Bloomberg's demands have the city's nearly 300,000 workers also worried that he wants a wage freeze, and that has made some union leaders reluctant to cooperate with his efforts to cut the $3 billion budget deficit. Some labor leaders are also resisting the mayor's call for unions to grant $600 million in concessions as their part of the shared sacrifice to eliminate the deficit. 
 "The unions cannot continue to give back to the city," said Norman Seabrook, president of the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association and one of Mr. Bloomberg's first and most prominent supporters among labor leaders. "Every time the city gives us something, they want to take it back two years later. And every time they take it back, it just causes us to fall further behind the cost of living." 
The threats that the Bloomberg administration made two weeks ago to lay off police officers, since withdrawn, have also soured the mood of the negotiations. Threatening to further complicate the talks, the presidents of several unions say it is time to jettison the tradition of pattern bargaining, in which the city gives every union more or less the same deal.
And in another unusual twist, the municipal unions, which usually work arm in arm in confronting the city, are suddenly elbowing one another as they seek to claim their share of the shrinking budget. For example, District Council 37, the largest municipal union, has said that hundreds of Police Department desk jobs should be held by civilian workers rather than by the police, but that has the main police union worried that District Council 37's proposals are jeopardizing police jobs.
Despite the unions' anger at Mr. Bloomberg's proposals, Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers' union and chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, said, "People often forget that the unions have come through countless times in crises."
If the bargaining focuses on any one issue, city officials and union leaders agree, it will be the mayor's demand that there be no raise without an increase in productivity to offset it. In the financial plan that Mr. Bloomberg announced in November, he floated the idea of finding money to pay for raises by lengthening the 35-hour workweek of municipal employees and by reducing the city's pension contributions.
The city's labor commissioner, James F. Hanley, said, "The mayor has been quite clear that there will be no collective bargaining increases unless they have been funded through productivity."
City officials have proposed some ideas for increased efficiency -- reducing the number of firefighters on some trucks to four, from five, and giving the police a slightly shorter workday in exchange for 10 extra shifts a year. The police and firefighters have resisted these proposals.
Budget experts say it is hard to square the city's tradition of pattern bargaining with Mr. Bloomberg's push for productivity increases, which need to be tailored individually for each union.
Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said this round of negotiations could greatly weaken pattern bargaining, which she said was already undercut in the previous round. 
"Pattern bargaining is different from productivity bargaining," she said. "I think we're all moving beyond the pattern bargaining approach to one that stresses productivity instead. That would be a smart strategy for the city."
In the city's previous bargaining round, the teachers, the police, firefighters and librarians obtained larger raises than other unions. But their contracts contained numerous caveats -- such as requiring teachers to work more hours in exchange for more pay -- that enabled the city to argue that those agreements remained true to a basic wage pattern.
The teachers' and police unions are eager to see pattern bargaining abandoned because they recognize that the practice makes it harder for the city to afford to give teachers and the police the large raises they say they need to catch up with their suburban counterparts. 
"I've always thought that pattern bargaining was the wrong way for a municipality to proceed," said Ms. Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers. "I think there would be so much more innovation in how everyone works if there was more flexibility away from the pattern." 
But she added, "Anyone who rushes around and says pattern bargaining is dead for everyone is deluding himself." 
For city officials, pattern bargaining makes negotiating easier because once they reach the first settlement with a union, they can pressure other unions that it is only fair that they take a similar deal. That is easier than starting from scratch in negotiating with each union.
Mr. Bloomberg has taken a tougher stance than many of his predecessors by insisting that the city will not pay any raises retroactively. In the past, the city has often negotiated agreements two years after the old contracts expired. If the city gave raises in the first two years of the new contracts, the city then paid those raises retroactively.
But Mr. Bloomberg is saying that even though the contracts for District Council 37 and for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association expired on June 30, the unions will receive no raises for the months since then. 
That, union leaders say, is tantamount to a wage freeze. The Bloomberg administration has sought to justify that position by saying that since productivity gains cannot be achieved retroactively, then raises should not be paid retroactively.
The mayor's suggestions of a wage freeze have upset union leaders, especially because city workers accepted a two-year wage freeze in the mid-1990's under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"Obviously the city faces some tough economic conditions," said Arthur Cheliotes, president of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers Union, which represents 8,000 supervisors and middle managers. "Our concern is that if city workers don't get raises that at least cover inflation, they're being hit twice. They're being hit on wages and then on higher property taxes, higher college tuition and everything else."
Voicing the views of many labor leaders, he said: "You want to talk about productivity increases? First you have to deal with across-the-board wage increases to make sure our salaries are not eroded, and then let's talk about productivity."
Taking a different approach from other leaders, Lillian Roberts, executive director of District Council 37, has issued several "white papers" recommending ways for the city to save money. 
Noting that the city pays some computer consultants more than $1,200 a day, she said the city could save $25 million a year by having her union members do the work. She said the city's schools could save another $10 million by using municipal employees rather than outside contractors for pest control. 
"The city has to take a hard look at all this contracting out, because it wastes a lot of money," Ms. Roberts said. "The savings achieved by having city workers do this work could help finance the raises our members need."
Mr. Hanley said, "Of course, we'll take a close look at any proposals to save money."
Among District Council 37's money-saving proposals are to replace 300 teachers who work as attendance officers with lower-paid district council members. That has teachers' union officials protesting that District Council 37 is trying to steal jobs.
This is one of many signs of tension within the municipal house of labor. Indeed, several union leaders said that after the teachers and several other unions sought to go their own way in the last bargaining round, there is less cooperation this time.
District Council 37, which often negotiates the first settlement, gave its proposal to the city on Dec. 4. The city is expected to present its counteroffer when the two sides meet on Feb. 5. Separately, the city and the Municipal Labor Coalition are scheduled to meet on Jan. 28 to discuss the city's call for concessions.
Several union leaders said little had happened in the talks because everyone was looking to see what happened in the transit workers' settlement. That union accepted a first-year wage freeze, a $1,000 lump-sum payment, and raises of 3 percent in each of the second and third years. 
Like Mr. Bloomberg, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said all raises would be linked to increased productivity. But the authority obtained just one measure to improve efficiency -- the merging of the bus system for the Bronx and Manhattan with the authority's system for the other boroughs.
Mr. Bloomberg is clearly looking for greater productivity gains. But the city's unions will no doubt argue that since the transit workers gave little on productivity to receive raises, they, too, should not have to grant major concessions.

HEADLINE: Georgia's New Governor Is Pressed to Make Good on His Pledge About Flag 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
Sonny Perdue is in a pickle.
 The new governor of Georgia has all these big ideas: a fully wired state with high-speed Internet access for all; mentors for students taking the SAT; a saber-toothed ethics commission; more money for legal defense of the indigent. 
 But all the attention keeps coming back to same, single, stubborn issue: the state flag.
Since this is partly a pickle of his own making, Governor Perdue has been uncomfortable talking about it. 
During his underdog campaign, he energized rural white voters by promising a referendum on the state flag, which the Legislature stripped of its large Confederate battle cross two years ago.
After he was elected, Mr. Perdue, the state's first Republican governor in 130 years, went silent on the issue.
But last week, the day after he was inaugurated, he broached the referendum idea again. And now, in a recent interview, Mr. Perdue said a flag vote "is the only way Georgia can move on," though he would not discuss specifics.
"It's like a family secret," Mr. Perdue said. "The only way to heal this is with the sunshine of coming together and dealing with it in a very forthright approach. That's why I committed to a referendum."
Many analysts say that if the question is put to voters, the Confederate cross will probably return -- and so will the boycotts, the tension and the backwater image Georgia has tried so hard to bury.
"If there had been a referendum in Georgia in 1860 on slavery, I'd still be picking cotton," said State Senator Vincent D. Fort, a leader of the black caucus. "The idea that a referendum will heal the divide is ludicrous."
If the Confederate battle flag rises again above Georgia, it will be the first time since the civil rights movement that a Southern state has resurrected a symbol so painful to many. Some here say it could also crush the already-wobbly economy of Atlanta, the South's most prosperous city.
"We can't afford any more economic losses," said Denise Majette, a newly elected Democratic congresswoman from Atlanta, who is staunchly against a referendum. "We can't have this fester."
Southern heritage groups say the flag represents valor. Most blacks say it stands for slavery.
Mr. Perdue, who grew up on a farm in central Georgia, will not say what he thinks. "I'm not going there," he said. "I don't want to impugn the referendum process."
Yet he is well aware of the emotional impact. At his inauguration ceremony last week, he banned Confederate flags.
But he could not block the airspace. All morning and afternoon, three biplanes circled the sparkling golden dome of the Georgia Capitol, towing banners in favor of the Confederate flag. "Let us vote," read one. "You promised!"
Who sponsored the banners is a mystery. Two leading groups seeking a referendum, the Sons of Confederate Veterans and the Heritage Preservation Association, said they did not have the money to pay for flyovers, which can cost $100 a pass. The planes flew for hours that day and returned the next.
Charles Lunceford of the Heritage Preservation Association said his group was fully behind Mr. Perdue -- and mobilizing against potential enemies.
"Any politician who decides to go against Southern heritage is a target," Mr. Lunceford said. "People chose to move to this area. When they move to the South, they abandon where they came from. Would it be right for me to move to California and demand that they take the bear off their flag?"
The flag emerged as a key issue in Mr. Perdue's upset of the incumbent governor, Roy Barnes, a Democrat.
Two years ago, when Mr. Barnes sought a new flag design, Georgia was one of the last states displaying a large Confederate cross as part of its flag. Mr. Barnes proposed shrinking the symbol to a small box at the bottom. The Legislature agreed, with Mr. Barnes hailed as a skillful politician, a leading light in the Democratic Party and a possible vice-presidential candidate.
Meanwhile, Georgia's rural white voters seethed. "You can't imagine the anger," said Dan Coleman, spokesman for the Georgia chapter of the Sons of Confederate Veterans.
In the campaign, Mr. Perdue, 56, a veterinarian and former state senator, promised to allow voters the choice of which flag they wanted. Rural voters turned out in record numbers and sent Mr. Barnes away.
But then Mr. Perdue seemed to cool to the idea. "The flag," Mr. Perdue said, a few weeks after victory, "is not really the issue of the day."
Last week, though, while posing for pictures, he abruptly shared his plans for a referendum.
"I think the people of Georgia need to heal this," he said. "The best venue to do that is in a referendum."
Will the old state flag be an option? Who will come up with the designs? When will it go to a vote? The governor would not say.
"The importance is in those details," said Merle Black, a political scientist at Emory University in Atlanta. "At some point, Perdue will have to weigh in."
A recent poll by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution indicated that two-thirds of Georgia residents wanted a referendum. More than 50 percent of the respondents said they thought the Confederate battle flag was a symbol of "heritage and history," while a third said it was a reminder of "oppression and racial division."
Two years ago, Mississippi voters overwhelmingly supported their Confederate-themed banner in a referendum. Three years ago, leaders in South Carolina insisted that the Confederate battle flag continue to fly from the Capitol dome until protests grew to such a din that legislators decided to move it.
The Atlanta business community is dreading any similar scenes. Many groups, including the National Collegiate Athletic Association, have said they will not hold a major event in a state flying the battle flag.
"A referendum would be detrimental," said Bill Howard, a spokesman for the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Last year, Atlanta lost more jobs, 62,000, than any other city in the United States. The city, which relies on tourism, transportation and technology, was punished by the bubble burst in the high-technology sector and the downturn in travel that followed the Sept. 11 attacks.
"There are more important things we have to worry about right now," said Mayor Shirley Franklin of Atlanta, than "turning the state into a battleground over the Confederacy."
Governor Perdue is leaning toward a nonbinding referendum, which would still need the approval of the Legislature. Republicans control the Senate, Democrats the House, but there are white Democrats from rural areas who support bringing the old flag back. And some suburban Republicans who do not.
Mr. Perdue said the fact Georgia ranks last of the 50 states in SAT scores is "embarrassing" -- and an issue he would like to focus on.
"But you know who keeps bringing up the flag?" he said. "The press. At every stage of the game."
Mr. Perdue also said he did not know who chartered the three biplanes on Inauguration Day.
