HEADLINE: MY BROOKLYN; 
Landmark Towers, Still Loved and Lived In

BYLINE:  By WENDELL JAMIESON

 BODY:
The Tower Buildings and I first met when I was in the fifth grade at Brooklyn Friends School. This was the mid-1970's. My teacher, Victor Wagner, took the class on a long winter walk through Brooklyn Heights to Cobble Hill and halted our unruly two-by-two procession on Hicks Street, next to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. After some patient and not-so-patient quieting, Mr. Wagner -- in my memory he looks like the actor Abe Vigoda -- directed our eyes skyward.
 It was a fantastic sight to a 10-year-old: bright red brick walls cut at intervals by black cast-iron railings; semicircular stone stairwells you could see from the outside; pointed and square-topped towers spiking the sky. Mr. Wagner let us go, and we raced up those cold, echoing stairwells, a stampeding, shrieking, sweating, ascending army of private school kids. We flew down the breezeways, our arms puffed out in our unzipped parkas, dangling mittens attached, and peeked through the windows. The place seemed deserted, and a little scary. 
 Twenty years later, the buildings and I became reacquainted. During a frustrating apartment search, annoyed by real estate agents, I stopped at the rental office (the place didn't seem deserted anymore), and was soon climbing back up those worn stone steps, more slowly and more quietly, to the top floor, the sixth. It was tiring, but the one available apartment was a find: two bedrooms, two walk-in closets, a medium-size living-dining room, plenty of sunlight, $875 a month. And a view from the breezeway of the Statue of Liberty.
Never mind the other view from the breezeway, the one into our two front windows. My wife and I took it. In the five years we lived there, we never quite got used to our neighbors walking by and sometimes inadvertently glancing in. But we enjoyed another fringe benefit: the architecture classes that would gather in the courtyard, beneath the towering maple, the professor lecturing and pointing upward just as Mr. Wagner had.
Whenever I had a few minutes, I would stand at the back of the class and listen, and I learned that these buildings were one of the first experiments in socially engineered housing in New York City history, an affordable complex that gave urban workers in the late 19th century a measure of space, light, fresh air, security and, perhaps most important, dignity. They were not just special and mysterious to me, they were special to the city, and they had touched and improved the lives of thousands of people long before that motley class from Brooklyn Friends School came along.
They are now called the Cobble Hill Towers, but they were originally part of a complex called the Tower and Home Buildings. Since 1975, they have been owned by a man named Frank Farella, but he was aware of them long before that. In the 1940's, Mr. Farella and his family lived in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and went regularly to what was then known as South Brooklyn to see relatives. As they drove down Hicks Street, the youthful Frank would gaze from the back seat of his father's 1936 Plymouth. He, too, was taken by the latticelike iron railings, the pointed towers.
"I was always curious about it; they were so different than other buildings," Mr. Farella said recently, plenty of Gravesend still in his voice.
This portion of Hicks Street was a true commercial street back then, cobblestoned, not a service road running alongside the B.Q.E. The ground floors of the buildings, now enclosed with gates, were filled by small stores with matching striped awnings: a delicatessen, a candy store, a bakery, an office for a ship-cleaning company that serviced the big freighters docked a few blocks away.
As young Frank and his family drove by, they would have passed the home of a 12-year-old named Pat Drobney who lived with her father, mother and younger brother in a first-floor apartment. While the buildings may have seemed magical to a kid from Gravesend -- as they did to me, a kid from Park Slope, 30 years later -- they cast an even more enveloping spell on this young girl living in them.
Pat Drobney is now Pat Marren. She remembers scooting around the courtyard sprinkler in her bathing suit in summer and singing carols around a giant Christmas tree in winter. And she vividly recalls the complex's office, with its banklike counter where residents -- sanitation men, the owners of the deli, utility and shipyard workers, at least one priest -- would pay their rent at the beginning of the month. She can visualize this scene with remarkable clarity because that office was long ago turned into an apartment, and she lives in it now.
"Where I am sitting on the couch, there was an archway," she said. "And you used to pay your rent here, and we used to make cookies here. If you paid your rent early, you got 50 cents back, and at Christmas time you got a jar of jam."
There were a few gangs around -- Mrs. Marren remembers especially the Kane Street Midgets -- but the buildings were safe. She had friends on almost all the floors, but never ran noisily up the stairwells: "We weren't allowed, no way."
The family moved around from apartment to apartment, never leaving the complex. She married, and she and her husband moved to 14th Street in Brooklyn. For six months. Then they moved back.
In 1975, she met Frank Farella. He was then a small-time developer with several buildings around Brooklyn. "The guy from one of the oil companies I worked with told me about these buildings," he said. "He was servicing them, and his client wanted to sell. So I came down and I looked at them and I said, 'Well, this is an amazing property, but there are a lot of problems.' "
Of 244 apartments, nearly 100 were vacant; 11 had had fires and were boarded up. The courtyard was piled high with garbage. "You would walk into the courtyard, and you wouldn't know who's who," Mr. Farella said. "You'd find a gang of people in the corner who'd moved into a vacant apartment, squatters, undesirable people, dope peddlers, you name it. It was a mess over here." Not to mention visits by shrieking classes of fifth graders from Brooklyn Friends School.
The buildings had declined along with the fortunes of much of the Brooklyn waterfront. The oil crisis of the 70's made it nearly impossible to turn a profit from renting the apartments; the annual oil bill hit $80,000 (close to what it is today, 27 years later); tenants in rent-controlled apartments were paying as little as $44 or $60 a month.
Mr. Farella thought he could make a go of it. He made the deal on Oct. 31, 1975, and two days later met the tenants. They gathered at St. Peter's Church on Warren Street and welcomed him with hisses, curses and boos -- not only was the place a shambles, but there had been no heat or hot water for two weeks. He pleaded for patience but thought he would never get it until one elderly man shushed the angry crowd and suggested they give him a chance. That was Mrs. Marren's father, Joseph Drobney.
The empty oil tanks were filled, and Mr. Farella started making plans. But first, some research: "Everyone told me, this is a famous building," he recalled. "I said, 'Let me look it up and see what it is all about.' " So he went to the Brooklyn Historical Society, and that is where he learned of Alfred Tredway White.
The A.I.A. Guide to New York City (published by the American Institute of Architects) and the Encyclopedia of New York devote just a few paragraphs to White, but he was very important to those who have spent some or most of their lives in his greatest creation, even if they have never heard his name.
He was born in 1846 and as a young adult traveled regularly to London, where he was exposed to and intrigued by new affordable housing projects. He took the lessons home to Brooklyn, where, in 1876, he built the Home Buildings on the south side of Baltic Street, off Hicks. This was when Brooklyn was a city, and the bridge that bears its name was being built just a little more than a mile away.
The Home Buildings were really two structures, one on Hicks, one on Baltic. White next built the Tower Buildings -- three structures, one a block long -- across Baltic Street, on Hicks, as well as two lines of small brick row houses, which he called the Workingmen's Cottages.
The Tower Buildings are more elaborate than the Home Buildings, but the basic idea is the same: with the stairwells and the hallways on the outside, sunlight and air filled the front and back of the apartments, and the air kept moving, a change from tenements. Toilets and bathing facilities were in the basements. The courtyards were a haven for children to play in, away from the dangers of the filthy, packed-dirt streets crowded with rattling horse-drawn wagons.
"It was the first project in New York City, to my knowledge, that created a semipublic courtyard, a communal space," said Carmi Bee, a partner at Rothzeid Kaiserman Thomson & Bee Architects in Chelsea who teaches at the City College School of Architecture. He takes his classes regularly to White's project. The breezeways, he said, diminished privacy but eliminated depressing interior stairways, improved safety by putting more eyes on the street and "animated" the facades of the buildings. For children, he added, "they're like a jungle gym."
The little decorative details that White envisioned -- the repetitive patterns of bricks that look like miniature upside-down ziggurats, the bay windows, the arches over the doorways, the little tower with a base of tiles with wave designs -- engaged and intrigued the minds of the people who lived there, and made their lives better.
There were no housing programs or agencies in New York in White's time, but he was not just a do-gooder. His favorite saying, according to the A.I.A. Guide, was "philanthropy plus 5 percent" -- it was nice to help people, but it was nice to make a little money, too.
Mr. Farella saw that the man who had created the buildings 100 years earlier had given him a workable blueprint for refurbishing the complex. The restoration, designed by the architect Richard Henry Behr, began in 1978. The tenants played musical chairs: they were first moved out of the Home Buildings -- cold-water flats when Mrs. Marren was a child -- into vacant apartments in the Tower Buildings, and then moved back when their original places were done. Mr. Farella had to adhere to strict city guidelines because, he said, "it's a landmark situation."
It was impossible to install elevators. The biggest job was restoring the apartments to their original design: during World War II, with the waterfront economy booming and apartments near the docks in short supply, they had been subdivided, eliminating cross-ventilation. Mr. Farella brought the number of apartments down to 188, all with sunlight and air on both sides. 
In 1980, with all the other work done, the final elements were finished: the courtyards. "The most glorious day we had here was when we put the new lawn out," Mr. Farella said.
Today, he charges less than he can for the apartments, to keep a mix of people who he thinks contribute to the life of his buildings. Our rent was around $950 when we moved in 1999, and that was on the high end, a good deal less than some professionals living a block away in Cobble Hill's brownstones, paying $1,800 for a one-bedroom apartment. 
My wife and I shared the stairwells with retirees, nurses and interns from nearby Long Island College Hospital, freelance writers, an engineer for the city. We moved after we saw, from our breezeway, an interesting-looking condominium building being built on the other side of the B.Q.E. It took the movers all day to get our stuff down those narrow, semicircular stairs.
"The only reason people ever leave is the reason you did: they buy an apartment," Mr. Farella said. "Otherwise, we can't get rid of them."
These days, whenever I pass by the Tower and Home Buildings, I still gaze at all that iron and all those bricks. During the years I lived there, I never walked down Baltic Street without getting a frisson of pride as my home came into sight, lighted up like a Christmas tree at night. Then I would pass the windows that Pat Marren decorates for each holiday. Climbing those steps, sometimes two at a time, I wondered about the people who had come before, their boots slowly wearing down the stones.
And I took a million photographs: the view from the window in my walk-in closet, the wave tiles on that little tower, the pattern of the snow as it settled on the wrought-iron railings.
Alfred Tredway White was right: those little details really do make your life better.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Don't Worry, Honey. It's an Investment!

BYLINE:  By NICK MADIGAN

 BODY:
LIKE the faithful at a revival meeting, the frenzied crowd swarmed toward the stage of the vast tent in the Arizona desert, checkbooks flapping like fans in the stifling heat.
 From the lectern, a perspiring man in blue blazer and tie bellowed into a microphone, exhorting the devotees to part with their dollars. A pack of assistants, similarly attired, roamed the edges of the throng, crooking fingers, arms sweeping the air as if they were orchestra conductors, eyebrows raised in supplication. Whenever anyone came close to surrender, the men in the blazers pounced. 
 "Go for it!" they yelled. "You can do it!" 
The religion here in the Scottsdale sands last week was cars -- rare ones, expensive ones, the kinds of machines that prompt gasps even from the converted. The occasion was the annual Barrett-Jackson auction, one of the largest of collectible-car events in the country, with some 700 automobiles on the block in four days. About 160,000 people passed through -- buyers, sellers, collectors, dealers and gawkers -- many of them fervent believers in the lasting power of vehicular art.
"You want what your dad had, or what you couldn't afford when you were in high school," said Gary Lindenmayer, an auto appraiser from Chandler, Ariz., who has owned about 75 cars and who carried in his wallet a photograph of one of his favorites, a pink-and-white 1955 Ford Crown Victoria. "People here are recreating memories."
Larry Cate did just that, ponying up $38,000 for a 1967 Chevrolet Camaro convertible touted as an Indianapolis 500 pace car, red decals on its doors. "Anyone who does this had better have an understanding wife," said Mr. Cate, who is from Annapolis, Md., and owns five other cars, four of them Corvettes.
"It could be worse," said his wife, Dana, sounding resigned. "It could be women, or drugs, or gambling."
Founded three decades ago, when it gained instant attention with the sale of a 1940 Mercedes 770K for $153,000, the Barrett-Jackson Auction Company's annual event in Scottsdale, a Phoenix suburb, has become a mecca for the motoring world, a place where the serious collector and the helpless voyeur stand side by side, trading talk of Weber carburetors, Low Kar shifters and other esoterica.
The atmosphere at the show last week was a far cry from the deadpan decorum at Christie's or Bonhams, both of which hold regular antique and classic-car auctions. Bidders and gawkers -- almost without exception male -- crowded the stage, often blocking the view of the gleaming metal and chrome while the auctioneers raced along, pushing through 200 cars a day.
Their rat-tat-tat babble got faster as the dollars climbed, and they paused only occasionally, to let a pitchman extol a car's virtues. Successful bids earned whoops, yells and ringing applause, as when a sky-blue Corvette, which went to its first owner in 1957 for $4,601, pushed the bidding to $92,000 before the gavel came down.
This year, many buyers seemed cautious, despite obvious temptations. Bidding for Reggie Jackson's 1967 Ferrari 275 GTB/2 stalled at $340,000 -- he had wanted $500,000. Even the so-called star of the show, a 1957 Jaguar XKSS, one of only 16, failed to reach its $1.3 million reserve, the lowest price the owner would accept. 
Still, there were buyers for 637 of the 708 cars available, and they brought in $26.4 million, a respectable sum in a shaky economy. The figure is marginally less than last year's total, but nowhere near Barrett-Jackson's record year, 1990, when $37.3 million worth of cars were sold.
"They've had about a 30 percent increase in revenues since 1999, while the economy has been going the other way," said Keith Martin, the publisher of Sports Car Market magazine and a regular attendee. "So in spite of the economy, you still have a group of enthusiasts who can afford to spend big bucks on the fulfillment of a four-wheeled fantasy."
Overall, the collector car market has risen just about 10 percent in the last decade or so, Mr. Martin said, but only one segment of the market, American cars from the 50's, 60's and 70's, have experienced anything like a boom.
The highest prices paid last week at the Barrett-Jackson auction, which specializes in American cars from those three decades, were for a pair of 1967 Ford GT40 racecars -- one went for $347,760, the other for $318,600 -- and a 1966 Shelby Cobra 427 S/C, which went for $253,800.
But some of the bids needed help. A car from the actor Don Johnson's stable, a yellow 1970 Plymouth Barracuda that he drove in the television show "Nash Bridges," sold for a handsome $137,500 after the auctioneer, whipping up as much hysteria as he could muster, enlisted the help of Mr. Johnson himself, who had driven the car to its spot on stage, to sing its praises.
"That was about 100 percent over value," said Phil Hope, a Phoenix developer, as the auctioneer declared it sold. "It was dead at $100,000, and they really worked it. These guys are sophisticated, and they know how to get a couple of these bidders going against each other."
After watching a 1933 Ford C400 victoria, converted to a low-slung canary-yellow street rod, sell for $62,000, Michael Shelby, a son of Carroll Shelby, whose creations epitomized muscle cars three decades ago, said the price "didn't make a lot of sense." But he suggested that buying such cars might be a palliative in an uncertain economy. "Maybe these people need something to feel good about," he said.
At the height of the dot-com boom a few years ago, money poured into collectible cars, often bought by people too young to know much about what they were getting.
"The guys who made money in Internet stocks, they were buying four or five muscle cars at a time, paying $100,000 for a car that was worth $50,000 or $60,000," said Mr. Lindenmayer, the auto appraiser. "That drove the prices up. I like to see records broken, but the car had better justify the price."
Given the current state of Wall Street, bargain hunting was an eminently good idea, said Bill Mann, a vintage auto and truck dealer from Redwood City, Calif., who put down $45,500 for a white '57 Chevrolet Bel Air convertible. "It seemed pretty cheap," he said. "I lost as much in the last two days in the stock market as I just paid for that car."
But for car lovers, the fun and the spectacle at Barrett-Jackson may mean as much as the economics.
Richard Munz, a retired developer from Madison, Wis., who keeps 40 cars in a downtown garage back home, said he had been coming to the Barrett-Jackson auction for about 25 years. "You find the greatest cars in the world at this show," he said. "It's a happening."
He had stopped bidding for the star-of-the-show Jaguar at $925,000 (the auctioneer had started the bidding at $600,00, despite the $1.3 million reserve). "I can't let my emotions get carried away," Mr. Munz said. "There's a limit to everything."
For $80, any car lover could buy admission to all four days of the auction and could scour vendors' stands for high-quality jewelry, antique race car posters, vintage gas pumps and pedal cars, and life-size sculptures of American Indians on horseback. On the grounds surrounding the big tent, crowds trolled the columns of cars, reverentially peering inside, taking care not to scratch flawlessly painted fenders.
Inevitably, cars advertised with celebrity connections attracted hordes eager to get close to history: Jacqueline Kennedy's white 1961 Lincoln Continental convertible, one of three lent to the White House by the Ford Motor Company; Howard Hughes's 1954 Chrysler New Yorker, equipped with an air purification system to keep out germs; a 1965 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud III convertible owned first by Debbie Reynolds and later by Lucille Ball.
"All this is fantasy stuff for arrested adolescents," said Leo Brereton, a dealer in design drawings of prototype cars, as he looked around the bustling sea of car compulsives. "The American automobile is the vehicle people use to drive to the promised land. That's why they call them car nuts."

(Jeff Topping for The New York Times)(pg. F8); BELIEVERS -- At the Barrett-Jackson auction, a '61 Chrysler and a '70 Barracuda, right, won reverence as Brent Graves worked the crowd to push prices heavenward. (Photographs by Jeff Topping for The New York Times)(pg. F1)

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3814 words

HEADLINE: Never Say Die In Indie Opera 

BYLINE:  By ANNE MIDGETTE

 BODY:
A SPOTLIGHT clicks on and lights a cardboard sun. The seven-member chorus bursts into song as a singer costumed as a waiter slices oranges on the piano. The soprano enters with the tenor hidden beneath her skirt.
 Judith Barnes is rehearsing an opera at the Vertical Player Repertory, which happens to be in her apartment. 
 In a former factory in Brooklyn, in a room that used to be Ms. Barnes's sculpture studio before she got a degree in voice from Indiana University and returned to Brooklyn with the opera bug, Vertical Player Repertory is embarked on its fifth season. The high brick walls and tin ceiling have resonated with everything from Handel's "Alcina" to Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana." This week the room is full of the percussion sets, keyboards and hanging fabrics of the set of "The Dwarf," a new comic opera by Yoav Gal. (Final performances are tonight, tomorrow and Sunday.) 
It seems crowded now; it will be more so with an audience of 60 or so people for the performance, standing against the wall or sitting on cushions on the floor. Vertical Player Repertory is attracting an ever larger audience. At this rehearsal the piano is supplying all the music, which illustrates the humorous fairy tale quality of the story by giving its harmonies a sardonic twist. In performance there will be four instrumentalists. Mr. Gal had to reduce the orchestration from the original 25.
In small opera, everyone has to pitch in. The lead soprano is the stage director and created the sets. The composer is moonlighting as a costume designer. The opera is about a woman who goes around with her lover, a dwarf named Lingus, under her gown, and designing a bustle large enough to conceal Aram Tchobanian, the tenor who plays Lingus, seemed as much a source of pride to Mr. Gal as writing the piece itself. He watched anxiously as Ms. Barnes and Mr. Tchobanian tried it out for the first time.
"Am I waddling?" Ms. Barnes asked. "Maybe a little," said a chorus member. "I'll sashay," Ms. Barnes decided, suiting her actions to her words. Mr. Tchobanian shuffled along on his knees behind her, his toes peeping out beneath her gown. "Wear white socks," someone advised him.
Ask the man on the street to define opera and you're likely to get adjectives like grand, foreign, expensive. Ask a New York opera patron about opera beyond the Metropolitan and City Operas, and you might get a mention of the Amato Opera, the stalwart 107-seat theater on the Bowery that's been putting on tiny productions of classic operas since 1948. But none of these quite covers the broad spectrum of indie opera companies that produce fully staged opera around New York City in living rooms, church basements and city parks.
"Grand" hardly describes Ms. Barnes's Vertical Player Repertory, or Golden Fleece, a downtown outfit that has been presenting new opera on a shoestring for 30 years. But "small" doesn't really fit the New York Grand Opera, which plays Verdi in Central Park with a full-size orchestra. Or the Dicapo Opera, which has its own opera house (although with only 204 seats), a professional set and costume workshop, and an annual budget of $1.2 million.

Homemade to Professional
The range of opera companies in New York is astounding. The companies discussed here are only part of the picture. And that's not even counting troupes that present opera in concert: the Opera Orchestra of New York, Teatro Grattacielo, Pala Opera, New York Opera Forum and others.
The offerings run the gamut from the creatively homemade -- like "The Dwarf" -- to the crisply professional, like "Patience and Sarah" by Paula Kimper, a production by American Opera Projects that had a big success at the Lincoln Center Festival in 1998. Going to indie opera in New York can mean hearing the New York Grand Opera do Verdi in Central Park, embodying both opera's traditions and its stereotypes: bright, two-dimensional sets; elderly tenors in glossy wigs; big powerful music. It can mean sitting in a small space in the East Village for a sung one-woman version of Anne Frank's diary -- attic hideout, iron bedstead and all -- as conceived by Nancy Rhodes and the Encompass New Opera Theater. It can even mean taking in Beijing opera at the New Victory Theater, where the Qi Shu Fang Beijing Opera Company is presenting "The Women Generals" this weekend.
The only thing these groups really have in common is a devotion that keeps their directors working long hours for little or no pay year after year. In today's economy, it takes all the resources and energy they can muster just to stay afloat.
Why do it at all? "I wanted to maintain the freedom to satisfy my musical cravings," said Mimi Stern-Wolfe of the Downtown Chamber and Opera Players. Most directors echo her or Michael Capasso of the Dicapo Opera, who said succinctly, "A combination of passion and insanity."

Unusual Repertory
One of the biggest reasons for starting an opera company is that it lets you do the art you want the way you want. Whether they're conductors, composers, stage directors or singers, most founders of New York's small companies created them because they found no other outlets to do what they wanted.
For some, that was new or unusual repertory; for others, it may have been simply conducting. Vincent La Selva of the New York Grand Opera, a talented Verdi conductor, has somehow failed to establish a strong foothold in international opera; but his company got on the map and into the Guinness Book of World Records by presenting all 28 Verdi operas in chronological order. (It took eight years.)
Companies that present traditional repertory also see themselves as a training ground for opera careers. "We are in a sense on the precipice of the professional field," said Michael Spierman, a conductor who founded the Bronx Opera in 1967. (Its latest offering, Smetana's "Bartered Bride," finished its run last weekend.)
Mr. Spierman auditions young singers, many with experience in regional companies, and rehearses them exhaustively, paying them a small fee. "Professionals in the field come and see the shows," he said, "and often people are hired a few days off a production. We'll get a call saying, 'Who was that masked man, that bass-baritone; can I have a phone number?' "
Singers who appear with these companies hope that a Bronx or Amato Opera performance will be a step on the way to a promising career. The precedents are there: Mignon Dunn and Jon Frederic West sang with the Amato Opera; the Bronx Opera presented the tenor Neil Rosenshein and the conductor George Manahan, now the music director of the New York City Opera. And the Regina Opera in Bensonhurst had Dolora Zajick in "Cavalleria Rusticana" in 1980 and Mark Delavan in "The Merry Widow" in 1992. "They wouldn't have sung with us," said Fran Garber-Cohen, chairman of the Regina's board, if the troupe had not met a certain standard.
But these are exceptions. Very few people go on from these companies to truly big success. And there's certainly no guarantee of a review. If critics come at all, it tends to be for unusual repertory. So when Mr. Spierman takes the Bronx Opera to Manhattan, it's with the lesser known of his season's two operas. At Dicapo, too, it's the more uncommon fare that (sometimes) gets media attention.
With audiences, it's just the reverse. "Our subscriber base is very conservative," Mr. Capasso said. Many who subscribe to all four of the season's operas turn in their tickets for the one less known (or contemporary) work. (This ends up being to Dicapo's advantage, since it can resell the tickets to single-ticket buyers.) Even in Ms. Barnes's eclectic surroundings, which one might expect would draw venturesome souls, "Cavalleria Rusticana" brought in a larger audience.
Among the more traditional companies, one senses a certain jockeying for position: they're competing for singers, for reviews, for audiences for their own "Boheme." But among the companies devoted to contemporary work, the audience's conservatism helps create a sense of solidarity. "The more, the merrier," Ms. Rhodes said.
"These various companies are not competitive," said Richard Marshall, founder of the Center for Contemporary Opera. "They are willing to help each other, through sharing mailing lists or sharing promotion. We're trying to create a climate where people see these newer things all the time, so they aren't strange anymore."
To help foster this climate and a dialogue about creating new work, Opera America, the national service organization, is bringing together producers, patrons and artists in New York this March for four days of discussion and seeing new opera in the hope of encouraging new projects. Encompass, the Center for Contemporary Opera and American Opera Projects will all be involved. "Smaller companies are sometimes great laboratories for new works," said Mark Scorca, president of Opera America. "They're not bound by pressure to produce a subscription series, so they can give creative artists all the time they need."
Because major American companies have started producing more American opera, some smaller companies have changed their initial emphasis. Ms. Rhodes, for example, took up the banner of American opera with encouragement from Virgil Thomson. Encompass's first production, in 1975, was of his opera "The Mother of Us All." "He said, 'Nancy, I leave to you the mantle of American opera,' " Ms. Rhodes recalled.
Today, however, rather than producing extant American operas, she is concentrating on developing new work, which includes writing a libretto for a new opera with the composer Lior Navok.

Dreaming of Donations
Ms. Rhodes dreams of a more significant place for her company, starting with a home of its own. "If someone wrote me a check for $10 million, I know exactly how my theater would look," she said.
In the absence of such a donation, performance space is a problem. "The space ballet changes all the time in New York," said Lou Rodgers, founder of the Golden Fleece. Once a venue is discovered, prices rise, which put the Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts on the Lower East Side, where American Opera Projects used to perform, out of the company's reach.
And since the company books only one or two nights at a time, rather than a more lucrative long run, "theaters hate to get back to us," said Charles Jarden, the group's executive director, who had to scramble to find a theater for his new production, Deborah Drattell's "Marina: A Captive Spirit," which will be staged in May at the DR2 Theater in Union Square.
On the other hand, it was a performance space that inspired the founding of the Henry Street Chamber Opera (soon to be known as the Gotham Chamber Players). On seeing the Harry De Jur Playhouse, "our mission was clear," said Neal Goren, the company's music director: "To present distinguished productions of rarely heard intimate operatic masterpieces that were composed for spaces such as this."
By putting its whole budget into a single production, the company can attract more established performers, like the mezzo-soprano Beth Clayton, who will take the title role in the next production, "Die Schwarze Spinne," or "The Black Widow" by Heinrich Sutermeister, a Swiss composer. The company had a critical success in November with its last production, a double bill of one-act operas, "The Forest's Voice" and "The Knife's Tears," by Bohuslav Martinu. 

Renting Out Space
And for Dicapo, performance space is a significant source of revenue. Having created its theater in a church basement in 1995, the company now makes good money renting it out. Dicapo, of course, has both lights and piano; but there's one piece of equipment a traditional opera company doesn't need. "They come in and ask, 'Where's your sound system?' " Mr. Capasso said. "And we say, 'We don't have one.' "
In the matter of resources, today's weak economy isn't helping anyone. Heavily dependent on government support, particularly the New York State Council on the Arts and the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, many opera companies are waiting nervously to hear the details of next year's budget cuts. "The wonderful thing about being somewhat small is that we don't have too many people we have to lay off," said Jonathan Levi, co-founder of the Nine Circles Chamber Theater, whose "Art of the Fugitive" was given last week at the 92d Street Y.
Mr. Levi, at least, has a day job; he's the director of the Fisher Center at Bard College, a performing-arts complex that will open this spring in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Not everyone is in such a privileged financial position.
"It's a piece of the puzzle," Mr. Jarden said of his salary from American Opera Projects. That is the core of the income he assembles, as most freelancers do, from several sources: sitting on grant panels, for example. Some company directors -- Ms. Rhodes, Mr. Spierman, Mr. La Selva and others -- have teaching jobs. Some are married to people with more regular incomes. And some have recently lost their day jobs, like Jay Meetze, the founder of the Opera Company of Brooklyn: budget cuts eliminated his post as a music teacher in a New York City school.

Financial Risks
Mr. Meetze, a conductor, knows all about the financial travails of producing opera. When he founded his company in 2000, his mandate was to perform fully staged, high-quality opera productions. Within two seasons he had a $40,000 deficit.
Mr. Meetze contacted all the singers he knew, asking if any of them were preparing roles for out-of-town engagements that they'd like to try out in public (for no fee) first. "So many people responded," he said, "that I ended up with nine operas."
This season he's presenting two performances of each, in concert, with piano accompaniment -- one for a paying public, one in a city school -- around New York. He has also set up a mentoring program, matching eight singers to eight students at the Young Women's Leadership School. This summer those students will form the chorus when Mr. Meetze produces all nine of the season's operas, this time with chamber orchestra, as the New York City Summer Opera Festival.
Meanwhile, Mr. Meetze beefed up his board to nine members, and they're embarking on a $500,000 capital campaign. Next season he plans to offer staged opera again: 10 productions culminating in a second summer festival.
For most people who found small opera companies, the company turns out to be an end in itself. But the size of the company doesn't reflect the size of the dreams -- whether you've been at it three years, like Mr. Meetze, or almost 30, like Ms. Rhodes. "Jimmy is loosening his reins up there because of his many responsibilities," Mr. Meetze said of James Levine and the Metropolitan Opera. "Down the road, when I have more experience, I wouldn't mind taking that over."

A Labor of Love That's Its Own Reward

HEADLINE: Berlin Journal; 
Starved for Cash and With 3 Opera Houses to Feed

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: BERLIN 

 BODY:
Wielding flowcharts like a rapier and his ledger book like a shield, Thilo Sarrazin was ready for the first round of wage negotiations with Germany's largest labor union.
 Mr. Sarrazin is the top financial official in Berlin, a city of soaring ambitions that have fallen to earth in recent years. The restored German capital, he never tires of noting, is buried under debt -- in fact, it should have gone bankrupt years ago. 
 It is Mr. Sarrazin's job to tell Berliners that they can no longer afford their state-subsidized luxuries: three opera houses, two zoos and 150,000 city workers where 100,000 would do.
Berlin is demanding that the union's rank and file accept a four-year wage freeze. The union, having extracted a much richer deal from the federal government, says Berlin's penury should not be passed on to its garbage collectors, kindergarten teachers and bus conductors.
There is talk of a strike in February. 
"So what?" said Mr. Sarrazin, as he shut his briefcase and headed for battle. "If they go on strike, I'll save a lot of money."
By day's end, the negotiations had collapsed.
Berlin was in trouble even before the German economy ran out of steam, hobbled by grandiose building projects, a stunted industrial base and a bloated public sector. Red ink was tolerated at first as a legacy of Germany's reunification, later as the price of having a proper capital after decades of the West being ruled from cozy, provincial Bonn and the East from only eastern Berlin.
But the economic malaise has turned the city's finances from red to angry purple. With public debt of $49 billion -- projected to rise to more than $60 billion by 2006 -- Berlin resembles not so much the New York City of 1975 but a debt-ridden Latin American country of today.
On a per capita basis, said Mr. Sarrazin, Berlin's debt is more than double that of Argentina.
"I say it as a joke, but with a purpose," he said.
Last November, Berlin appealed to the federal government for help. But the finance minister, Hans Eichel, has his own troubles. The European Union recently scolded Germany for running too high a budget deficit. So he said no.
Yet people here still expect the German government ultimately to bail out Berlin, even if the city has to go to court.
That makes Mr. Sarrazin a lonely crusader for spending cuts. He brandishes charts that show Berlin's debt spiking upward in an ugly zigzag. But they have little impact.
"This system cannot be reformed," said Markus C. Kerber, an expert on municipal finance at the Technical University of Berlin. "You've got a combination of West Berlin socialism and East Berlin Communism."
In the fall of 2002, Berlin throbbed with rumors that budget cuts would force a merger or the closing of one of its three opera houses. After fierce lobbying, the city agreed to leave all three open, but cut their financing.
Among prominent cultural institutions, only the Berlin Philharmonic has raised money aggressively from private sources. Nor are Berliners willing to shoulder a greater burden in supporting culture.
"Berlin has a very sophisticated audience, but no one wants to pay for extremely expensive tickets," said Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, former general manager of the Philharmonic.
Few places symbolize Berlin's financial plight better than the Palace of the Republic, a monstrous pile erected by the East German Communists. Parliament voted in the summer of 2002 to tear down the building and rebuild the Prussian king's palace, which once stood on the site. With no money for construction, it continues to blight the city center. 
Berlin is not the only German city in a financial hole. Hamburg and Munich face budget cuts and mushrooming debt. In Frankfurt, the once-wealthy financial hub, tax revenue from companies has plummeted by more than $400 million since 2000. 
But Berlin's problem is more basic, said the mayor of Frankfurt, Petra Roth. To establish a self-supporting local economy, Berlin needs to develop an industrial base and an international profile.
"Germany should have a powerful, wealthy and vivid capital city," Ms. Roth said. "It needs to attract a lot of institutions, like the European Central Bank." Lest anybody get the wrong idea, she added, "My job as mayor of Frankfurt is to make sure it doesn't get them."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Palace of the Republic, from the Communist era, right, still blights Berlin, symbolizing the city's financial predicament. The Protestant Cathedral is at left. Thilo Sarrazin, below, is the top financial officer. (Photographs by Otto Pohl for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Rise; Economic Indicators Improve 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose by 18,000 last week, the Labor Department reported today. But a prominent gauge of economic activity by an industry research group was more promising.
 The group, the Conference Board, reported that its index of leading economic indicators rose by 0.1 percent in December, to 111.3, lending support to the view that the economy would perform better this year than last. While the increase was small, it was the third consecutive gain and followed advances of 0.5 percent in November and 0.2 percent in October. 
 The Conference Board's chief economist, Ken Goldstein, said the series of positive readings suggested "that the economy might turn in a better performance in the first quarter of 2003 than it did in the second half of last year."
The Labor Department, though, reported that the number of Americans filing initial claims for jobless benefits rose to 381,000 last week, up from a revised figure of 363,000 the previous week. Economists had been predicting a rise in jobless claims, given that claims declined by an unexpectedly large 30,000 the previous week.
The four-week moving average of jobless claims, which helps to smooth out weekly variations, ebbed last week to 386,500, from 388,500 the week before, reaching the lowest level since late November.
The Labor Department reported early this month that the nation's jobless rate remained at an eight-year high of 6 percent in December. Some analysts are predicting that the unemployment rate will reach a high around 6.5 percent in early summer before an expected period of economic growth generates jobs.
Labor Department economists cautioned that this week's 18,000 increase in jobless claims could be revised significantly next week because it was based on more estimates than usual because the holiday on Monday provided less time to collect data.

PERSON: Marvin Bower 

HEADLINE: Marvin Bower, 99; Built McKinsey & Co. 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Marvin Bower, whose leadership of McKinsey & Company turned the business of selling management advice into a keystone of American corporate culture, died on Wednesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 99.
 McKinsey was a small engineering and accounting firm in Chicago in the 1930's when Mr. Bower, abandoning his Cleveland law practice, went to work there. In the decades that followed, he helped McKinsey -- and through McKinsey the entire management consulting field -- to grow beyond the skepticism of those who called it a racket and into a serious and substantive industry. 
 Today, McKinsey advises 100 of the world's 150 biggest companies. Business Week magazine in 1987 termed Mr. Bower and Edwin B. Booz, founder of Booz Allen Hamilton, the two people most responsible for the growth of management consulting after World War II.
Jack Sweeney, editor in chief of Consulting Magazine, said business historians routinely hail Mr. Bower as "the father of the consulting profession."
Mr. Bower has been credited with taking a fledgling industry and setting its course not only as to the kinds of services it could sell but also the standards it must uphold for its work to be respected.
He displayed something of a passion for niceties. He insisted that McKinsey be called a firm, never a company. Jobs were engagements and the firm had a practice, not a business. Employees for many years were required to wear hats.
Mr. Bower's approach, beginning with common sense, was supercharged with the input of the brightest graduates of Harvard Business School, whom he preferred to long-serving executives. McKinsey's business grew beyond giving advice on far-reaching corporate reorganizations to the likes of General Motors and General Electric, in time advising Germany on how to rebuild the economy after the fall of the Berlin Wall. A current assignment is advising United Airlines, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, on how best to restructure its service and fares to remain competitive.
Mr. Bower stressed integrity. Consultants, he maintained, must always put the interests of a client ahead of McKinsey's own revenue. They were to do only work that was necessary and that they could do well.
He had the title of managing director from 1950 to 1967, and stayed on for many more years. In 1993, at the last of a series of retirement dinners, a colleague, Jack Crowley, recalled a meeting in which the head of the client company bellowed argumentatively. Mr. Bower told the executive that his company's problem was its top leadership.
"There was deathly silence," Mr. Crowley said. "It happened to be totally accurate. That was the end of our work with that client, but it didn't bother Marvin."
Mr. Bower was born in Cincinnati on Aug. 1, 1903, and grew up in Cleveland, where his family moved when he was a child. He went to public schools there and graduated from Brown University in 1925.
At that time, he had no fixed idea of how he wanted to make a living. His father, who was deputy recorder of Cuyahoga County, persuaded him to study law.
In 1927, he married the former Helen M. McLaughlin, who worked to help him through Harvard Law School and then Harvard Business School. She died in 1985, and Mr. Bower married Clothilde de Veze Stewart three years later. She died in 1999, as did Mr. Bower's son Peter. 
After graduating from Harvard Business School in 1930, Mr. Bower was hired by the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Cleveland. The firm assigned him to serve as secretary of a number of committees of the bondholders of troubled companies.
"No one asked why these companies failed -- or how much earning power the new bonds could support," Mr. Bower said in an interview with MBA magazine quoted in Investor's Business Daily in 2000.
In 1933, he secured an interview with James O. McKinsey, a former University of Chicago professor who had started a firm of accountants and engineers in 1926. He liked Mr. Bower's ideas about a professional management firm and offered him a job.
In 1937, when Mr. McKinsey died of pneumonia at 48, Mr. Bower and another senior partner, A. T. Kearney, disagreed over how to run the firm. Mr. Kearney kept the Chicago office and eventually named it after himself -- A. T. Kearney & Company. Mr. Bower named the New York firm for his departed partner.
He persuaded his colleagues not to follow other consulting firms' lead in selling themselves to other companies or public shareholders. His strongest argument was made by example: he sold his own shares back to the firm at book value when he turned 60 -- far less than he could have received on the open market. In essence, Mr. Bower considered McKinsey too good to sell.
"Would the Vatican go public?" asked Forbes magazine in an article about McKinsey in 1987. "The First Marine Division?"
Not that Mr. Bower did not embrace change. In the early 1960's, he recognized that offices had become less formal. So he showed up for work without a hat, becoming the first to break his own rule.
Mr. Bower is survived by his sons Richard, of Bronxville, N.Y., and James, of Providence, R.I.; six grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: U.S. Role in the World Dominates Economic Talks as Brazilian Clamors to Be Heard 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
In private banter and public pronouncements, the United States today dominated the first day of the World Economic Forum here. But it sometimes seemed as if the politicians and captains of industry meeting here were talking about two totally different countries.
 There is the United States that is massing for war -- a superpower feared and resented in many parts of the world, to judge by the mood in this Alpine village-turned-talk-shop. But there is also the United States with an economic engine on which the world is depending to regain its prosperity. 
 Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia was loudly applauded after he noted that public sentiment around the world had turned sharply against the United States over its handling of Iraq.
"You cannot trust someone who says, 'You will go along with other people, but if they don't want to follow, you will go on your own,' " said Dr. Mahathir, who was once one of the staunchest supporters among Muslim leaders of the Bush administration's campaign against terrorism.
"The level of trust has diminished somewhat," he said. "And lately, I think it has reached a very low level indeed."
In a later interview, Dr. Mahathir contended that "the whole world" rejects a possible war in Iraq. He said the Bush administration's apparent determination to "go it alone" if the United Nations did not mandate military action had eroded most of the good will built up by the United States overseas.
"In many instances, people express a dislike for America, maybe to some degree, you may call it hate," he said.
But Malaysia has thrived in part because of American-built semiconductor factories and other investments. The chairman of DuPont, Charles O. Holliday Jr., who sat on a panel with Dr. Mahathir, pointedly reminded him that Mr. Holliday's chemical company had a plant there.
The importance of the United States to the global economy, whatever its politics, was a recurring theme here. Several economists and businessmen said Europe and Asia would remain in the doldrums as long as a recovery in the United States did not gain momentum. 
"There are no other engines," said Robert A. Mundell, a Columbia University economist who was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1999. "Japan will take longer to recover from the downturn than the U.S. has. And the rise of the euro will dent exports in Europe, which is the only strong part of their economies."
Professor Mundell worries that the United States will not rebound powerfully enough to pull the world with it.
"We'll keep going along sluggishly, but that's not enough for the U.S. to be the motor of the global economy," he said.
The prospect of a war further complicates matters. Oddly, given its prominence in political discussions, the potential effect of an Iraq war on the global economy figured relatively little in the day's panels.
Some economists said this reflected the difficulty of calculating how such an unpredictable event would affect oil prices, markets and the confidence of consumers. But a few tried anyway.
"If oil goes to $38 or $40 a barrel, we'll have another recession," said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley. "If an economy is growing vigorously, it can withstand a shock. If it is barely growing, the shock can be the straw that breaks the camel's back."
In his rounds today, Mr. Roach said he heard little discussion about how other countries could contribute to global growth. The role of the United States as a prime mover, he said, seems to be taken for granted.
"The U.S. gets criticized for behaving unilaterally," he added. "That's fine, but if you have any better answers, let's hear them."
The isolation of the United States seemed starkest during Dr. Mahathir's remarks. To some extent, he was playing a traditional role of provocateur. In 1999, he raised eyebrows by discussing how a cabal of Jewish financiers, led by George Soros, had ruined Malaysia's economy.
This time, however, his message resonated with the audience, which applauded him like an elder statesman.
Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, gamely argued the White House's position. But even he conceded that the United States had not done a good job of explaining its goals to the world.
The former archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. George Carey, seemed to speak for many here, saying, "I would be profoundly concerned if my country was so disdained in some parts of the world."

HEADLINE: Grupo Mexico Faces Debt And Striking Copper Miners 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH MALKIN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
Grupo Mexico thought it was seizing its big chance to step up into the ranks of the giant multinationals, a rare feat for a Mexican company, when it bought an American rival, Asarco, in October 1999.
 The deal made Grupo Mexico the third-largest copper producer in the world -- but at a terrible moment, when copper prices were falling into a deep slump; they have still not recovered. The company has yet to find a way to make its big deal pay off, and has meanwhile been hit from other directions as well -- environmental problems in America, trouble refinancing its $2.8 billion in debts, and labor strife at home. 
 Some 1,200 miners at its Cananea mine, about 30 miles south of the Arizona border, walked off the job this week, demanding a raise of 5.25 percent that they say they have been owed since last year, plus productivity bonuses. 
The Mexican government stepped in late today to mediate between the company and the union, while a labor court considers whether the strike is legal and whether the company violated the current contract. A ruling could come as soon as Monday.
"The company has always been very reluctant to negotiate," said Juan Escamilla Ortega, an official of the National Miners' and Metalworkers' Union. 
Indeed, the company has taken a hard line, threatening on Tuesday to close the Cananea mine, which produces 150,000 tons of copper a year, if the workers stayed out. News of the threat helped push Grade 1 copper for March delivery up to 77.3 cents a pound in New York trading, the highest in six months; it retreated slightly to 77 cents a pound today. 
The company made a similar threat when workers struck for a week last June, and prices spiked then, too, topping 80 cents a pound. That strike ended with a pay agreement, but other issues remained unsettled, and they now figure in the new strike.
The company has continued to invest in the mine, which is more than a century old. A bloody 1906 strike at the mine, then American-owned, made Cananea an enduring symbol for the Mexican labor movement. 
"Over time, a series of strikes is not positive for morale," said Joe Bormann, Latin America credit analyst at Fitch Ratings in Chicago.
Juan Rebolledo, Grupo Mexico's vice president for international affairs, said in an interview today that "in the right conditions, Cananea could produce well." But Cananea's miners are already the highest paid in Mexico, he said, and the cost to produce a pound of copper at the mine is now higher than the selling price of the copper. "The specific conditions are bad," he said of the mine's current economics. "If you add to that very intense labor activism, then you have a problem."
Even when prices shoot up in response to labor problems or other disruptions, though, they remain much lower than Grupo Mexico was counting on when it bought Asarco for $1.2 billion; it also assumed $1 billion in debts. 
Many analysts thought at the time that Grupo Mexico's chief executive, German Larrea, was taking a smart calculated risk, gambling on his company's proven cost-cutting acumen to turn Asarco around. And they applauded the prize that came with Asarco -- a 54 percent stake in Southern Peru Copper, one of the world's lowest-cost producers.
"The whole trouble for Grupo Mexico is related to the fact that the copper industry is downtrodden," Mr. Bormann said. "Since the acquisition, copper prices have hovered around 71 or 72 cents, which has made it difficult for them to ever generate the cash to repay debt." Through much of the 1990's, Grade 1 copper sold for more than $1 a pound. 
Aside from the strike, debt repayment is the company's most pressing problem. The Asarco unit faces a Jan. 31 deadline for payment on a $450 million syndicated loan, and a $100 million bond issue coming due shortly thereafter. Grupo Mexico wants to finance these payments by having Asarco sell the Southern Peru stake to another of Grupo Mexico subsidiaries.
But the United States Department of Justice objected, and filed suit to stop the sale. The deal, officials said, would strip Asarco of its most valuable asset, one it needs to be able to avoid bankruptcy as it faces hundreds of millions of dollars in environmental cleanup costs at closed sites in the United States. 
Mr. Rebolledo said the company was making progress on settling the dispute. "We are optimistic that everything will fall into place at the right time," he said.
Even if the details of the Southern Peru sale can be sorted out, though, Asarco must still reach a settlement with American regulators over the cleanup costs. One analyst, Tom Meyer of UBS Warburg, thinks the total cost may come to $700 million or more if Asarco is found to be fully responsible at all the sites; an Asarco spokesman, Clay Allen, said that figure was "significantly higher than our estimates." 
Grupo Mexico itself is close to completing a deal to reschedule some $875 million in debts at its Mexican mining operations, but that will buy the company just a bit of breathing room, according to Mr. Bormann, the Fitch credit analyst. It is no substitute for what the company needs most: a sustained rally in copper prices.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
For Apartment Prices, It Wasn't That Bad a Year

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Resilient even in hard times, the average price for an apartment in most of Manhattan slipped only 3.4 percent last year, to $819,975, according to one major market survey. It had been $849,118 in 2001, a year in which the average price hit a historic high before being buffeted by the World Trade Center attack and the recession.
 And while the market did turn sluggish during the fourth quarter -- coming off a spring and summer during which the average price had rebounded 7.7 percent, from $788,256 in the first quarter to $849,013 in the third -- it still ended 2002 with a 15.7 percent increase in closed transactions, according to the Insignia Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report. Sales volume climbed to 9,093 last year from 7,858 in 2001. 
 Demand for small apartments and a slackening in the luxury market played an important role in lowering the overall average price.
Those findings were, in general, corroborated by a survey conducted by the Corcoran Group, indicating that the average price for Manhattan co-ops increased slightly last year (0.4 percent), to $700,000 from $697,000 in 2001, while the average for condominiums slipped a bit (3 percent), to $1,037,000 from $1,069,000. At the same time, sales volume in both categories rose more than 15 percent.
Given the recession and the attack, said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, the appraisal company that prepares the Elliman report, "we're moving sideways, which I think is pretty amazing."
Pamela Liebman, president of the Corcoran Group, said: "The market showed continued strength in certain segments, particularly studios, one- and two-bedrooms, while in the fourth quarter downward pricing pressure surfaced in the three- and four-bedroom market. But, over all, volume is outpacing expectations."
The Elliman report is based on 9,093 sales from Battery Park to West 116th Street and East 96th Street. That represents 85 percent of the market, Mr. Miller estimated.
With $819,975 the average for all apartments, the report found that studio prices jumped 24.8 percent last year, to $284,802 from $228,135; one-bedrooms increased 4.4 percent, to $429,840 from $411,633; and two-bedrooms rose 4.6 percent, to $1,001,708 from $957,805. The three-bedroom category experienced a 7 percent decline, to $2,523,248 from $2,714,216, and for four or more bedrooms there was a 16.6 percent decline, to $4,813,554 from $5,771,554.
Manhattan's price per square foot rose 2.7 percent last year, to $633 from $616, Mr. Miller said, and the average size of all apartments that sold declined 6.1 percent. "That means that a portion of the drop in the average price was directly attributable to the reduction in the size of those apartments that transferred," he said.
The historic high for Manhattan's average price, $894,617, was recorded in the second quarter of 2001. "That's when the market stalled because we were edging toward recession," Mr. Miller said. "The average price dropped to $849,194 in the third quarter of 2001, which included 20 days of post-9/11 when we had market paralysis."
The Corcoran report calculated co-op and condominium statistics separately.
With the average co-op price of $700,000 "virtually unchanged" from $697,000 in 2001, Ms. Liebman said, the average studio price was $218,000, up 6 percent from $205,000. For one-bedrooms the average was $400,000, up 8 percent from $372,000. The two-bedroom category rose 6 percent, to $854,000 from $802,000, and the average for three-bedrooms was $2,117,000, a 7 percent drop from $2,279,000.
In the condominium sector, with a marketwide average of $1,037,000, the average for studios was $332,000, up 12 percent from $296,000 in 2001. For one-bedrooms, it was $529,000, up 1 percent from $526,000. In the two-bedroom category, the average was $1,110,0000, up 6 percent from $1,049,000, and for three-bedrooms it was $2,330,000, down 5 percent from $2,462,000.
The Corcoran report, based on sales below East 96th Street and West 125th Street, recorded 4,488 co-op transactions in 2002, up 15.9 percent from 3,871 in 2001, and 2,528 condominium sales, a 15.1 percent increase from 2,196.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE FIREFIGHTERS; 
Oil Teams Recall Kuwait And Fear Iraq May Be Worse

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE

DATELINE: ELK CITY, Okla., Jan. 21 

 BODY:
On a scrap of windswept prairie 7,000 miles from the Persian Gulf, in a small office where two stag trophies gaze down from the walls, Ronnie Roles is preparing for an American invasion of Iraq.
 Mr. Roles is president of operations for Cudd Pressure Control, one of the three American companies that extinguished hundreds of oil well fires in Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war and have lately been in touch with the Pentagon about similar service in Iraq. 
 Like his counterparts at the other companies, Boots & Coots International Well Control and Wild Well Control, Mr. Roles is making sure that men and equipment in the United States and around the world can be sent to Iraq at a moment's notice. Bush administration officials and oil industry executives now worry that Saddam Hussein could similarly torch Iraq's oil fields if the United States attacks, just as retreating Iraqi troops blew up 700 of Kuwait's 1,000 oil wells in 1991, sinking the country into a months-long night of roiling fires and black skies. 
For all their experience in such danger, the firefighting companies say Iraq could pose extraordinary new challenges. No one in the industry has worked on oil wells tainted by chemical or biological weapons. No one wants to enter booby-trapped fields. And no one is quite sure who will pay for salvaging Iraq's vast oil reserves, the second largest in the world after Saudi Arabia's.
"Initially, the problems would probably be the same as in Kuwait," Mr. Roles said, "whether there are working airports, or water nearby to fight the fires. But with the fields there in Saddam's backyard, will he cause more problems with things like mines at the wells?"
A Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Dan Heplage, declined to comment on any contact with oil firefighting companies, saying the Defense Department did not discuss contingency plans or talks with private companies unless a contract is signed. "But it is part of our job to be ready for different situations," he added. 
The Bush administration says that restoring Iraq's oil production is paramount to the United States' long-term interests in the country and the Middle East. Revenue from oil exports would be crucial to reviving the economy if Mr. Hussein is ousted, and a healthy economy, in turn, would shore up political stability. So if Iraq's oil industry were damaged -- a possibility very much on the minds of American military planners -- companies that battle fires would need to get to the fields fast to limit the destruction.
"It's not unimaginable that the war effort would still be going on while we're in there," said Jerry L. Winchester, the president and chief operating officer of Boots & Coots, based in Houston.
Oil field firefighters make no secret of the thrill they get from walking into danger. Though the legendary Red Adair is no longer in business, the men who run this generation of companies are all his proteges. They are the rock stars in an industry that has become increasingly tame, high-tech and climate controlled. Yet there are fewer fires and blowouts than there used to be. Of the 40 to 60 emergencies that Wild Well Control handles every year, only about 6 of them rage into fires, its chief executive, Pat Campbell, said.
Kuwait turned out to be like nothing the companies had ever seen, and Iraq could be worse, executives said. When Iraq invaded, Kuwaiti oil executives who had fled into exile and Western well-control companies were able to work together in anticipation of the sabotage of Kuwaiti fields. Those Kuwaitis who stayed in their occupied country reported back to their old bosses that the Iraqis were placing explosives on the wells, Mr. Campbell recalled. The executives and the Westerners thought Mr. Hussein might damage a couple of hundred wells at most. 
In March 1991, when the first teams of firefighters arrived, they thought they had walked into a version of hell, Mr. Winchester said. "You're used to pulling up to a location and seeing one well on fire, not 80, and you know there's another 80 out there and a few hundred behind those."
The fires roared louder than jet engines. Smoke blotted out the sky. Oil pooled in lakes in the desert. Allied forces had bombed the Iraqi troops in the Kuwaiti fields, leaving behind thousands of unexploded cluster bombs that were quickly camouflaged in shifting sands. Escaping troops seized the earth-moving equipment the firefighters would need to control the wells. And there was little water to use.
Experts initially estimated that it would take four or five years to extinguish the fires. Instead, the job was completed in nine months. The firefighting companies, executives said, had some good luck and a great deal of help -- both of which could be hard to find in Iraq.
Iraq's fields are all over a sprawling country, Mr. Campbell said, with some in the swampy south or the mountainous north, where it may prove hard to ship the huge equipment needed. Kuwait's flat desert terrain made shipments relatively easy. 
As prolific as some Kuwaiti wells are, there are Iraqi wells that produce more oil. If they were blown up, they might be harder to control, and the oil spills from them more difficult to contain. "That's a big environmental nightmare," said Bill Mahler, marketing manager at Wild Well Control. 
Firefighters do not expect help from Iraqi oil officials. The Kuwaitis piped in water from the sea that the firefighters used to put down the flames. But many Iraqi fields are far from rivers and lakes; it is unclear where water would come from.
The Kuwaiti military, along with Allied forces, helped clear ordnance and debris, but the well-control companies are keenly aware that if they go to Iraq, they may well encounter great hostility toward Americans.
They have worked in dangerous places before. Mr. Roles recounted how the military in Algeria always accompanied his men to damaged wells in the 1990's, at the height of the country's vicious if low-grade civil conflict. But no one welcomes another layer of danger beyond what there already is at the wells, executives said.
"Our conversations with the government on this are very brief," Mr. Campbell said. "We say, 'Make it safe, and we'll be there.' And they say, 'We will.' But I haven't lasted in this business 30 years because I believe what some guy in an office says."
The Kuwaiti mission was very lucrative for well-control companies, Mr. Winchester said. The industry is unsure who will pay to repair the Iraqi oil fields -- the United States government, the United Nations or the Iraqis themselves once their fields were operational again. 
"I don't know, and I don't know if anyone else knows yet," Mr. Roles said. "The government hasn't volunteered and said, 'We'll pick up the bill.' "
And there remains the slight hope that Iraqi troops, while ready to destroy their neighbor's riches, would balk at destroying their own. "Saddam might blow up his own wells if he felt he had nothing left to lose, but the Iraqis themselves might not do that if they feel he is on his way out," Mr. Campbell said. "That should be everyone's hope. But for thinking that all that could not, should not happen, after standing in the middle of the fires in Kuwait, I can't really say, 'Never.' "

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE ALLIES; 
Europeans Try to Stem Anti-U.S. Anger

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
Cool down in Washington and calm down at home was the advice from Europe after continental tempers detonated over Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's dismissal of France and Germany as "old Europe" because they are trying to avert a war with Iraq. 
 Mr. Rumsfeld's comments to foreign reporters in Washington on Wednesday outraged both European politicians and ordinary citizens, who took the remark as example of America's growing arrogance. 
 "The only answer is, 'cool down,' " the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said today in Istanbul when asked for his reaction. 
President Jacques Chirac of France, visiting Berlin, counseled composure after members of his government took to the airwaves to denounce the American defense secretary. Mr. Chirac's spokeswoman said the French president wanted the debate to "take place with seriousness and calmness." 
The trans-Atlantic catfight raised Europe's already elevated anti-American sentiment another notch. Washington "continues to want to govern the world alone and more and more without rules," Martine Aubry, a Socialist leader and influential former labor minister, told France's RTL radio. 
France and Germany's opposition have prevented NATO from approving Washington's request for help in any conflict with Iraq, though most of the alliance's 19 countries are ready to do so. 
Mr. Rumsfeld said he thought of Europe as more than just Germany and France. "I think that's old Europe," he said. "If you look at the entire NATO Europe today, the center of gravity is shifting to the east and there are a lot of new members." 
The comment was seen as part of an effort by Washington to marginalize France and Germany on the Continent, though the two countries dominate Europe's economic and political affairs. 
"I want to remind everyone that this 'old Europe' has resilience, and is capable of bouncing back," the French finance minister, Francis Mer, told LCI television. "And it will show it, in time."

HEADLINE: A Measured Mayoral Message 

 BODY:
Delivering his second State of the City address yesterday, Mayor Michael Bloomberg did not needlessly pander, clutter his remarks with levity or pull a rabbit out of a hat. But on the coldest day of the year, amid a staggering financial crisis, he conveyed a sense of hope that New York City's challenges are surmountable. He pronounced the city "strong, confident and undefeated." These words could easily apply to the mayor himself -- or at least to the image Mr. Bloomberg sought to convey of a leader undaunted by dipping popularity ratings. 
 His remarks, delivered in the glass-enclosed Brooklyn Botanic Garden, were a candid if incomplete accounting of the city's legitimate successes and obvious problems. They were designed not to dazzle but to reassure, and were delivered in as heartfelt a manner as this disciplined mayor has ever managed. It was the right speech for the occasion. New Yorkers need reassurance right now. 
 The mayor cited, among other signs of vitality, the low crime rate; New York, he said, is the nation's safest big city. He also noted its continued hotel construction; the Republican Party's choice of New York for its National Convention; and the long-awaited realignment of the school system.
Mr. Bloomberg acknowledged that the municipal economy had weakened. But unlike last year, when he threatened to send his staff roaming through the bureaucracy in search of spending cuts, he didn't try to scare anyone. Instead he issued a measured summons to Albany, Washington and municipal workers' unions to give him the help he will clearly need to close the city's gigantic $3 billion budget gap. In specific terms, this means help in containing ballooning Medicaid costs and getting a commuter tax and more federal dollars, as well as improved productivity from the city's work force. He also asked the City Council to pressure state legislators by passing its own tort reform bill that could save the city hundreds of millions of dollars in legal actions.
Despite budget cuts, he said, he will not compromise New Yorkers' quality of life. And while he lacked the animated passion of his predecessor, Rudolph Giuliani, on the subject of crime, Mr. Bloomberg pledged new efforts to bring down sex crimes and to continue a successful campaign to reduce crime in the city's most vulnerable areas.
Without getting warm and fuzzy, the mayor expressed concern that the property tax increase could cause hardship for "hard-working people." He also promised improved accountability, including regular status reports on how he is doing on every project he has proposed. This could be useful in helping the public keep score. It could also make for handy reference in a second mayoral campaign.
