HEADLINE: Data Show Rapid Growth in Federal Budget Shortfall 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
New government data show that the federal government's budget shortfall has grown sharply in the last few months, even before Congress takes up President Bush's plan to cut taxes by $670 billion over 10 years.
 The new shortfall has already complicated the calculations behind Mr. Bush's budget proposal for 2004, which he is to announce on Feb. 3. With revenues sinking and outlays for the military and for domestic security rising, White House officials are searching for every possible way to trim social programs and muster support for their tax cuts. 
 In the three months from last October through December, the federal government ran a deficit of $109 billion, nearly three times as big as the year before and well on the way to setting a new record by the end of the fiscal year.
Administration officials have already conceded that the budget deficit for this year will be from $200 billion to $300 billion, not including the costs of a possible war with Iraq.
But other analysts think even that prediction may be too cautious. "The U.S. budget outlook continues to deteriorate," wrote William C. Dudley, an economist at Goldman Sachs, after analyzing the government's latest revenue data. "Our estimate of $300 billion for fiscal 2003 looks somewhat optimistic." 
Democrats on the House Budget Committee, hoping to upstage Mr. Bush when he releases his budget plan, have calculated that the shortfall could reach $306 billion this year, even if the costs of a possible war in Iraq are excluded.
The Democratic projections, which assume that Mr. Bush's tax proposals become law, predict that the government will run an unbroken string of deficits that would total $1.7 trillion by the end of 2011.
"This is not some hypothetical outline of what could happen," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the top Democrat on the House Budget Committee. "This is what they are pushing."
White House officials say budget deficits pose little danger, because they are small in comparison with the size of the economy. The best way to reduce the deficit, they say, is to reduce spending while cutting taxes to increase economic growth.
"There's a risk that deficits could be that large over the next 10 years if we keep on this course -- if spending continues at this rate and if the economy continues to underperform," said J. D. Foster, chief economist at the White House Office of Management and Budget. "It's precisely because of that risk that the president chose the path that he did."
White House officials have said they want to increase "discretionary spending" by 4.1 percent, but most of that increase would be in military and homeland security programs. Other domestic programs are being squeezed wherever possible.
In a move that could be interpreted as trying to get more bang for the buck, administration officials also unveiled a plan today to give federal agencies more freedom to reward particular workers with more pay.
The proposal calls for a $500 million "performance fund," which would be divided up among federal agencies and be reserved for pay increases to favored employees. The measure, which would require Congress to change the existing law, would partly offset the more modest raises that White House officials are proposing for federal workers this year -- 2 percent, down from 3.1 percent last year.
By any measure, the government's fiscal condition has experienced a spectacular reversal since 2000, when the economic boom and the stock market generated a torrent of tax revenue and a surplus of $236 billion.
In early 2001, the Office of Management and Budget predicted an accumulated surplus of $5.6 trillion over the next 10 years. By last July, in the aftermath of a recession and huge new outlays for the campaign against terrorism, the White House had slashed the projected surplus to $1.7 trillion.
The Congressional Budget Office, the nonpartisan agency that forecasts the budget outlook, will almost certainly slash that projection even more next week when it releases its outlook for the year. 
The Congressional agency's forecast will show only part of the picture, because its projections are based only on existing law and are not allowed to include the effects of President Bush's tax proposals, the possible costs of a war with Iraq or other costly measures.
Even without any of those elements, the budget outlook has gotten worse. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the government's deficit from October through December hit $109 billion, more than three times the $35 billion deficit experienced during same period last year. 
In October, a month when people make quarterly tax payments, revenues declined $33 billion from the year before and spending went up by $12 billion. November's deficit was slightly higher than the year before. And although the government ran a monthly surplus in December, which is common for that month, the surplus was about one-sixth what it was in the previous December. 
The latest data for January, another month for quarterly tax payments, is not encouraging. According to the Treasury Department's daily revenue reports, revenues from nonwithheld taxes totaled about $44 billion. For all of January last year, those taxes totaled $55 billion. 
Most experts say the biggest reason for last year's plunge in tax revenues, which declined by more than $100 billion, stemmed from the drop in stock market profits, executive bonuses and corporate profits.
But spending has continued to rise, mostly for the military and homeland security. Last year, total discretionary spending climbed 9 percent.
Democrats on the House Budget Committee say the long-term problems will not be solved just by a rebound to more normal economic growth of about 3 percent a year.
In addition to Mr. Bush's huge tax-cutting proposal, they say, the most recent proposal by House Republicans to offer prescription drug benefits to the elderly would cost more than $300 billion over 10 years.
Mr. Bush also wants to make last year's tax cuts permanent, rather than allow them to expire toward the end of this decade. He and Congressional Republicans also want to roll back what is known as the Alternative Minimum Tax, which is expected to take an increasingly big bite out of middle-income taxpayers over the next several years.
If one adds in all those proposals and about $85 billion for the cost of a war with Iraq, House Democrats estimate the accumulated deficit could hit $2.3 trillion by the end of 2011.
"Even before you get to those likely expenditures and costs, you have some pretty shocking numbers," Mr. Spratt said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about a worsening of the federal government's budget shortfall in the last few months referred incorrectly in some copies to the amount of surplus foreseen last July by the Office of Management and Budget for the next 10 years. It was $1.7 trillion -- not billion.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Yields So LowThat a Mattress Might Do Instead

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
FACING the lowest interest rates since the introduction of money market funds in 1971, many fund sponsors have been cutting fees to keep investors from losing money.
 Money market rates have sunk close to 1.25 percent, the target rate of the Federal Reserve for overnight lending among banks. Standard fees for managing money market funds of all sizes average about seven-eighths of 1 percent. This means that many funds, mainly those with hefty marketing expenses, are operating at a loss. 
 To prevent negative returns for investors, many sponsors have been forgoing or deferring at least part of their fees and sometimes dipping into their own pockets to inject cash into the funds. Some have bought distressed securities at premium prices to bolster yields.
These efforts are intended to avoid "breaking the buck," that is, to prevent the net asset value of shares in a money market fund from dropping below $1, a level that has been sacrosanct. But it could happen if the yield -- the market return less expenses -- on a money fund's portfolio of short-term securities turned negative. 
"That's the cardinal sin among money market managers," said Jeff Tjornehoj, a research analyst at Lipper, which tracks fund performance. He noted that this had happened just once, in 1994, to the Community Bankers U.S. Government Money Market, a fund with $82 million in assets that was available only to institutions. Its managers made losing bets on derivatives and had to liquidate the fund at 96 cents a share, so investors lost 4 cents on the dollar.
In addition, some money market accounts held within annuity contracts last year produced small losses of capital. These were recognized as less liquid than are traditional money market accounts, which are expected to return investors' capital on a moment's notice, and there has been relatively little reaction so far by investors.
With inflation negligible and the economy limping, the Federal Reserve seems to have no intention of raising money market interest rates anytime soon. But industry executives and analysts say that while skimpy returns are likely to persist, investors in money funds face little risk of losses.
"We expect all money market funds to maintain a positive yield," said Peter Crane, vice president and managing editor of iMoneyNet, publisher of Money Fund Report, which monitors the $2.3 trillion business.
Mr. Crane predicted that returns, after expenses, would settle at an average of about three-quarters of 1 percent in the next few months and that sponsors, while pinched, would not need to take significantly greater risks with fund portfolios to keep them in the black. For the week ended last Tuesday, rates averaged 0.82 percent, down from 0.84 percent the previous week. Investors poured an additional $6.95 billion into the funds during the week. 
Bruce R. Bent, chairman and chief executive of the Reserve Funds and a money market pioneer, agreed that investors' principal was not in jeopardy.
"It's not going to happen to anyone," Mr. Bent said when asked about the possibility that sponsors would let the share price slip below $1. "If expenses exceed interest, you reduce expenses." The John Hancock Money Market fund, like others, for example, has waived the fee paid to brokers who market its Class B shares. Some funds have gone so far as to put floors on yields, typically a quarter or an eighth of 1 percent.
Still, another reduction in short-term interest rates "would start cutting muscle" in the financial condition of sponsors, who would have to take bigger losses to preserve investors' capital, Mr. Crane said.
Mr. Bent agreed. "Rates have gone as low as they can possibly go," he said.
The lowest-yielding money funds are generally those with the highest expenses. "There's a nearly perfect negative correlation between high yield and low expense ratio," Mr. Tjornehoj said. The expense ratio of the John Hancock B shares, for example, is 1.39 percent, virtually wiping out any unsubsidized return to investors. Last week, the fund's yield was 0.11 percent. 
Some of the best performers are the largest money funds, which benefit from economies of scale. Those of Vanguard, TIAA-CREF, Fidelity and Scudder are among the leaders. Among these funds, the highest-yielding was the Vanguard Prime fund, with a yield of 1.20 percent and expenses of only 0.33 percent.
MR. BENT warns that managers of funds whose yields are flirting with zero may be tempted to become more venturesome to stay competitive.
"The only risk I see is if a fund manager decides he has to reach for yield in order to pay up," said Mr. Bent, whose company prides itself in avoiding the market for commercial paper, where defaults by Pacific Gas and Electric and others pressed sponsors to bail out portfolios. In 1997, Strong Capital Management bought Mercury Finance commercial paper from three of its funds to spare shareholders from a loss. In late 2000 and early 2001, Founders Fund, Zurich Scudder and Dreyfus were among those taking similar steps because of the California utility crisis.
Mr. Crane, for one, minimized this threat. "The recent trauma is fresh enough that a lot of people are gun shy," he said, alluding to the California crisis. "The No. 1 job for managers is avoiding headline risk," some disaster that the prudent could have been expected to avoid. Moreover, because money funds invest in short-term instruments, their funds must be rolled over often, limiting their exposure to any single company.
The greater, broader danger, Mr. Crane said, is that today's low rates are inducing consumers to spend their money instead of saving it, leaving them without a cash buffer against even a mild financial reverse.
That is the kind of atmosphere in which Mr. Bent and others are promoting what they say is the next money fund innovation -- adding the safety net of coverage by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by creating a banking unit and sweeping cash into accounts there. Features like debit cards with rebates for purchases and online bill-paying can be added to these accounts.
"That's definitely where we're going," Mr. Bent said, pointing to billions of dollars pulled into such accounts at Reserve Funds and various major brokerage houses, including Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup.
Others, though, are skeptical that this is the wave of the future. Mr. Crane said he doubted that there was huge demand for insurance coverage and said that while there had been an early surge of inflows into the new accounts, much of this reflected relatively high "teaser" rates that would not be sustained when interest rates returned to more normal levels.
Mr. Tjornehoj said that advocating insurance protection might send the wrong message to consumers. "It will give the sense," he said, "that their investment is not all that safe."

HEADLINE: Business; 
So Many OnlineSales, So Little in Tax Revenue

BYLINE:  By NORM ALSTER 

 BODY:
STATE officials across the country have been keeping their eyes on two sets of numbers, and it is sometimes difficult to tell which is growing faster. One is their projected budget shortfalls. The other is online retail sales, which they would like to tax to help fill the gaps.
 Forecasters say the states may come up short next year by as much as $80 billion, which would create the biggest state budget crisis since World War II. A merry holiday season in cyberspace, meanwhile, has pumped up the receipts of online retailers -- to $78 billion last year, according to Forrester Research, an increase of more than 50 percent over 2001. 
 That does not count the larger categories of business-to-business online sales and catalog sales, for which sales tax is generally not collected. A study by the University of Tennessee estimates that sales tax is not collected on $234 billion in online business-to-business commerce. And tax on most of what the Direct Marketing Association estimates at $125 billion in annual catalog sales is not collected, either. 
The states cannot currently impose the tax because the Supreme Court has ruled that their multiple tax systems would impose an unfair collection burden on retailers that do not have a physical presence in their buyers' various states. Online buyers are actually required to pay sales taxes directly to their states, but they rarely do.
If the states can simplify and coordinate their sales tax systems, they may be able to convince Congress or the courts that collecting the levy will not be an unfair burden.
"Collection of online sales tax could plug 30 to 50 percent of state budget deficits this year and next," said Frank Shafroth, director for state and federal relations at the National Governors Association.
An effort to overcome the Supreme Court's objections made headway last November when 33 states agreed to narrow the differences in their sales tax rules and to provide retailers with software to collect taxes.
"We have developed a simplified process for collection of sales tax that meets the criteria of the Supreme Court and the Congress," said Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a leader in the states' effort.
Maybe so. But it is not enough in the eyes of business interests that are lining up against online sales tax collection. Anti-tax groups, direct marketers and online sellers have long opposed efforts to collect online, but new opposition has emerged from broad-based business groups that want concessions on other tax issues in return for their support for the collection changes.
"Before Congress authorizes a mandatory system for sales tax collection, they need to resolve some outstanding issues," said Vincent Randazzo, director of public policy for the Business Roundtable, which represents the chiefs of 150 big companies.
The states are expected to seek a Congressional mandate to collect sales taxes after they win legislative approval for their new tax system in at least 10 states that represent at least 20 percent of Americans who pay sales taxes.
Governor Leavitt said that as many as 25 state legislatures would begin considering acceptance of the new system early this year. Neal Osten, a lobbyist with the National Conference of State Legislatures, said Congressional legislation could be introduced this spring.
Expecting a lobbying showdown, the Business Roundtable has already begun "to touch base with the big players in Washington," said Mr. Randazzo, who declined to specify the chief lobbying targets.
Business groups fret that state officials will use the information they gather from collecting online sales taxes to become more aggressive in seeking income taxes from corporations that have sales but no physical presence within their states.
"Once you have a system in place for identifying out-of-state sales," Mr. Randazzo said, "the states will have all this information they can turn over to their revenue departments and say: 'They did $25 million in sales here -- we'll collect income tax.' "
Some state officials see the linking of the issues as part of a lobbying strategy by big business. "They want to get their pound of flesh, and they see this as an opportunity," said Mr. Shafroth of the governors' group.
Opponents of online sales taxes have other complaints.
Amazon.com participated in the deliberations that created the states' plan but is not satisfied with the results. "There's not enough simplification," said Richard Prem, Amazon's director for global indirect taxes.
Christopher M. Kelley, a Forrester analyst, said collecting sales tax would have a minimal effect on Amazon and other online retailers. He said they could compensate for the higher cost to customers by expanding free-shipping offers, though that would cut into already thin profit margins.
MOST large bricks-and-mortar retailers support online tax collection, but Frank G. Julian, operating vice president and tax counsel for Federated Department Stores -- parent of Bloomingdale's and Macy's, which sell through stores and over the Web -- said the collection process was still too complicated.
Sponsors of the tax-simplification process wanted a single tax rate for each state, but that idea was opposed by local authorities and some local businesses that were unwilling to forfeit tax breaks. Some states, for example, exempt "essentials" like food and clothes from the sales tax -- though the definitions of exempt catagories varies from state to state, with some areas including goods like candy and belts while others do not. Some states, like California and New York, also let local governments impose sales tax surcharges that only apply in their jurisdictions. The proposed compromise allows three rates per state.
Multiple rates make collection difficult, Mr. Julian said, noting that Federated already spent "tens of millions of dollars" to collect $1 billion a year in sales taxes.
But retailers that have stores virtually everywhere see universal online collection as a matter of fairness. "We're required to collect it," said Wayne Zakrzewski, an assistant general counsel for taxes at J. C. Penney. "Our rivals should also collect it."
Tripp Funderburk, policy director for the e-Fairness Coalition, which represents big retailers like Target, Wal-Mart and Circuit City, as well as real estate interests, said that retailers' profit margins are so thin that "when you give someone a 6 to 8 percent price advantage, that's the government favoring one sector over another."
As online sales eat into sales tax collections, local authorities will have to make up the difference, Mr. Funderburk added, and many are already raising property taxes.
The information technology industry has been very effective in its Washington lobbying, and it is not about to forfeit a tax break that has bolstered both e-commerce and the computer, communications and software sectors that support it.
Walter Hellerstein, a professor at the University of Georgia School of Law, said the simplification camp would have little trouble lining up 10 states -- Illinois, Wisconsin and North Carolina should be among the first -- but he said they would need "roughly half the states" to overcome lobbying opposition in Congress.
Opponents of the drive for online sales taxes worry that the states may bypass Congress and simply take nonpaying corporations to court, arguing that they have met the Supreme Court's objections and are now allowed to collect.
"Congress has never been willing to stick its foot into the sales tax nexus issue, and I don't see anything that's about to change," Mr. Shafroth said.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Is Digital Eclipsing The Moment At Kodak?

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
AMERICANS buy 850 million rolls a year.
 For decades, rampant picture taking made Eastman Kodak, the world's biggest maker of film, an immensely profitable company. Film accounts for about 20 percent of the company's sales, but up to 50 percent of its profit. 
 But digital photography, heightened competition and the weak economy have cut into sales. And last week Kodak, which eliminated more than 7,000 jobs last year, said it intended to cut as many as 2,200 more. Investors, who have flocked into the stock the last year, unceremoniously dumped shares on the news. They ended at $32.08 on Friday. 
Benjamin A. Reitzes, imaging technology analyst at UBS Warburg, talked last week about the company's prospects. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. What caused Kodak's problems?

A. Film demand peaked in early 1999 and has been on a slowing growth and declining trajectory ever since. As consumer confidence began to wane in 2000 and digital camera sales began to become more meaningful, film demand began to slow really markedly.
Kodak has thrown out numbers that last year digital cameras cannibalized its film unit growth by three percentage points. I think that number is even higher, because digital camera sales have been even stronger than expected and sales of digital printers have been stronger than expected.

Q. Is film becoming obsolete and is Kodak responding rapidly enough?

A. We think more and more people are taking advantage of digital imaging. The biggest problem is that it is more expensive, it takes time and requires a good quality printer.
Film is still the best way to get durable prints, and Kodak has been outperforming the industry for the past three quarters in film. That is one of the reasons we were surprised by the magnitude of their struggles when they reported their results last week.

Q. How important are the megachains like Wal-Mart to the film business?

A. We estimate that Wal-Mart accounts for at least 20 percent of the U.S. film market. If you include Sam's Club, that rises to between 25 percent and 30 percent. The processing figures are very similar. In short, Wal-Mart is one of the most powerful companies in the photography industry.
One of the challenges for Kodak is that Wal-Mart has a contract with Fuji Photo Film until 2005 for providing paper, chemicals and supplies for onsite photo finishing.
Effectively, this deal keeps Kodak out of Wal-Mart in the United States. Kodak lost this contract in the mid-1990's, and it was one of the things that contributed to the company's problems in 1997.

Q. Kodak's stock went up nearly 20 percent last year. It was the best-performing component of the Dow Jones industrial average. Why?

A. The stock did well last year because of the major restructuring they undertook in 2001. We upgraded the stock at the end of last year with the view they would outperform because Kodak does very well when they get very serious about cutting costs. Also, we thought their traditional businesses weren't becoming outmoded as fast as others thought.
Those things helped to move Kodak's numbers, especially in the second and third quarters. And the stock also benefited from its high dividend yield.

Q. Last week Dan Carp, Kodak's chairman, said he expected the company's digital camera business to be profitable by the end of this year. Is that a realistic expectation?

A. They were supposed to be profitable earlier than that, but pricing continues to come down and there are a lot of competitors out there. This year they may meet that forecast because there is a migration to higher resolution cameras. But we have trouble envisioning this being a high-margin business.

Q. Are you worried about debt load?

A. I would like to see their debt-to-capital ratio trend down about 40 percent over the next year or two. Currently it is 48 percent.

Q. The stock price fell a lot after last week's announcement. Is it a buy at these levels?

A. First, I don't own any Kodak shares. And we have a hold rating on the stock. I have a $35 target on the stock, which puts Kodak at a level that is consistent with its traditional forward price to earnings multiple.

Q. What will Kodak look like in five years ?

A. You will see a lot more digital revenues and services. Kodak's future depends on its ability to enable its retail customers to process photographs from digital cameras.
Right now Fuji Film has digital minilabs that allow you to print pictures from digital cameras. Kodak has several products coming out in this area this year. But they are going to have to invest a lot in sales, marketing and promotion on the launch of these new minilabs.

HEADLINE: Before the Game, Bacchanalia XXXVII 

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Michael Irvin, the former Dallas Cowboy receiver and carouser, embraced the Bachelorette like a contestant the other night, clutching her tightly until he heard a familiar voice.
 "Mr. Irvin," intoned Neon Deion Sanders, his former teammate. "Could you leave that woman alone? More than 50 million are already trying to get at her." 
 In about an hour, the two former National Football League stars would make their way upstairs at the W Hotel, to a warm fire on an imported beach, where some clear, sweet, carbonated liquid called Smirnoff Triple Block Ice was being passed around liberally, and the bacchanalia of another Super Bowl week was about to begin. 
"It's already past my bedtime," Mr. Sanders said at about 9 p.m. "I don't go out like I used to. Nowadays, I just go home and go to sleep."
Nonetheless, he went upstairs. Mr. Sanders stood in front of the fire, his feet in the sand. On the W roof, one of those pre-pre-Super Bowl parties was beginning to grow with names.
Tara Reid ("American Pie") was there. So was Carson Daly ("Total Request Live"), who used to go out with Tara, but now they're just friends.
"We were engaged, but it didn't work out," Mr. Daly said. "Tara's still great."
O.K. 
Ms. Reid mingled with her good friend Pat O'Brien of "Access Hollywood," Mr. Daly hung out with his good friends, and ESPN anchors, everybody's good friends, milled about until they were recognized.
They came from all over this week: be-seen actors in need of upgrades in their Q ratings; professional athletes working the party circuit harder than they ever worked their games; sportswriters and fans competing for space and attention with more important people than themselves -- an amalgam of American party culture, crammed into a California seaport city. 
If the Oakland Raiders and Tampa Bay Buccaneers don't do it for you in Super Bowl XXXVII, there is always the Blue Tattoo or E Street Alley in the historic Gas Lamp Quarter. Or Maxim magazine's party on Saturday night, where the magazine has essentially turned San Diego's old Wonderbread factory into a community that would do Caligula proud. Did we mention the Playboy and "Girls Gone Wild" soirees? 
The National Football League can do nothing but blush and hope the revelry does not lead to an image blow like those from big games gone by. In 1999, the night before Eugene Robinson was to compete for the Atlanta Falcons in Super Bowl XXXIII in Miami, he was charged with soliciting sex from an undercover policewoman.
Today's Raiders do not exactly pay homage to the partyers of the past, people like the late John Matuszak, who two decades ago drank like a fish, showed up woozy at press conferences and once hired a look-alike to be in his hotel bed at curfew. Earlier this week, trying to find a party-hearty player scheduled to suit up Sunday amid the shrill of the Gas Lamp Quarter, a PG-13 version of the New Orleans French Quarter, was fruitless. In fact, you had to go back in time.
Marcus Allen, the most valuable player in the 1984 Super Bowl, was holding court in a bar called Magnet in the bottom floor of the W Hotel on Wednesday. Mr. Allen was eventually joined by Mr. Sanders, Mr. Irvin and Mr. O'Brien.
The next night, Jeremy Shockey and Tiki Barber of the New York Giants made their presence known, along with Terrell Davis, the former Bronco running back. Yes, Mr. Shockey said, he was going to the Playboy party.
"Hey, it's not like we sit around and think, 'Let's go to a party and look suave,' " said Mr. O'Brien, sipping a glass of cabernet sauvignon on a couch at Magnet. "It's the only thing to do here. Am I going to the San Diego Aquarium? I'm not going to look at some orca. I'm coming here."
"In the early 90's, it got out of hand," Mr. O'Brien added. He has made it to 22 Super Bowls. "You'd get four and five thousand at a single party. It was just too much excess."
But a struggling economy begets low advertising revenue, and low advertising revenue begets lower profit margins, and when all the trickle-down effects kick in, suddenly you've got a half-empty club in the middle of Super Bowl Week. The days of private helicopters and entire sales teams taking weekend junkets are dying, along with the multimillion-dollar parties.
On Thursday night, E Street Alley was home to the EcoBowl party -- a $170-a-ticket benefit that goes toward Ecolution, the pollution-education charity based in Los Angeles. It actually outbid Nike and Cadillac for the club. 
Ms. Reid was a host, along with another of the "American Pie" cast, Shannon Elizabeth, and Rosario Dawson, the New York actress currently starring in "25th Hour" with Edward Norton. 
Ms. Reid was wearing a very low-cut satin dress, with side slits. It would need another foot of fabric to graze her knees.
"Am I trying to get noticed?" said Ms. Dawson, laughing. "Not with Tara dressed like that. I'm in the background. I might as well be a bodyguard."
Ms. Dawson went on to say she was happy to lend her name and stature to a cause she believed in. "I know most of this week is about nothing particularly real, but if I can get some people to look at why they really need an S.U.V., then it's for a good cause."
She went on to say that making the rounds at Super Bowl week could have its downside on celebrity, too. "If you show up at too many things, people start to wonder if you're more about yourself than what charity you're promoting. You could do the organization detriment if you don't pick your spots. Oversaturation is bad. After a while, no one cares about your cause. They want to know who you're sleeping with, how long it took to put on your makeup and what dress you're wearing."
(For the record, Ms. Dawson wore a black flower-print gown designed by Diane Von Furstenberg. "She was responsible for the wrap in the 70's," she explained, helpfully. "I just thought it was sexy." No word on whom she's sleeping with.)
But it was Trista Rehn who drew the most attention. She is the star of ABC's "Bachelorette," a former Miami Heat cheerleader who was rejected on national television in the last week of the first season of "The Bachelor." As her revenge, Ms. Rehn now has a truckload of men to choose from in her own show. If the Match.com crowd was having a rough go finding mates on the Internet, poor Ms. Rehn has been looking for a husband on television for more than two seasons.
She was congenial enough, chitchatting her way through promotional interviews with local affiliates, careful not to give up any of her suitors. But her handlers were intent on scurrying her away from the crush -- not because Ms. Rehn could at any time be approaching her 16th minute in America's celebrity consciousness. No, it is a much more pressing matter, the public relations man said. "Trista wants to watch herself tonight. She whittles it down to about five, I think."
A few blocks from the W, Mark McLemore, the veteran Seattle Mariners ballplayer, drove up Fifth Avenue in a metallic silver Ferrari 360. He parked as admirers scurried around to look at his shimmering vehicle under the street lamps. Mr. McLemore looked like the John Milner character from "American Graffiti" -- he and his car, joined in coolness till their pink slips do them part.
"You could say I'm showing off a little," Mr. McLemore said, smiling.
He and his passenger were told that Marcus Allen, Michael Irvin and Deion Sanders were at the W. 
"They're all has-beens, not like you, still a real player," a reporter said.
"That's cold," Mr. McLemore said, looking at his passenger. "Have you met Michael Allen, yet?" he said. "He's Marcus's younger brother."
Oh.
Mr. McLemore and the Allens are a few of a number of San Diego-born and -bred athletes who made it back for the big party. Another native, Ricky Williams, the Miami running back, gave his own party at the Blue Tattoo on Thursday. Donovan McNabb, the Philadelphia quarterback, was one of the bigger luminaries on Wednesday night, along with the linebackers Bruce Smith and Marcellus Wiley.
 Most of the fans find their way to the Gas Lamp Quarter at night. Their revelry begins at a sort of restaurant row at 7 p.m., continues as the streets pulse with people and music around 10 p.m., then falls into disrepair after 1 a.m., when the most serious carousers start to take the streets. Six rickshaw companies work the late shift, pedaling the inebriated home.
Mark Shadinger, a Raider fan called Spike, traipsed out of a bar on Wednesday night, waiting for more of Raider Nation to join him. Someone asked him where the fan widely known as Violator was this evening.
"We don't baby-sit each other," Mr. Shadinger grunted, unsmiling. Mr. Shadinger is a scruffy, hairy man, with actual spikes protruding from his shoulders, across from the skull with the eye patch. He looks more rugged than a Hell's Angel, but the effect wears off after he reaches into his wallet and presents you with a business card and his very own Spike trading card.
"Here, want one of these?" he said, sheepishly.
Jennifer Martin was not sure what to make of it all. She is a second-grade teacher from San Diego, taking in the madness with her two friends.
"There is more of an L.A. scene than a San Diego scene here this week," Ms. Martin said. "You come back next week and it'll be a lot more laid back. You got too much of this L.A. vibe right now, people in black and worried about what they're wearing. By next week, the town will be back to flip-flops and jeans."
Brook and Paula, Ms. Martin's friends, were chatted up at the W by Mr. Sanders and Mr. Irvin, who referred to each other as their personal assistants. 
"They've been hitting on my friend Paula for a while," Ms. Martin said. "I've decided if nobody's there, Deion will hit on himself."
Mr. Sanders, now a television com mentator, was almost incredulous when the three San Diego women did not know who he was. It was not clear whether Mr. Sanders, the two-sport athlete once simply known as Primetime, was actually upset or putting everyone on.
But it did not help when, after the commotion subsided, Ms. Martin wondered aloud, "So which one is Deion?"
He is the guy who said it was past his curfew several hours ago, the former player -- nursing a drink by a faux cabana in the imported sand, trying to stay incandescent for as long as old Super Bowl legends can. 
"Oh, you got me," he said, closing in on 1 a.m. at the Magnet. "I guess it's not time to go to sleep."
The week of the big game, Bedtime for Primetime always comes late.

HEADLINE: At the Beating Heart Of an Export Machine 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: SHENZHEN, China 

 BODY:
THE giant maroon, blue and white cranes here hoist 40-foot-long steel freight containers onto four container ships, each as long as two football fields. The cranes work around the clock, yet lines of trucks bearing containers keep coming, and vessels often crowd a nearby anchorage waiting to be loaded at Yantian port.
 The port, open less than eight years, is just one of a half dozen in the Pearl River delta in southeastern China, including the world's busiest container port, Kwai Chung in nearby Hong Kong. Together these ports now handle almost as many containers as all the ports in the United States combined, and are growing much more swiftly. More than a third of the electronic goods, clothing and other products that flood through here are headed for America. 
 With 3,000 miles of navigable waterways and hundreds of barges that bring containers full of parts right to factories' docks and take away assembled merchandise, the delta is turning into a Venice of manufacturing. The region has led the way in China's extraordinary transformation into a global trading power, producing fully 40 percent of China's exports. 
Yet in recent weeks, the delta has also been the scene of an acrimonious struggle over who will control the highways, bridges, tunnels and ports that transport an ever-growing river of goods.
The fight has been pitting some of Asia's wealthiest tycoons, like Sir Gordon Wu and Li Ka-shing, against one another. The tussle is also a contest over the delta's political future, as increasingly assertive municipal governments here and in other cities of Guangdong Province try to seize control of logistics and shipping businesses long controlled by Hong Kong.
The delta region is slightly larger than Connecticut, extending from Hong Kong and Macau, at the mouth of the delta, to Guangzhou, 80 miles upstream, and to Huizhou to the east and Foshan to the west. It exports nearly the same value of goods as all of Mexico or South Korea.
The rising trading power of China -- its exports leaped 22 percent last year, and it now trails only the United States, Japan, Germany and France -- has been especially important for transportation companies and port operators. Countries that are more developed rely heavily on exports of high-value products that are either small, like computer chips, or that require practically no shipping, like banking and insurance services. But China's ascendancy is in manufactured goods, from shoes and furniture to fax machines and electric fans, and these tend to be bulky products for which shipping and logistics account for a considerable portion of the final price.
EACH city in the delta is now trying to capture as much of this business as possible by outbuilding its neighbors, often with wasteful and duplicative results. Five international airports were built in the late 1990's in a 60-mile radius, and a similar boom is starting for ports and bridges.
"The Pearl River delta has already become one metropolis," said a recent report from CLSA, the investment bank, and Civic Exchange, a nonprofit research group in Hong Kong. "Administratively, it remains a nightmare with many jurisdictions."
Several Hong Kong developers, led by Sir Gordon, chairman of Hopewell Holdings, want to build a bridge from Macau to Hong Kong's Lantau Island and a new deep-water container terminal port at the western end of it. That would allow factories on the southwest bank of the Pearl River, which lacks deep harbors, to send goods by truck to the new port for loading onto ocean-going ships.
But Shenzhen officials want a tunnel farther up the river, connecting Zhuhai to Shenzhen. That would mean more goods going through Shenzhen's ports. And Guangzhou officials want to build an immense new container terminal farther upstream.
Guangzhou is also replacing its airport with an enormous new one, to compete with Hong Kong's four-year-old airport and recently opened airports in Zhuhai, and is brushing off criticism from Hong Kong that it is all unnecessary. "We are not asking Hong Kong not to develop," Lin Shusen, the mayor of Guangzhou, said recently. "In the same vein, there are some projects that we need to develop, and we hope Hong Kong will not expect us not to."
Even before any construction can begin, trade in the delta will be in for some big changes. On Feb. 2, the United States Customs Service will start levying penalties on any shippers that send containers to the United States without first complying with a 14-item checklist intended to reduce the risk that weapons of mass destruction are concealed inside. The new rules apply to exporters all over the world, but may particularly be a problem here, where exporters take pride in their ability to minimize inventory costs by sending goods to ships hours before sailing time. 
Concerns about security rules, port construction plans and other logistics issues are no minor matter here in the delta, where as much as a fifth of Hong Kong's economy depends on the processing of goods for export.
Ports, bridges and tunnels do not just create jobs for dock workers and truckers. Garments and pairs of shoes that cost $2 to make in the delta sell for many times that in the United States, partly because many tasks must be done between the factory gate and the store shelf overseas. These include sorting and inspecting merchandise, packing it into containers, and financing and insuring the goods. Computer printers, VCR's, telephones and other electronic goods are the delta's biggest exports, followed by textiles and apparel, with 36 percent of the shipments going to the United States and 23 percent to the European Union. 
The world's largest multilevel industrial building is an immense complex in Hong Kong owned by an American company, the CSX Corporation. The 14-story building at the Kwai Chung docks has 16 miles of roads inside, mostly of three lanes, and handles 10,000 trucks bearing containers each day. Companies like Adidas, Wal-Mart, Target, Next and Liz Claiborne all lease space in the building for various tasks, like inspecting garments.
In one room, lacy white women's vests from the Next brand are loaded into a container in exactly the order they will need to be unloaded at a British department store -- eliminating the need for warehouse and sorting space in Britain. Each vest is already on its hanger and has a tag with a price in British pounds.
But packing and loading containers is not cheap. Especially expensive are the handling charges the shipping lines have levied on exporters in recent years. The shippers contend that they are only passing on what they describe as unusually steep fees collected by port operators in China.
In suggesting a new port, Sir Gordon has played on the anger that many exporters here feel at the handling charges, which are highest in the delta. American and European importers, not Chinese exporters here in the delta, typically pay all freight charges except for initial loading fees. Many shippers contend that the port operators form an oligopoly that overcharges the shipping lines for loading containers.
"Hong Kong has got the highest charges of anywhere in the world for terminal charges," Sir Gordon said. "And you know where the second highest is? Yantian, the same management."
The port operators dispute this, especially Hutchison Port Holdings, the world's largest, which manages more than half of Kwai Chung and all of Yantian. John F. Meredith, the company's group managing director, contended that other ports had even higher charges although they used different names for them. He also accused the shipping lines of charging customers much more than they are paying the ports.
"The shipping lines are desperate to get income into their systems, with freight rates so low," he said. Shipping executives deny that they are padding the charges.
HUTCHISON is a subsidiary of Hutchison Whampoa, which in turn is controlled by Mr. Li, Hong Kong's wealthiest tycoon. Mr. Li has more than most at stake in the debate over a bridge across the Pearl River, as he also controls two-thirds of the many shallow-draft barges with cranes operating on the river. The barges collect containers up and down the river, then sail to the mouth of the delta and load the big boxes directly onto ocean-going ships.
Hong Kong's port operators question the insistence of Guangzhou officials that a huge port at Nansha is even feasible. The muddy Pearl River is too shallow to accommodate modern container ships, and shipping lines are planning even bigger vessels.
Guangzhou's plan is an enormous dredging operation to deepen the Pearl River's shipping channel to 48 feet from 30 feet all the way from Nansha to the ocean.
Environmentalists are appalled but have limited influence. Hong Kong port operators say that the port in Buenos Aires has not been able to accept the larger container ships despite continuous dredging, and question whether the Pearl River can ever be deepened.
"When you go up the Pearl River, you're going up one of the world's largest gravel conveyor belts," said William McHugh, CSX's chairman of Asian terminals.
The shallowness of the Pearl River makes it attractive for bridge builders, however. Of all the projects pending, the bridge seems to have the most momentum, having received a strong endorsement on Jan. 8 from Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, while provincial officials in Guangdong have toned down some of their objections. "It's one of the most obvious things that should have been built, but because of the lack of coordination over the last 20 or 30 years, it wasn't," said Franklin Lam, a Hong Kong equities analyst at UBS Warburg.
Hanging over every debate about future civil engineering projects, and over the future of the delta itself, is the region's growing competition with Shanghai and the Yangtze River delta.
The Pearl River delta still has a slightly greater economic output and exports. But the Yangtze River delta is attracting more domestic and foreign investment. It is also far ahead in growth industries like heavy manufacturing, computer chip fabrication and financial services that Beijing sees as more important to China's future than the light industry that dominates the Pearl River delta.
Yet the Pearl River delta could have considerable growth ahead. Its southwest bank has less than a quarter of the output of the cities along the northeast bank. Investors have put most of their money into factories within a three-hour drive of Hong Kong -- allowing entrepreneurs in chauffeur-driven Mercedeses and BMW's to make the trip to their factories and back in a single day. A bridge from Hong Kong to Macau would open up large areas of farmland for development.
Fully developing the other side of the delta is likely to produce another flood of exports from what is already becoming the world's workshop. "Does that mean double the trade?" asked Michael J. Enright, a business professor at Hong Kong University. "Not necessarily, but not much short of that."

HEADLINE: The Revolution That Wasn't 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
EXACTLY 10 years ago today, I.B.M. announced that John F. Akers, its chairman and chief executive, would soon leave. Institutional investors, furious at the company's gigantic losses and stunning decline in value, had for months clamored for his head. Finally, the I.B.M. board blinked.
 The ouster came just three months after the board of General Motors had pushed out Robert C. Stempel, its chief. And it was soon followed by a flurry of headline-grabbing departures at American Express, Kodak, Westinghouse, Apple Computer and other blue-chip companies. 
 The so-called Year of the Sharp Knives seemed to signal a new era, one in which directors would act solely in the interests of shareholders. No longer would they adhere to the gentleman's agreement that poor performance was no reason to kick a chief executive out of office. 
Yet 10 years later, it looks very much as if the corporate governance revolution of 1993 is back at Square 1. Boards are quicker to punish incompetence -- but no more apt to spot criminality. They will howl when quarterly numbers are depressed, yet shut their eyes when the numbers are squishy or even fraudulent. They will use stock grants and options to align management's interest with that of shareholders, yet ignore the temptation the options create for management to drive up stock prices with false promises, take the money and run.
"It now seems that what we had in 1993 was sporadic and random action by high-profile directors at high-profile companies, but no countrywide improvement in corporate governance," said Peter C. Clapman, the chief counsel of TIAA-CREF, the huge pension and mutual fund manager that has long fought for better boardroom vigilance.
No one is satisfied with the status quo. Investors have fled the market. The New York Stock Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission, Congress -- all are scrambling to pass laws and write regulations detailing what committees boards must have, what credentials their members must possess, what work they must do. And even with the new strictures, disappointed governance experts worry that, when the economy rebounds, directors will be lulled into complacency yet again.
"I'm just mildly optimistic that the latest reforms will stick if we go into another bull market now," Mr. Clapman said.
This isn't how it was supposed to be. Just as World War I was the war to end all wars, the battle waged by the shareholder advocates of 1993 -- people like Dale M. Hanson, then chief executive of the California Public Employees' Retirement System; Richard H. Koppes, its general counsel; Robert A. G. Monks and Nell Minow at Lens Inc., an activist investment fund; and Ralph V. Whitworth, who founded the United Shareholders Association -- was supposed to be war to end bad governance.
Fed up with "poison pills" that prevented badly managed companies from being acquired, with regulations that made it illegal for shareholders to band together without first notifying the S.E.C., and rules that allowed boards to keep executive compensation policies secret, they waged battles company by company. Many boards and regulators responded, opening corporate policies to public scrutiny and making heads roll. Supine boards and management malfeasance were to be things of the past.
INSTEAD, the nation got blowups at Enron, WorldCom, Tyco International, Adelphia Communications and myriad other corporate scandals since late 2001.
"I was naively hopeful back then that institutional investors would continue to have a scouring effect," said Mr. Whitworth, who now heads Relational Investors, an investment firm that has teamed up with the California retirement fund -- known as Calpers -- to buy large stakes in companies that they want to change. "It just didn't happen."
What did happen is not insignificant. At shareholders' urging, more boards are now made up of outside directors whose independence is not compromised by personal ties to the chief executive or business ties to the company. Pay and pay policies are listed in proxy statements, and shareholders can join forces in everything short of a proxy solicitation without notifying the S.E.C.
Institutional investors, activists and the news media increasingly are placing board activities in a glaring spotlight, too. The Corporate Library, a research group that follows boards, will soon start rating them as if they were bonds -- "from triple-A to junk," as Ms. Minow, a co-founder of the group in 1999, put it. 
Directors, meanwhile, now take more seriously their fiduciary duties to regularly evaluate the chief executive's peformance. "They replace the C.E.O. before the company tanks, not six months after," said Gerard R. Roche, senior chairman of the executive recruiting firm Heidrick & Struggles International.
Yet the last year's events certainly prove that good governance is lacking at many companies. What went wrong? Several things, governance experts suggest:
* Shareholders were lulled into believing that the growing use of stock options as part of executive pay would align management's interest with theirs; instead, it tempted executives to push up share prices with accounting tricks. "One of the great drivers of the scandals we've seen in the last few years was executives trying to preserve paper wealth," said Warren L. Batts, an adjunct professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business.
* There is a growing scarcity of qualified auditors to spot those manipulations. "When I was running the S.E.C., 20 percent of Wharton School graduates wanted to become accountants," recalled Roderick M. Hills, a lawyer who was chairman of the S.E.C. from 1975 through 1977. "Nowadays, the accountants and auditors don't even have M.B.A.'s."
* There is an even greater lack of qualified directors. "The feeling has long been that directors should restrict the number of boards they sit on," said Thomas J. Neff, the chairman of American operations of Spencer Stuart, the executive recruiting firm. "One result is that there just aren't enough good directors to go around any more."
* The boom market of the 90's had a numbing effect on corporate ethics and shareholder vigilance. "We were all doing pretty darned well, and that made it easier to turn away from the egregious self-enrichment of many corporate chieftains," said Anthony M. Maramarco, managing director of the investment firm David L. Babson. 
In fact, some experts now say that the executive suite purges of 1993 may have set the governance cause back a bit by letting the boardroom pendulum swing too far. That, they say, led some directors who had once refused to punish chief executives for anything to punish them for everything.
"A lot of chief executives were turned into scapegoats," said Jay W. Lorsch, a professor at the Harvard Business School.
No question, even the companies that dismissed their chiefs a decade ago, and many of those who followed their lead, have had mixed results. Revenue, profits and stock prices rebounded strongly at I.B.M. after an outsider, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., replaced Mr. Akers. And American Express definitely did well after Harvey Golub, a long-time American Express executive, was moved up into Mr. Robinson's chair, even if Professor Lorsch may argue that the cause and effect is blurred. 
But Eastman Kodak, whose stock plunged last week when its earnings came in below analysts' estimates, is only now figuring out how to make money from digital photography -- and only after George M. C. Fisher, the technolgy guru brought in from Motorola to replace the ousted Kay R. Whitmore, himself ceded the reins to Daniel A. Carp, who had been with Kodak many years.
General Motors has only recently regained its bearings in the automotive market, and its stock still underperforms the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Apple Computer, 10 years after John Sculley left, is still an also-ran in personal computers. And Westinghouse Electric does not even exist any more -- Michael H. Jordan, a former McKinsey consultant who replaced Paul E. Lego as chief executive, broke up the company, parceling its industrial and broadcasting operations out to disparate buyers.
"With the possible exception of I.B.M., I'm not sure that anything really improved at any of these companies," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, who runs the investment firm Ghriskey Capital Partners.
MAYBE not. Nonetheless, the bloodbaths of a decade ago left a positive legacy in some respects.
Back then, for example, many pundits were shocked when I.B.M. hired a "cookie man" -- as Mr. Gerstner, then of RJR Nabisco Holdings, was disparagingly referred to by some entrenched I.B.M. insiders. Today, companies routinely bring in expertise from outside their industries.
Shareholders, meanwhile, are armed with more information and -- as they routinely take advantage of the right they won in late 1992 to meet freely and act in concert -- with more authority to use it. "We have windows into compensation plans now," Mr. Whitworth, the shareholder advocate, said. "And pressure for change no longer comes solely from shareholders who are well-heeled enough to stage a proxy fight."
Directors have much more at stake now, too, thanks to proposed rules that would make them culpable for malfeasance that takes place on their watch. Mr. Koppes, the former Calpers general counsel, remembers having to threaten directors with public embarrassment to elicit action.
"Today, they are worried about personal liability and criminal charges," said Mr. Koppes, who is now of counsel to the law firm Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.
Board members are also worried about their bank accounts. They increasingly own stock in the companies on whose boards they sit. Enron, in fact, may have been the exception that just might prove the wisdom of that rule. In November 2000, the Corporate Library checked out director stock ownership at more than 1,000 companies. "Enron tied for last place," Ms. Minow recalled. "Institutional investors should have been looking at that, and calling them on it."
Washington action may yet make shareholder involvement moot. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act, intended as a sweeping overhaul of corporate securities, accounting and fraud policies, is just starting to kick in. The new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board should be up and running in a few months. And the S.E.C. has promised to adopt stricter governance rules.
But snags are already cropping up. S.E.C. staff members have suggested that the oversight board, which was late in starting, defang proposed rules that would have prevented lawyers, companies and accountants from using client or employer confidentiality to keep evidence of misbehavior from shareholders.
In the end, the success of a governance revolution rests with shareholders -- and maybe the market.
"Investors don't usually get really mad if honest capitalists are making a lot of money," said Mr. Maramarco, the investment firm executive. "But throw investors a spitball, and they will charge the pitcher's mound every time."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Is There Such a Thing as a Jobless Recovery?

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
A WALL Street maxim holds that the difference between recession and depression is that a recession is when your neighbor loses his job. A depression? When you lose yours.
 That saying goes a long way toward explaining the disconnect between recent statistics showing that the economy as a whole is in decent shape, and polls finding that economic anxiety is gripping many Americans. 
 After falling into recession in 2001, the economy did indeed recover in 2002, hard as that is to believe. Despite a sluggish fall, most economists believe the United States expanded at close to 3 percent last year (final statistics are still being compiled). 
But because productivity -- the amount of goods or services produced for each hour worked -- is climbing relatively fast, last year's relatively tepid expansion created almost no new jobs. Instead, businesses are finding ways to get more production out of each current employee. In fact, the unemployment rate has risen from 3.9 percent in 2000 to 6 percent today.
"The single most important statistic that looks ugly and is concerning people is jobs, and we've created no jobs, in the aggregate, in this 11month recovery," said Donald Straszheim, the president of Straszheim Global Advisors and the former chief economist for Merrill Lynch. "For most people, it's about a paycheck, and if you've got a job, you're O.K. And if you don't, you're not."
The lack of job growth is the downside of the productivity boom that began in the mid-1990's and still seems to be continuing today, said Brad DeLong, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley. In the long run, higher productivity should be good for the economy, leading to broad increases in wealth. But in the short term, it means that 2.5 percent annual growth, which in the late 1980's or early 1990's would have created lots of new jobs, now does not, he said.
"The kind of growth that previously gave us a rising employment environment now gives us a rising unemployment environment," Mr. DeLong said.
THE possibility of war with Iraq and of new terrorist attacks is also depressing confidence levels, said Delos Smith, senior business analyst for the Conference Board, a nonprofit group that assesses consumer confidence each month. (Mr. Smith said much the same thing occurred before the Persian Gulf war, when the board's confidence index fell from 102 in July 1990 to about 55 in January 1991, when the allied bombing campaign began. After Iraqi forces surrendered and oil prices plunged, the index rose 22 points in a single month, an unusually large gain.)
The index now stands at 80.3 and is expected to fall into the mid-70's when January figures are released on Tuesday. This would be lower than at any point since November 1993, at the outset of the long boom of the 1990's. 
What role consumer confidence plays in the economy is a more complicated question. Even Mr. Smith called the board's survey more of an "ambiance index" than a concrete guide to consumer spending. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is known to believe that consumer confidence is of minimal importance to the economy. He and others believe that, regardless of how they say they feel, most people will spend almost all the money they make.
But Stephen Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley and one of the most bearish forecasters, said the increasing pessimism of consumers is troubling. Mr. Roach has repeatedly warned that the United States faces the threat of deflation, which has gripped Japan's economy for the last decade.
"The American consumer has been the last gasp for the U.S. economy," Mr. Roach said. "If the consumer weakens further, there's not a whole lot left."
Most mainstream economists, however, are more optimistic than Mr. Roach and expect continued moderate growth this year. But unless growth accelerates, Mr. DeLong said, "2003 doesn't feel good at all for the unemployed, and it doesn't feel very good for the employed."
In other words, this recovery is, to a lot of people, merely a statistic -- several consecutive quarters of economic growth that, nonetheless, leave many people feeling as if they are in the midst of a recession.

HEADLINE: Out, Damned Spot 

BYLINE:  By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
IT'S not exactly an urban mystery. More a case of mass denial, or a lack of anthropological curiosity. Whatever the reason, only some New Yorkers, including, now, the mayor, know that the black blobs stuck to pavements around the city are not part of the concrete mix, not stray bits of asphalt, not hardened drips of roofing tar. No, the splotches, some amoeba-shaped and some round as half dollars, are pieces of discarded chewing gum.
 "Those little black dots on the sidewalk," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called them in November during his regular radio program, lamenting their ubiquity and confiding that he had always wondered what they were. 
"That's gum," he told his listeners. Twice, as if it were hard to believe. 
 The mayor urged property owners to turn this discovery into action. "Hire a company to come and clean your sidewalk," he said. 
 As it turns out, the available arsenal to battle the gum now includes a new weapon: a solvent that vaporizes the splotches. Gumbusters of New York, the company that deploys the mixture, has served about 300 clients, including the Statue of Liberty, since its founding three years ago. Perhaps it's high time for all this attention, because there is evidence that New York's hefty new cigarette tax may be producing a city of even more gum chewers -- and potential gum litterers. 
 True, a smear on the sidewalk is not crime in the streets. It's not an act of terrorism. It's not a battered school system, a rising homeless population, a buffeted economy or the specter of shrunken city services. 
 But hardened gum underfoot is undeniably an urban hallmark. And of course, the bigger and denser the city, the more the gum, which may make New York the gum splotch capital of the world. 
 Like artifacts at a dig site, these splotches can be found where they were abandoned. Many land outside restaurants, stores, subway stations, subway cars and anyplace people have been standing in line. Others, in a sign of good intentions, pile up near refuse baskets on street corners. 
 Who knows? Among the millions of gum blobs on New York's 12,500 miles of pavement may be a fragment from the era of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, who ran a campaign to reform gum litterers in 1939. "Mayor's Gum Drive Off to Fast Start -- Two Companies and a Flood of Volunteers Join Up," read a headline in this newspaper at the time. 
 "It's one of those things that has become a fact of city life," said Tim Tompkins, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District. "I think, on a core level, most people are used to it." 
 Historically speaking, New York may deserve all its abandoned gum. In an odd tale that touches on the Alamo by way of Staten Island, it was here, in the late 19th century, that the world's first chewing gum factory was built. But if the city gave birth to modern chewing gum, it once again has a few forces, not least a mayor, who want to take it off the streets. 

How New York Got Its Spots
 The chewing gum industry got its start in New York because chicle, a rubbery substance produced by the tropical sapodilla tree, found its way to Staten Island. It was carried here, as a chew, by General Santa Anna, the Mexican dictator who prevailed at the battle of the Alamo in 1836. Santa Anna came to Staten Island as an exile, after he was defeated by Sam Houston and after Texas became a state. There he met Thomas Adams, a local inventor.
 In 1869, Adams tried, unsuccessfully, to make tires from Santa Anna's stash of chicle, then gave it a chew himself and liked it better than the paraffin-wax or spruce-resin chewing plugs that New Yorkers were buying from pharmacists at the time. (Today's gums are made mostly with a synthetic-polymer gum base.) By 1876, according to The Encyclopedia of New York City, the inventor had opened Adams Sons & Company on Vesey Street in Lower Manhattan, the first gum factory. Its packages featured a drawing of City Hall and the slogan "Adams' New York Chewing Gum, Snapping and Stretching."
 The Adams company, long a part of Pfizer and now slated to be sold to Cadbury-Schweppes, dominated the gum business that grew up in the early 20th century, making Chiclets, Tutti Frutti gumballs and other brands. Gum spread throughout America, then throughout Europe, as G.I.'s in both world wars enjoyed and distributed the gum supplied in their rations. 
 Gum also spread all over the sidewalks of New York. In a 1939 New York Times article headlined "Bogged in Chewing Gum," a hotel executive complained that "the city of New York may become totally enveloped in refuse chewing gum in the course of time." 
 That same year, Mayor La Guardia embarked on his public education campaign against gum litterers. He pressured gum companies to print warnings on their wrappers about proper gum disposal and announced a search for a "catchy" advertising slogan for a cleanup. His final choice? "Don't Gum Up the Works." As part of the campaign, "some 20,000 wads were scraped from one spot on Times Square alone," wrote Robert Hendrickson, author of "The Great American Chewing Gum Book" (Stein & Day, 1976). 
 So it continued in New York: a lot of gum spit out, a little gum removed. And some gum immortalized. In 1972, a self-defined "disposable artist" named Les Levine who lived on Mott Street cast about 30 pieces of freshly chewed gum in gold. The resulting works, called "Solid Gold Chewing Gum," were shown at the Fischbach Gallery in Manhattan; the sculptures are a comment about art, "about the making process," Mr. Levine said in a recent interview.

The Bull's-Eye Stratagem
 These days, discarded gum is practically part of the city's infrastructure.
 "When you think about doing something special, a nicer type of sidewalk or something," said Mr. Tompkins of the Times Square BID, "you have to consider the gum issue." 
 Although gum spots are found throughout the city, the problem is understandably worse in more congested areas. The Grand Central Partnership, another large business improvement district, struggles daily against the litter in its gum-heavy neighborhood. "It's a disgusting sight," said Alfred C. Cerullo III, president of the partnership. 
 And it may be worse below street level. For a time in the 90's, the Transit Authority set up targets at selected gum-encrusted stations and invited passengers to hurl their gum at bull's-eyes instead of dropping it on the ground. The program was discontinued because it was not cost-effective. 
 Many subway riders are inured to the splotches. "It's so dirty, I just block it out," said Eneas Soares, a Hunter College student, pointing to the heavy gum deposits along the downtown subway platform at 96th Street and Broadway.
 That's assuming they know it's gum in the first place. "It's too much to be chewing gum," said Lenora Jones, a retired customer service representative, who sat nearby eyeing an unbroken line of splotches along the platform's edge.
 Too much, indeed. Americans chew about $2.8 billion worth of gum every year, according to a report by Packaged Facts, a market research company. Using Wrigley's 25-cent pack as a measure, that adds up to about 56 billion pieces annually. And there's no reason to think that New Yorkers chew less than their share. "As far as I can tell, gum consumption is pretty uniform across the United States," said Jim Echeandia, a Texas-based confectionery consultant. 
 The city's recently increased cigarette tax, which raised the price of a pack to about $7.50, may mean that New Yorkers will chew even more as they try to reduce their smoking or quit. At the United Grocery at 94th Street and Broadway, Anna Khan, whose family owns the store, now orders six boxes of gum a week instead of the two boxes she ordered before the tax took effect on July 1. "One customer, he used to buy two packs of cigarettes a day," she said. "Since the price went up, he buys five to six packs of gum a day instead."
 New Yorkers -- unlike, say, the residents of Switzerland -- are not famous for their neatness. But it is unclear why depositing gum on the ground became acceptable, especially given that it is officially prohibited as littering or spitting under city regulations.
 "It would be a good graduate student project," said Mr. Tompkins of the Times Square BID, laughing. "'The Rupturing of the Social Contract With Respect to Gum Disposal."' 
 The reduction of subway graffiti got a big boost from new technology that made it easier to clean the trains. For their part, gum makers are trying to devise a gum that does not adhere to pavements. 
 "There are a number of encouraging developments, but no new products ready for consumer testing," said Amy Chezem, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Chewing Gum Manufacturers. The companies also say they have made progress toward a gum base that breaks down over time, but, she added, "The prospect is still a way off."

Scraping, Slicing, Steaming
Until then, gum removal will remain a constant struggle. 
 Sanitation crews for the Grand Central Partnership routinely remove gum from news boxes and phone booths in eastern Midtown. "They scrape it, they use solutions," Mr. Cerullo said. "Every day, seven days a week. It's an ongoing battle." Periodically, he also hires power washers to remove gum stuck to the sidewalk. 
 At Grand Central Terminal, three "degummers" -- employees wielding broom handles outfitted with razor-sharp blades -- patrol the concourse every night at 1 a.m. as part of the general cleanup. The floor, made of Tennessee marble, resists nicking "and allows the gum to come up," said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North Railroad, which operates Grand Central. 
 But perhaps the organization taking the most focused aim at the problem is a small Queens company called, appropriately, Gumbusters, headed by Brad Fields, a trim 32-year-old entrepreneur with a low-key manner and high aspirations.
 So far Gumbusters of New York, one of the American franchisees of a Dutch company, has vaporized gum spots from 500,000 square feet of the city, Mr. Fields said. But that, he knows, is just a tiny clearing here in the petrified-gum forest, and the underbrush can grow back fast. The new McDonald's at 42nd Street hired Gumbusters last September, and needed it to return just weeks later. 
 The nature of his work has turned Mr. Fields into something of a gum anthropologist. "I walk with my head down now, like most New Yorkers, but I do it for business knowledge," he said. He can explain why some wads are huge ("Kids chew four pieces at a time"), why some are just larger than average (probably bubble gum), why some have tails (someone stepped on them when they were fresh, pulling them along the street before they hardened), and how long it takes for a pink, white or green confection to become a grimy stain that stubbornly stays put ("I'd give it about 24 hours").
 Gumbusters has cleaned gum from the sidewalks of Carnegie Hall, the sidewalks of the Magic Johnson Theater in Harlem and Arthur Ashe Stadium. (Pavement cleaning is the duty of property owners, not the Department of Sanitation.) In November, Mr. Fields degummed 100 square feet of pavement in City Hall Park to demonstrate his system to the Parks Department. 
 Bill Tai, who as chief of the department's Manhattan operations branch arranged for the display, was noncommittal about the chance for any Parks Department business. "I don't know what will come of it," he said. "We don't have a lot of extra money in our budget." 
 Around the same time, Mr. Fields demonstrated his company's steam-and-solvent system at the Gumbusters headquarters in Long Island City. With two of the company's five employees, he climbed into a Gumbusters truck painted with smiley gobs of colorful gum. He hopped out at a nearby corner and hooked up a small, portable "gumcart" to a surprisingly quiet generator. "No point in trading gum pollution for noise pollution," he said.
 Then the three men, using a long brush attachment, handily evaporated 25 black blobs from the pavement before moving to another spot. "Probably Juicy Fruit," Mr. Fields said, as one splotch liquefied and dribbled away. "We can smell the gum sometimes. The flavor wafts up."
 The low-pressure system, Mr. Fields added, uses less water than high-pressure power-washing, which must be done at night when pedestrians are absent.
 His prices depend upon gum density, but customers generally pay 35 cents a square foot plus $18 a gallon for the patented solution. His clients can buy their own gumcart from the company for $5,900, as managers for Pennsylvania Station and the Statue of Liberty have done.
 Given the expense of gum removal and the entrenched habits of gum chewers, is cleanup worth it? After all, a gum splotch poses no health hazard, according to Andrew Tucker, a spokesman for the Department of Health. 
 But Mr. Cerullo of the Grand Central Partnership believes that discarded gum should be removed, "whether on public or private property." And Tony Regno, facilities manager at Carnegie Hall, said a degummed sidewalk can make all the difference. After the Gumbusters visit, he said, his pavement looked much brighter without the black spots, making the entire location appear well maintained. 
 Personally, however, Mr. Regno discards his gum in his usual good-citizen way.
 "I swallow it," he said.
