HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Waiting for War Weighs Down Economy

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
CORPORATE executives are reluctant to build new factories. Small business owners are hesitating to hire more workers. Investors are unwilling to put more money in stocks. 
 In ways large and small, the economy has come down with a bad case of the jitters, and one big reason is concern about the increasing likelihood of war with Iraq and the effect it might have on everything from oil prices and air travel to consumer confidence and international financial markets. 
 Weighed down by such worries, the economy has throttled way back after showing signs last year of accelerating toward a reasonable cruising speed, and it could even be at risk of stalling. The stock market is swooning once more, giving up the gains of its rally early this year. Corporations are cautiously predicting lackluster earnings. 
On Friday, the stock market fell to its lowest point this year, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling more than 238 points.
"It has affected sentiment, absolutely," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, an investment firm. "If you're at a management committee meeting, it tends to influence whatever you're talking about. Can I hire somebody? Can I make that investment commitment? The best thing that can happen is to get it out of the way."
While there is no evidence that the economy is driving his decisions about whether to go to war or when, President Bush is aware of the issue. It came up last week during a meeting at the White House with 15 economists.
"What was said -- and he didn't disagree with this -- is that uncertainty hampers investment decisions, and that markets don't like uncertainty," said Brian S. Wesbury, chief economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, an investment firm in Chicago, who was at the meeting.
A quick military victory, economists said, could bring sighs of relief in oil and financial markets, and help bolster business, investor and consumer confidence. A drawn-out diplomatic standoff could leave the economy and markets suspended between fear and hope. A prolonged or bloody conflict would hold the risk of damaging the economy.
Success in the war would also strengthen Mr. Bush's hand on Capitol Hill, where he faces opposition from Democrats and a few moderate Republicans to the centerpiece of his economic plan, $670 billion in tax cuts over the next decade, including an immediate repeal of the tax on stock dividends. A less positive outcome in Iraq could weaken Mr. Bush's dealing with Congress. 
The political perils of the relationship between Iraq and the economy were reflected last week in a New York Times/CBS News poll. While Mr. Bush's overall approval rating, at 59 percent, remains high, his approval rating on foreign policy has dropped to 52 percent from 68 percent last summer and 75 percent right after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Approval of his handling of the economy, at 44 percent, is down from a peak of 64 percent 15 months ago. Perhaps more worrisome for Mr. Bush, his disapproval ratings on the economy nearly doubled, to 49 percent, over the same period.
Mr. Bush and his aides have long asserted that the right way to think about the economic implications of confronting Iraq is to consider not the costs of action, but rather the costs of inaction. Failing to remove a despot with the means to create havoc in a critical region would leave the United States open to potentially calamitous losses of all sorts, including economic ones.
Whether war cost $40 billion or $80 billion or $200 billion (all figures that have been bandied about), it would be well worth it if the threat of weapons of mass destruction were removed from Iraq, White House officials said, even if it meant a temporary increase in the already ballooning budget deficit.
But while such an infusion could provide a not-inconsiderable jolt to the economy, the administration is intent on keeping overall government spending far below levels of the last few years by limiting or cutting budgets outside of the military and domestic security, an effort that the Republican-controlled Congress seems willing to take seriously. As a result, the fiscal stimulus from any war is likely to be limited, though Mr. Bush is still pressing for a big tax cut to help the economy.
THE attempt to tamp down the fiscal effects of a surge in military spending is just one way in which this war is likely to be different from World War II or Vietnam, when huge increases in defense revved up the overall economy. Another is the greatly increased importance of national psychology in determining the strength of financial markets and the economy, and vice versa.
"Capital market risk of the sort caused by the prospect of war reaches the heart and the wallet of the individual now like it's never done before, because he's got a mutual fund instead of a C.D. and a 401(k) instead of a defined benefit pension," said Paul McCulley, chief economist at Pimco, a bond trading firm. "This war, which by definition begets risk aversion, also happens at a time of post-bubble disorder in the corporate sector, which has made companies disinclined to invest anyway."
Yet if winning a quick war would help lighten the mood in the markets and the executive suites and the shopping malls, it would not eliminate the broader threat of terrorism and would still leave Mr. Bush to confront the next threat posed by his axis of evil, North Korea. So the relief rally from even a decisive military victory over Iraq might prove short-lived.
"The risk of something unexpected and bad happening has never been higher than it has been since 9/11," Mr. Paulsen said. "That will remain whether we go to war with Iraq or not."

HEADLINE: RESPONSIBLE PARTY/HARRY MILLER; 
A Practical Economics Of Growth

BYLINE:  By JUDY TONG 

 BODY:
INCHWORMS, shoes that grow with your child, could help make many a weary parent a little less footsore. Instead of hitting the shoe store again every few months for your child, you can stay home and stretch the Inchworms. The shoes expand by two half sizes, giving you, and your wallet, a little breathing room. 
 Harry Miller, 43, is co-inventor of the Inchworm and president of the Harry Miller Company, an industrial textile manufacturer in Boston started by his grandfather and now the parent of a shoemaking subsidiary, Inchworm Inc. 
Before Mr. Miller joined the family business, he was vice president for business development at K2 Inc., a sporting goods company that makes, among other things, several brands of athletic footwear. 
 So shoes were not a big reach for Mr. Miller when, shortly after he took over as president of Harry Miller in 1998, a friend in South Korea, Kwon Dong Chil, sent him the prototype of what would become the Inchworm.
 "The first shoe he sent me was 'Frankenstinian,"' Mr. Miller recalled, but over two years he and Mr. Kwon refined the prototype. In the summer of 2001, Mr. Miller moved to Pusan, South Korea, for nine weeks and, working out of Mr. Kwon's shoe factory there, the two hammered out the final details. The shoes have been in stores for about a year.
 "People have said to me, 'Why hasn't someone done this before,' " Mr. Miller said. "The reason is it's not easy to do."
 To expand an Inchworm shoe, one presses a button on the outside and then pulls the ends of the shoe until it clicks into the next half size. In the unlikely case of a shrinking foot, the process can also be reversed. So a size 1 to 2 Inchworm, for example, would fit a child whose foot was size 1, 1.5 or 2. An accordion-like plastic molding in the middle of shoe expands or contracts, while an inner sole equal to the middle size of the shoe, like 1.5, does not change.
 Inchworms, which sell at retail for $45 a pair, are available in stores nationwide as well as on the company's Web site, www.inchwormshoe.com. Only four styles are available so far, but new ones will be introduced at the 2003 World Shoe Association trade show in Las Vegas.
 "We're expanding the expanding shoe," Mr. Miller said with a chuckle.
 Of course, the real question may not be whether parents will buy the shoes but whether children will wear them. After putting his shoes to the ultimate test, Mr. Miller is confident they will.
 "My middle child, Max, is 5, and he is a tough customer," he said. "And he loves our shoe. I would bring him a prototype, and he didn't care that my financial future may ride on them. When you're 5, man, you tell the truth." JUDY TONG

HEADLINE: Happy Endings Start Here 

 BODY:
For weeks, during the 91st campaign of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Times readers have been able to glimpse the lives of people they help through the fund.
 Carolyn Braddy, who has raised her four children despite multiple sclerosis, received help with her rent. Vinod Gupta, who has a heart condition and a brain tumor, now has beds where his family can sleep. Roy Lantigua, 11, blessed with intellect and ambition but born with underdeveloped legs and no arms, has a new computer to help him discover a world that has been beyond his reach. And there is Caryll Adderley, whose cancer has given her about a year to teach her 16-year-old son, an aspiring chef, how to survive without her. His chances look better now that he has received the equipment he needs to learn his craft. 
 These New Yorkers remind us how unexpected circumstances can ruin the most modest expectations. So many readers have helped with donations, with apartments, even jobs. Others sent checks to the fund's seven participating agencies. While total contributions are short of last year's level, this campaign has been remarkable for the number of people responding: 2 percent more than last year, many of them first-time donors. Despite the economic hard times -- or perhaps because of them -- these generous people animated Thomas Jefferson's belief that "every human mind feels pleasure in doing good to another." Their donations mean that thousands of other stories may have happier endings and brighter new beginnings.
To add your contribution, you may donate online at www.nytimes.com/neediest or at CharityWave .com; write a check, made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and send it to 4 Chase Metrotech Center, 7th Floor East, Lockbox 5193, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11245; or give by telephone at (212) 556-5851 (Extension 7). To delay may mean to forget. The current campaign ends on Friday.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Fiscal, and Physical, Belt-Tightening

BYLINE:  By CHARLES L. P. FAIRWEATHER 

 BODY:
In perhaps another measure of consumer confidence in the economy, or lack thereof, more Americans say they would rather reduce their debt than their weight when given a choice of the two goals for 2003.
 About 37 percent of the 1,012 adults questioned in a random-sample telephone survey this month said that they planned to concentrate on their fiscal fitness this year, while 29 percent said they would focus on physical fitness. 
About one-quarter were equally focused on both, with the rest focused on neither, or undecided.
 Those trying to pay off debt wanted to wipe out $10,911, on average. The respondents trying to lose weight said they wanted to shed an average of 22 pounds. The poll was commissioned by Bankrate Inc. and conducted Jan. 3-5. CHARLES L. P. FAIRWEATHER

HEADLINE: U.S. Supports Anticrime Group In the Caucasus and Central Asia 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BINDER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
With concern growing about the dangers worldwide of organized crime and terrorism, the United States will provide financial support for law enforcement to a regional group of countries in the Caucasus and Central Asia, officials from the United States and participating countries said this week.
 The five -- Georgia, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Moldova -- formed their regional group four years ago and are planning a law enforcement center linking their police forces, border guards and customs authorities. 
 Their model for coordinating law enforcement is based on a center in Bucharest, Romania, that links Balkan governments to combat international crime. It has been in operation for two years under the auspices of the Southeast European Cooperative Initiative, which also has substantial American support. 
Underscoring the increasing American interest in the wider region, John F. Markey, director of regional law enforcement programs at the State Department, said in a speech here this week, "Assistance to Southeast Europe, Central Asia and the Caucasus in 2002 is approximately $1.8 billion -- a large percentage of it focused on rule of law and good governance." 
He said "the ability to control or interdict items of contraband and weapons of mass destruction" was a priority in supporting these efforts.
Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage helped initiate the joint dialogue between the regional group and the United States three years ago.
The United States has already committed $6 million for customs and border control improvements by the five-country grouping and is supporting World Bank loans for further enhancements.
The five countries, formerly part of the Soviet Union, are members of the Russian-led Commonwealth of Independent States, the grouping that emerged from the collapse of the Soviet Union. But their joint regional efforts are entirely separate.
"Russia is not a member," said David Soumbadze, an official of the Georgian Embassy here, "but it is not an anti-Russian alliance." 
"Our group has common problems, a common threat perception and, I hope, a common vision." 
A State Department official said efforts were being made to interest Armenia -- and eventually Russia -- in participating, or at least to send observers to the group's meetings.
Officials of the five countries will meet next month in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, to begin constructing a "virtual center" -- in cyberspace -- with a data bank integrating law enforcement information dealing with both conventional crime and terrorism. 
Meetings are also scheduled next month for customs officials in Kiev, Ukraine, and for border protection officials in Tblisi, Georgia. Overall strategy will be discussed in Yalta, Ukraine, in March.

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
Controversial Bishop Fights On in Retirement
 He really worries, he says, about "the soul of America." 
 In 1989, the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. retired as the Episcopal bishop of New York, ending a 17-year, often controversial tenure as an eminent embodiment of theologically and socially liberal Christianity. 
He ordained an avowed lesbian as a priest in 1977, the first ordination of a declared homosexual in the Episcopal ministry. He was an outspoken advocate of civil rights laws, antipoverty programs, nuclear disarmament and socially responsible behavior by corporate America. 
He could be blunt. In one Easter Sunday sermon, he declared that businesses that moved out of New York City while it struggled with severe fiscal problems were "like rats leaving a sinking ship." He also took on public officials, clashing repeatedly with Edward I. Koch, then the mayor, over issues involving homelessness. 
The bishop's supporters saw a cutting-edge clergyman guiding his church to a modern outlook and socially relevant role. Conservative Christians and other critics saw a "limousine liberal" in ecclesiastical vestments driving his church down a deviant road of endless left turns.
Fourteen years into retirement, Bishop Moore, who wrote a 1997 memoir, "Presences: A Bishop's Life in the City" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), maintains the same perspective as when his views drew a spotlight. In some cases, he says, his concerns have grown, as they have about homelessness in the city. "I think things are so much worse now," he said of the matter last week.
And the clergyman who ardently opposed the Vietnam War maintained that an American attack on Iraq would be "horrendous, killing thousands, even millions." 
In his retirement, several causes, including independence for East Timor, have been among his priorities. Formerly under a repressive occupation by Indonesia, East Timor became independent last year.
Bishop Moore, 83, has also taken part in efforts to preserve the battlefields on Guadalcanal, where, as a young Marine officer in World War II, he was gravely wounded by a bullet that narrowly missed his heart. His motive, he said, is to "help the economy" of the island by maintaining it as a draw for visitors.
These days, Bishop Moore said from his Manhattan home, he is in an uphill battle against an aggressive cancer. But he focuses on positives. "I feel I had 60 extra years," he said, citing his close call on Guadalcanal.

This Pioneer in Spaces Never Quite Took Off
In April, a resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, Theodore Angelus, turned on the ignition on a business idea: charging fees to bring together those seeking parking spaces in the area with those vacating them.
As Mr. Angelus, a former owner of a shaving implements company, outlined it, someone who paid $22.95 a month to his Street Parking Exchange was to call it a half-hour before leaving a space, and another member calling in search of a space would be told about the coming vacancy.
The scheme got press attention, but today it is as lifeless as a dead battery.
"It ran about six months," Mr. Angelus said last week. About 500 people signed up, he said, with about 100 giving him their credit card information to pay the fee. But he said he did not complete any transactions because the venture never seemed to be gaining traction.
"The basic problem was not enough callers who were leaving spaces," Mr. Angelus said. He reported losing about $5,000 in promotional costs.

HEADLINE: Trying to Put Mexico First, With No U.S. In the Way 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
U.S. out of Mexico!
 This is, in so many words, the cry rising in this country's Congress, where some are trying to change the nation's official name. That name is the United Mexican States. They prefer plain old Mexico. 
 The implications, it should immediately be clear, are large.
"The official name is a fawning imitation," said Ignacio Burgoa Orihuela, the nation's premier constitutional scholar. "It is wrong."
If so, it has been wrong since 1824.
When the United Mexican States came into being, its ministers had just won liberation from Spain. They took the name because, in part, they liked they way the white-wigged Americans had made a federal republic out of states. The Mexicans did things a little differently: they created their own states out of provinces, and a nation out of the states.
"The only model they had was the United States," said Lorenzo Meyer, a leading historian and social critic. "They wanted the past to disappear. The idea was to erase it."
But the admiration that created the United States of Mexico definitely diminished after the Americans took half of the country during the war in the 1840's. It is arguably still dwindling. 
Few in Mexico support a war with Iraq. Once friendly relations between President Vicente Fox and President Bush have cooled. In fact, it was the leaders of Mr. Fox's own party who moved the name change forward in Congress this week.
The tension between the word Mexico and the other official names that have appeared on maps and pesos has a long history. 
Mexico is a Nahuatl word, from the people who were here before the Spaniards came in 1519. Its origins are misty. It means "navel of the moon," and may derive from the reflection of the full moon in the great lake that once surrounded this capital. 
The Spanish sacked the city, drained the lake and changed the name to New Spain. The name stuck for three centuries, until the United Mexican States was coined.
The tension persists. "Maybe we should just erase 'Mexico' and keep 'United States,' " Mr. Meyer said. "That's the sad truth: we are an extension of that country."
A decidedly unscientific sampling of public opinion found some recognition of Mr. Meyer's "sad truth."
"In some ways we are almost part of the United States already," said Regina Solis, 34, a chemist in the city of Guaymas with two teenagers working as farmhands in the United States. "They invade us more and more, not with weapons, but in our daily lives. Soon we'll be using dollars instead of pesos.
"The government, instead of inventing idiocies like this, should be working to save our culture, our customs, our identity," she said.
But Congressman Felipe Calderon Hinojosa, the man behind the name- change movement, passionately believes that preservation is precisely what he is doing.
"For me, the name of our land is Mexico," Mr. Calderon, the leader of the National Action Party in the lower house of Congress, told a radio audience on Thursday. "People tend to forget that the official name is the United Mexican States. And when they remember, a great sinking feeling, a great restlessness, washes over them."
Mr. Burgoa, the constitutional scholar, said the idea's time had come.
"We are subordinated economically, politically and socially to the gringos," he said. "Nevertheless, the name must change. Legally, by definition, it is the wrong name."
